reviewText:
Early Access Review

SMALL UPDATE Jan 2016 - Check comments for details!

[ SUMMARY ] :
Space Engineers meets some StarMade and the exploration aspects of Shores of Hazeron.
I DON'T RECOMMEND buying this game right now, unless you're a HARDCORE FAN of sandbox and space games. I really mean that. Don't say you weren't warned.
I DO RECOMMEND watchlisting or following it if you like sandbox games in general.
If you want more details, read further to understand.

[ BACKGROUND AND DISCLAMERS ]:
- Me and Empyrion:
I got to know Empyrion through Scott Manley's Youtube Channel 2 weeks before the Steam Early Access Release, and decided that I would most definitely give it a go.
I went through ~97% of the game - I got all the resources I need and explored (probably) everything, but didn't build a Capital Ship yet.

- The Team:
Empyrion is made by 3 indie devs. They pushed through a failed kickstarter, and here is the (early) result. They seem nice, and determined.

- This Review:
I'll first describe the game with as little personal notes as possible, and in the end I'll give my take on whatever I find necessary. This way, I save both your time and mine! :)

[ REVIEW ] :

> INTRODUCTION:
Your capital ship crashes on an alien planet. Left with a escape pod, you must gather resources and craft your way back to space.
Crafting, mining, building, hunting, surviving, running for your life when things go wrong. You'd like that, wouldn't you?
Empyrion provides a very immersive and fresh experience for those who like survival and sandbox games.

> GAME FEATURES:

SURVIVING is your first priority and your constant goal in Empyrion. You must find Water to generate Oxygen, hunt, scavange or forage for food, and find Promethium Ore to make Fuel to power all your operations!

MINING is crucial. You'll need to find resource deposits and strike the earth in order to build your base, vehicles and personal items. Mining is done by equipping your drill and digging - vehicles don't mine yet.

CRAFTING and BUILDING is a main part of the game. Much like Space Engineers, every final item is comprised of components which you must craft first. Removing a block will return its components, so remember to bring your Removal Tool to rip those expensive components from ships and bases you find in your expeditions!
Building your base is straightforward, and can end up looking pretty nice.

VEHICLES are critical for survival, exploration and progress. You can build a hovering Ground Vehicle, Small Vessels for interplanetary and atmospheric flights (as well as small-scale combat and raids), or Capital Vessels for (not yet implemented) intergalatic travel and serious combat operations.

COMBAT can happen on ground or in space. You can also be inside a ship or on foot, which makes things great: what if you leave your ship, but get flanked or surprised by the enemy?
You can also hunt wildlife for food and resources.

The EXPLORATION vibe is definitely there. Even on initial release, you can't help but wonder what awaits you when you look at the night sky - or when seeing a weird building from a distance when you're still a survivor with just a escape pod. Maybe you could cannibalize or take over whatever that thing is, and turn it against your enemies (or against the unsuspecting wildlife)?
It's something I was looking forward in a survival sandbox space game for ages.

> GAME ASPECTS:

GRAPHICS: Very good for an indie game, but could definitely look better. Yet, I wasn't bothered by it.

SOUND:  Decent, but needs mastering, attention and variety - which are probably planned.

INTERFACE: Simple and straightforward, if you have played any similar games you'll be ready to go in minutes. The lack of a tutorial or proper in-game instructions WILL make things harder and more tiresome for non-hardcore fans. Be ready.

GAMEPLAY: Survive, mine, craft, build, fly. The gameplay and progression already feels nice, and the game doesn't take you by the hand. You're free to do whatever, whenever, however you decide.

BUGS AND ISSUES: There was a big number of release issues and bugs, some people even had their savegames corrupted or fallen out of the world. I didn't experience anything gamebreaking like that, but there's a lot of minor things that can get on the way of your fun. Still, it feels more polished than many Early Access titles I've played.

> PERSONAL NOTES:

= Positive:
- Regarding GAMEPLAY: Even though story and quests/missions are planned, I love how YOU choose where to go.
There's an obvious way to go about things (now I need X ore that's only available on Y planet in order to build Z item")
date: but you can ignore that and end up getting end-game gear by your own means and creativity. I REALLY hope this doesn't change with development.\n\n- Random
hoursPlayed: circumstance might surprise you. You might be distracted and hear a weird noise

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI was fully stocked and ready to move from Akua to Omicron, fully decked out ship filled to the brim with everything I needed to set up shop on omicron quick and easy. I was about halfway there when I had a great idea and decided to go to one of the little alien towers near the lava planet that looks like a satellite, I took out what I thought were all of the massive plasma rocket cannon thingies, pulled in close to go salvage the core and be on my way, when suddenly I heard a big huge explosion, I was face to face with a huge plasma turret which had been hidden on the other end of the satelllite. Just like that my ship was without any fuel tanks to power up with, my emergency ship parts at the time did not include fuel tanks, only RCS, generator, & a couple directional thrusters. I was distraught, there is no way to get back down to my large constructors on Akua to repair the ship. I'm going to lose a whole days worth of preparation and it's gonna be a sad day. That's when I checked my inventory one last time and saw a spare core, it was at this time I knew I only had 1 option left. Assault the massive alien base that looks like a giant satellite on foot, with nothing but my assault rifle, 250~ bullets, & my trusty remove & repair tool. I set off towards the gigantic intimidating space station, the closer I got, the more I knew this was going to end with my backpack floating around in space, lost forever. The base was absolutely covered head to toe with those giant plasma rocket turrets, usually the bases on a planet have 5-6, sometimes even 10 turrets that can destroy a basic SV in 1-2 hits, this base had at least 30-40 rocket turrets on the outside. I charged the station, zig zagging up & down, left & right, just narrowly avoiding what felt like thousands of missiles and plasma blasts. I slammed against the side of the station and immediately used my remove&repair tool to bust inside, where I was met with a space station full of automatic turrets that were shooting the ♥♥♥♥ out of me and causing me to panic. I cleared the first room of turrets and took a moment to think, my oxygen was running very low, time was getting shorter, at this point I figured I'd never forgive myself if I came all this way for nothing, so I pressed on. I went through a hallway in to a room that was covered in turrets, I took them out with my assault rifle from afar, upon walking in, I hear and see a huge explosion right in front of me, one of the massive plasma cannons outside had shot a hole in the wall of the space station, blowing up several fuel tanks and almost killing me. Short on oxygen, health, food, & ammo, things were looking grim. Eventually, I fought my way to the top of the space station, where I was overcome with joy when I found a small room containing the core, a fuel tank, and 2 constructors. I did it! I replaced the core with my own, threw some fuel in the tanks, & made myself a brand new fuel tank for my SV. I have never felt so victorious in any game ever, against insurmountable odds, I managed to fight my way though a hail of gunfire, giant face-melting missiles, & a dwindling oxygen tank to salvage my ship and my mission. I returned to Akua to make some much needed cosmetic repairs to my ship, as well as a lot more armor covering just about everything on the ship that can explode when shot by those horrifyingly powerful turrets. Learned my lesson after that, always have a plan b in this game, because if you're not prepared for just about anything, you're going to have to pull some crazy ♥♥♥♥ like that in order to salvage the situation :P

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I’m not here to sell it to you. What I do want to do, is give you a fair assessment of the game.
This is a Pre-Alpha game. I’m writing this while the game is currently at PA 3.5.something-or-other (*1). That said, there are some things that it lacks. A plot for one. If you want a story (as of right now) move along. If you are expecting perfection, move along. If you’re expecting a million dollars, get in line, send me half, or move along.

I read through several reviews of this game before and after purchasing it. Those who have played the game for less than an hour have generally (and undeservingly) given negative reviews. Yes, this game has issues. It’s not perfect (*2). It has some flaws. But to insult a game based on less than 60 minutes because it’s not perfect or does not fit your play style is not entirely fair.

Those who have played 40+ hours and have given it negative reviews; I have read them and can relate to most of their frustrations and experiences. Read them! (*3) You may find that what you and the reviewer expect from a game that (currently) costs about $20 are similar. If they sway you away from buying the game, that’s fine.

Things to help you with a decision:
Do you/did you like Minecraft; before the Ender Dragon and “beating the game”?

Do you like survival games? Imagine Seven Days to Die - in space, without the never ending hordes of zombies ripping your base (that you spent 20 hours on) apart in minutes. (Although there’s drones to worry about, but there’s way’s to avoid them)

Do you enjoy challenges? Figure it out on your own, or pull up your trusty search engine and start researching. Either way, there’s lots of trial and error.

Are you expecting perfection? This game is well made. Hell, I’d imagine a few big name companies releasing it “as is” with all the hype and a very large Zero-Day patch followed by several patches and DLC’s later to make it a real game… It’s not perfect. Not by a long shot, but it’s progressing. Very well too.

Are you okay with dumping hours and hours (20-60) into a game, knowing that there’s a possibility to  lose it all when a new patch comes out? All in the name of progress?

As of right now, this game is Minecraft in space. Similar to Space Engineers, but not quite. While there’s no real goal other than to survive, it’s going to be more than that when it’s through. It reminds me a lot of SDtD: the textures, the crafting style, etc. But it’s more enjoyable because there’s not random zombies and hordes spawning every 15-30 minutes hell bent on tearing apart all you’ve worked for. Although, there are “waves” of drones now every 20-30 minutes. They’re pretty easily overcome and there’s a warning too.

Do you enjoy developer support? This game has it. I have emailed the game developers on several occasions and have received plenty of personal replies back. It lets me know that my voice matters. I’m contributing and not just some a stupid consumer who has nothing offer. The community is helping and the developers listen! Their forum's very active. http://empyriononline.com/forums

That said, there’s been several times I’ve found myself stuck/lost/stranded and unable to “progress”. Some of these times have been my own fault. I didn’t know any better, or I didn’t prepare, etc. People who complain about losing hours of work because of this or that happening, should take advantage of the “backup” system. People who tell of losing weeks because of corrupted save files have my sympathies. I too, have lost hours of play time because of corrupted saves. It’s pre-alpha. I have walked away from this game (and subsequently, the computer) so often in the last few months that my wife is no longer surprised at me beginning a conversation with her over a cigarette and some coffee (or a beer) in the garage (*4). This game has its faults, to be sure. However. This game really fills a niche - for me at least.

This game has its problems:
There’s no plot. After you’ve “done” everything, there’s not much more to do but wait around or start over.

There’s some glitches: You can fall through the map. Yup. It’s 2015 and games still break like that. Check out their forum for more. http://empyriononline.com/forums/bugs.24/

Please, be informed before you buy this game! Honestly if I could give a “Mixed” recommendation, I would. I know this game is not for everyone, but it really bothers me when people give negative reviews because it doesn’t “fit” their style. But then again... (*3)

*1 Not the official version.
*2 Who is, really?
*3 But, you know, do what you want. I’m not a cop or anything.
*4 Just kidding. I don’t so much talk to her as such. It’s more I stare at my beer while she stares at her Kindle, reading.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Land on strange planet.  Build a base.

Wildlife appears docile at first.  Go out scavenging for food and materials.

In a hole, mining random ore when a carniverous plant falls in and tries to eat my face.  Shotgun it in its...face...thing.

Hours and loads of ore later, floating in space building a *huge* capital ship.  Warp to another planet (Omicron).

Think my capital vessel is badass because...guns.  Approach starbase in asteroid field.

Starbase has much pew-pew capital ship becomes swiss cheese fast.  Retreat to nearby planet, forgets fore thrusters are destroyed.

Can't stop fast enough, plummet into the stratosphere.  Stranded on Omicron, capital ship is now makeshift temporary base.

Good thing I still have my dropship in the hangar.  And thank god the cargo is in-tact.

10/10 would crash again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: As I first make it into space, like a child being born, I was in awe of the beauty and the distant habitable planets in view. Then kaboom. Two drones, one laser, one plasma, blew my ship to shreds and I am now floating in free space with nothing but a handful of emergency rations and the limited oxygen supply in my space suit. A silouette of what appears to be a research station just outside the nearest asteriod belt catches my eye and I immediately turn towards it purging the last few pounds of O2 in my space suit to gain forward velocity. The two drones lurk behind me relentlessly firing.
As I get closer to the research station, I notice it's heavily armed with auto plasma turrets and AI drones. I am almost out of O2 now, the immediate future feels very grim at this time. I push on. If I could just sneak past the enemies and slip into the space station, I could probably find an O2 station and a few mre rations to get me by temporarily. I'm approaching the near vicinity of the turrets detection range now and all turrets begin attacking in sync. Now I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥. They blew up the ship I spent hours perfecting, then chased me all the way through the asteroid field, and are now joining forces with this hostile facility in a mutual effort to end my existence. I'm now almost completely out of O2, so I use the last of it flying around the turrets in circles until they literally shoot each other trying to hit me as I purposely time the cycle of their shots to dodge at the right time. But what their scanners didn't pick up is that this man is Chuck Norris. So I destroyed the AI core and replaced it with my own, and powered up my new space base :)



If you are a fan of sci-fi entertainment and voxel based sandbox games, buy this game now.

First of all, this is one of the few early access games out there that is not only regularly updated but actively developed by the dev team. Now for the content review.

Empyrion is a free roaming sandbox game, where you fight for survival in an open universe. You begin the game plummeting through the atmosphere in a small escape pod watching the surface of the planet you chose get closer and closer. After crashing down sometimes on land or at the bottom of an ocean, you leave your vessel behind and begin your journey.

In Empyrion, you can freely build bases, hovercraft, space vehicles, galactic space travel vessels, even space stations or asteroid mining facilities. The sky is the limit, as you can easily build anything you can imagine using the unique construction system. The beautiful part about buiding is the simulated physics. For example, if you have too much weight on one side of your ship, you will directly feel that imbalance when you pilot the vessel. The placement of all objects, balance, thruster force and direction, are all factors that affect the way your ship flys, including turning speed, and even precise directional acceleration. You have full access to fuel consumption, power generation, power drain and other data directly from the cockpit. Take my word, the ship system is amazing in its complexity and is very satisfying.

Dedicated servers are out, so you can host, join a public pvp/pve, etc.

Crafting. Oh yes, the sweet sweet glory of crafting. As you level up, you earn points that are used to upgrade your tech tree, unlocking more blueprints at the various types of constructors available. The crafting system is very polished. The devs really put hard work into making it not feel grindy and making it fun and rewarding. There are TONS of awesome sci-fi themed items to build, not even including all the weapons and vehicle materials. Too much to cover all details here.

Mining.
oh.my.god.....
You have to either watch a video or buy this game now to see how rediculously amazing it is. Finally!!! You can freely mine any shape or direction or size you want without stupid little blocks everywhere. Thank you devs. Much appreciated.This is exactly what we sandbox addicts have been craving. I feel like the guys and gals that made this game sat down with each other, and agreed to build a familiar sandbox game this time with all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ issues addressed that other similar games ignore . You know what I mean guys...

Sorry my phone is on 3% and I dont want to lose this review text so I gotta end this now. Look at my time gamers... trust me and indulge in your sandbox addiction and buy this twenty dollar jewel right now. Thank you devs for making and continually improving this fulfilling experience that me and my brothers thoroughly enjoy!

EDIT:
I apologize for not already mentioning the fact that you can fly directly off any planet with NO loading screens. Having seamless transitions makes this game very fulfilling as you explore the universe and random POI's (points of interest) which are randomly generated and mostly hostile facilities that you can find anywhere. Some of them have a VAST underground complex that quite frankly, is very difficult to conquer. Most of the poi's that you find have plasma and machine turrets that will kill you and blow up your ship so be very careful flying around these. Park with a mountain to cover your vessel from enemy fire and then go on foot to pillage and loot and DESTROY THE ALIENS. There are so many adventures to be had in Empyrion. Why are you still reading this review and not buying this game?

Early Access Review

I'm writing this review because I'm seeing a ton of negative reviews as of the free weekend and its not really fair because all the negative reviews are from people that played between 10 minutes to 30 minutes.   To those people that are ♥♥♥♥♥ing about how they are getting killed by drones and whatever, its called galactic SURVIVAL.  It's a SURVIVAL game.   Yes, you can spend hours building a ship only to get it destroyed.  You don't get to build a a small ship and then think you're going to easily wipe out everything in the whole solar system with a single gatling gun and never take damage.

I've been playing this game from the beginning and the devs are ALWAYS adding more and more new stuff.  Trust the reviews from people that have played more than an hour, not these people that start the game and are like where's my epic ship?  I've been playing 10 minutes already.  This game sucks.  Delete.""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an amazing game for Space Engineer players looking for a game a bit less Mechanical and more Survival. You start off right now on a crashed Planet in an escape pod. You have some basic survival gear in the escape pod as well as the ability to cannibalize the pod it'self. From here you survival the harsh planet environment slowly building up a base with oxygen collectors and creating food by growing and harvesting or even hunting the wild life of the planet and cooking their meat.

From here you end up building a Ground Vehicle to explore the planet and then slowly move to a Small Ship where you can explore the stars. After that you can even build a larger sized ship and much much more.

There is so much to do there is many things to explore and this is only the start.. So far in Closed Alpha (Before Steams Early Access) the game has had nothing but content updates after content updates. If I was to judge it from Space Engineers I would say in a simple 2 Months or so I seen more updates then a year worth of content in Space Engineers.

There is a lot of Similarity to Space Engineers. But Space Engineers is a Engineers Building Game. Empyrion is a Survival Action game.

I can't see what is in store for this game in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Best Game on Steam....


Playing the Pre-Alpha for more than 1k+ hours  I must say this is absolutely the best Game in its Genre.
In creative mode you can build your Small vessels, Bases (ground and orbit), Capital Vessels and Hover vessels. Then you can blueprint your build and upload them to the workshop. If you are not a good builder you can download other peoples blueprints and use them in game. Not only do these blueprints work in Creative mode, they work in Survival mode for Single player or Multiplayer.

There is tons to explore. If your tired of exploring the planet you are on just build a ship and go to orbit and see whats there....
There are no Cutscenes" when leaving planet to go into orbit. A second or two delay as you change playfields

Early Access Review

Video Review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VP0rIP8q0gc

I have really enjoyed my time with the game despite the numerous bugs and issues. It has the potential to be a great game. Currently it offers about 10 - 20 hours of gameplay.

Pros:

+ Great Atmosphere
+ Deep Construction Mechanics
+ Long Progression Curve
+ Lots of Room for Expansion
+ Spaceships!
+ 60 FPS

Cons:

- Poor Visuals
- Complex Mechanics with Limited Tutorial
- Lots of Small Bugs
- No Manual Save
- Limited Multiplayer
- Very Ambitious

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion - Galactic Survival (which I'll refer to as E: GS from now on) is an early access survival game (stay with me here) currently taking place across four planets and in Space. In E: GS you begin your fight for survival on a barren, desert planet called Omicron next to your escape pod which is beyond repair. In the distance you see the remains of your Capital ship and exploring the planet not only reveals ore deposits but it also reveals strange structures and hostile drones wandering the planet.

Now you're probably thinking why on Earth should anyone be interested in yet another Early Access game, simply put E: GS does something no other survival game, to my knowledge, has done; it gives you three entire planets to explore as well as the ability to travel around in Space. The next thing that might spring to mind for you is how is this any different to Space Engineers? E: GS is fundementally different to SE, E: GS is more focused on the Survival side of things whereas SE is more focused on the creativity in building side of things, plus SE doesn't have planets.

Since some of this game's issues are more serious than others I'll split my negative section into two, the first section having a much larger impact on my overall verdict than the second.

+E: GS manages to add something new to an already crowded genre and it does it reasonably well
+You're given a great deal of freedom in regards to crafting bases, vehicles etc. So long as you have the key components for whatever it is you're building (key components are listed by the starting block for each thing) you can add whatever you want and make it look however you want it to look and still be able to use it, though practicality is often something worth considering with vehicles
+Speaking of starting blocks, each large project (i.e. a base, a ground vehicle, a small cruiser or a capital cruiser) has a corresponding starter block which provides the ship's foundations. A starter block gives you access to a menu detailing your project's stats, such as power consumption, but it also gives you a list of the components which your project MUST have in order to function, such as a fuel tank or a cockpit
+There are already a lot of different items which can be crafted ranging from tools and weapons to thrusters and generators
+The three planets are all very different to each other, each one with its own distinct appearance as well as different creatures and plants
+The game's controls are, for the most part, good though using the mouse for turning in vehicles sometimes feels a tad bit sluggish
+The devs are already updating the game frequently, hopefully that'll continue throughout the game's development
+E: GS already features multiplayer and there are plans to improve it over the course of the game's development process
+The four planets are procedurally generated. What does this mean? While the four planets will always be the same, everything on the planet's surface will be randomized everytime you play with a different seed, e.g. where resources can be found and where enemies spawn

+/-E: GS' graphics aren't awful but they aren't exactly easy on the eye either, it doesn't take away from the game as a whole (hence it's in the neutral section) but considering the fact there are currently no solid plans to improve the game's graphics it is somewhat disappointing

Major Negatives:
-Crafting items is unbelievably tedious, which is a problem in a game where so much of the gameplay is based around crafting things. Every major item, such as a generator, requires several different components for you to make it, some of these components require other components to make them, all of your components require some sort of ingot or equivalent item and each ingot has to be made from the ore. At face value it isn't awful but when you add into the mix the fact that you can only craft one type of item at a time, the fact that most things take between 5-20 seconds to craft one unit of and the fact that the crafting machines have small inventories for you to store raw materials as well as completed items it starts to become clear why E: GS' crafting system is its biggest problem
-The four currently available worlds feel empty, apart from the occasional hostile structure or drone and the creatures that inhabit these worlds there is literally nothing to see on the worlds other than the ore in the ground. Futhermore, to counteract this ore deposits are very spread out, a nice idea in theory but frustrating when a round trip to get more ore takes 10 minutes while you're still on foot
-Despite the fact that silica is one of the most important ingredients in crafting (used in some capacity to make pretty much every major component) it's seemingly incredibly rare which is rather frustrating when you run out of it and have no means of finding more

Minor Negatives:
-Unlike in Space Engineers, colliding with terrain in a vehicle has no effect on the terrain though it does still damage your vehicle
-There's currently very little in the way of character customisation
-Sound effects are pretty hit and miss as to whether or not they sound realistic and apart from on the main menu there's no music in the game
-The in-game menu can't be accessed while the game is paused which means if you wish to tweak your settings or controls you can't do so unless you want to risk not pausing your game

Verdict:
Worth Purchasing On Sale (6.5/10)

E: GS is a good survival game which gives you a lot of freedom when it comes to building things and surviving but it's currently let down by its tedious crafting system.  E: GS has a lot of potential and hopefully the game will only get better as time goes on but for now, wait until a sale unless you're willing to look past the game's major issues.

Review Copy Provided.

No drama, Just Reviews.

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a fan of Space Engineers with over 3000 hours of building in that game, I have been playing Empyrion for the last couple of months testing it out.
Most people who have  played SE will enjoy playing Empyrion.
The feel of the games are different from each-other flight controls are different.
Empyrion focuses much more on survival than building, though you can build much bigger structures in Empyrion without lag and the block size in Empyrion is 2m for large blocks and .5m for small blocks. [SE 2.5m blocks for large and .5 for small]  This results in large builds with large blocks ending up much slicker and less blocky, It also means you need to place alot more blocks for the same size ship.
There is going to be a levelling up system and theres alot of blocks still missing in the game, but it has more blocks and items than SE does right now in pre-alpha so it can only get better from there.
The AI in the game is pretty good for there first version, alot of fun with the drones in space around the Xentor station, you can go to 3 planets and a moon at the moment, and asteroids,  the planets are being seperated at a later stage in development when the procedual map generator is put into the game.
The performance of this game on a good pc is awesome if your used to SE performance.
The developers are very friendly, Eleon Game Studio read there forum often and respond to alot of posts, its awesome to see that.
Like SE and KEEN I wish Eleon the best with this game and I hope its very successful for them and I thank them for the hours of enjoyment I have ahead in survival. My current game is 4 weeks old has multiple big bases, a big ship, multiple small ships, stuff going on on all the bases, and its not lagging at all. Fantastic stuff. Playing on amd 9590 and 16g ram with r9 290.

Game has alot of different creatures in it already, alot of them will attack you, be armed or suffer, there are alot of plant models already in the game, but you can see there are still alot more to come, like trees, you can collect all sorts of things, most of the plants you see around have a use and can be harvested, the creatures [ ai ] are pretty good for pre-alpha, a few of them are deadly, there are drones that hunt you if you go into particular areas.
You can collect meat from animals you kill, parts ammo and fuel from downed drones, you can build your base or ships block by block to whatever shape you like, Empyrion has alot of curved blocks already, it has interior decorative blocks as well, you can really replicate sci fi show ships with ease in Empyrion because of the extra time the developers have put into interior blocks, nice job devs.
You can build on the planet, under ground, in water, under water, or in space or on an asteroid or in an asteroid, so building is very free range.
Water doesnt flow, yet.
Lava doesnt flow, yet.
The graphics are pretty good, DX9 or DX11, both look nice, alot of blocks are placeholders but still look pretty good, the game is high definition textures, and has a performance mode or quality graphics mode that it can be played in, the options for video are getting better every few weeks, the patches are big, alot of content and alot of bugfixes, the developers are very friendly and have added alot of player made structures to the game and my impression is they want more for there huge universe they need to fill.
Flying mechanics in Empyrion are much more precise than SE, a little arcade like even, makes for much more enjoyable dogfights, alot more fun to fly ships in Empyrion in my opinion.
Havent had much to do with the hover craft, built a couple , over the lakes there alot of fun to race, but I use an SV for survival hunting.
Hoping the developers get super filthy rich from this game and fully develop it, Empyrion will be a master piece when its completed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion - Galactic Survival is a space open world survival game with randomly generated planets and with heavy crafting and building elements. When I say open world, I really mean it, in the sense that if you have some sort of spacecraft you can fly across space and land on any planet you choose.

The game offers you two different game modes at the moment, creative and survival. Creative is what you’d expect, build and do whatever you like, your imagination is your limit. As for the survival mode, you’re able to choose different seeds to create your worlds and you can also choose where you’d like to begin your adventure, in a more friendly planetnet with a breathable atmosphere or in a more deadly desert planet that is perfect for hardcore players. Since I’m not really someone who is very creative or that enjoys building, survival is always what I go for in these types of games.

The core:
On survival mode you’ll find yourself looking for oxygen, food and other resources. The game provides a pretty in-depth tutorial covering survival, base and ship building. Food can be acquired by hunting, gathering or farming and it can get spoiled. This can be prevented by either cooking or by storing food on a fridge. The oxygen can be obtained by placing a O2 generator on water, which then will begin producing bottles of oxygen. Resource gathering is pretty simple since you start with the tools needed, simply aim and click with the right tool to the place you want to mine. Still, every tool requires a certain type of charges to use so be careful not to waste all your charges before you’ve gathered the resources needed to craft more. One thing I really like about the game is the fact that when you discover a ore deposit, it will be marked on your map which is a 3D representation of the planet you’re in. If you check the map, you can also see how many, and what type of deposits you still haven’t found on the planet.

Empyrion also has some other mechanics which make it somewhat more challenging and engaging, such as stamina, a jetpack and blueprint “trees”. You use stamina while sprinting so you have to keep an eye out in case you’re being followed by some mobs and run out of stamina. Nonetheless, you still have your jetpack which, despite making you unable to run, allows you to escape tricky situations including when you get trapped while mining downwards (never dig downwards). By performing simple actions such as gathering resources or crafting you’ll gain experience points, these will allow you to level up and gain points which you can use to unlock certain blueprints/recipes on some sort of “skill tree” menu.

Assuming you have the required blueprints and materials, crafting is pretty straight simple since the game tells you what a certain item needs in order to be crafted. Building is likewise pretty straightforward, you just select on your hotbar the block you want to place and click where you want it, and you can also fly a drone to help you build in more tricky spots where your character can’t properly reach. If farming is an option in a survival game, I tend to go that route, thus I must say I quite enjoy how farming plays out in Empyrion. Basically you place “growing plot” blocks, place whatever seed you want and then you have to make sure that a light source is 2 blocks above it. The plant won’t grow immediately of course so you can go on another errands while you wait for your crops to be ready to harvest.

One minor complaint I have with the game is the fact that there are no reload animations. Still, I’m sure this is due to the Early Access nature of the title and that is something that will be implemented soon. That said, combat is serviceable at best, you just aim and shoot, the weapons have pretty much no recoil or authentic feel to them and I believe this is something that should be worked on. Despite the dynamic day and night cycle (where if you look at the sky you can see the other planets far off), I didn’t notice any change in mobs behaviour which kind of disapointed me.

Verdict:Huge amount of things to craft
Space and planetary exploration
Overall decent performance - except a few slowdowns when visiting new areas
Well done ambient and background sound effects + pretty great main menu theme
Detailed tutorial, which welcomes newcomers
Dated visuals - as far as I care, the game looks somewhat dated
Empyrion - Galactic Survival is the closest thing to what I want from a game that combines space and planetary exploration. Even if you’re like me and don’t like building, you can just import creations from other players from the Workshop, in the form of blueprints, and get them in your world. I highly recommend you check this one out if you’re into space exploration and survival! I’m looking forward to see how this one develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am a huge fan of sandbox games and I have a large number of them in my library. Some are good and some are bad and every once in a while I find one that really just surprises me at how good it is....Empyrion is one of those that has surprised me at just how good it is.

The survival aspect of the game is great....it has some of the usual aspects of most sandboxes such as mining, leveling, crafting, farming, base/ship building and exploration.  Most of these are similar to other games so I will touch on each of these briefly.

MiningMining is done by scouting out the planet and a scanner locating deposits. Once a suitable deposit of ore is found you use a drill to extract the ore. It does take some time to mine much like most sandboxes, but oddly it seems more satisfying in Empyrion to me than other games even though I cannot pinpoint exactly why. Once you are done with the drill you can then press T" to pickup the mined ore to take back to base from processing said ore into ingots.

Leveling/Tech TreeThere is leveling and a tech tree that go hand-in-hand.  Basically
date: you start out at level 1 and as you do certain tasks suchs as mining
recommended: building or farming you gain experience towards the next level. You also gather points that you can spend learning new things to craft via the Tech Tree in the game. This is broken up into various tabs such as Hover Vessel
hoursPlayed: Space Vessel
voteText: Capital Vessel
helpfulPercent: Base
votesHelpful: Decor and a few others. So each time you level you get to learn new craftable items. While this is not something new
votesTotal:
it is still great fun!

CraftingCrafting is done via Constructors. Constructors are large multi-block structures that craft items for you. These constructors come in various sizes and versions. At the start of the game you get a simple "Survival Constructor" and as you progress through the game you gain access to create more advanced constructors.  The more advanced constructors are slightly faster and the top tier constructor allows for auto-assembly of items by automatically constructing pre-requisite items for whatever item you may want to build. It saves quite a bit of time.

FarmingYou can farm in the game via seeds
votesFunny: growth boxes and grow lights. You simply put a box down place a grow light over the box and plant the seed and over time plants will grow and produce food. You can grow things such as tomatoes and wheat to more exotic plant life found in the game. You can then use the food you harvest in a Food Processor to create food some food is simple one item recipes while some are more complex and give extra bonuses.\n\nBase/Ship BuildingThis is one of the areas I love in the game. It's your typical build a base
commentsCount: build power
column16: build a support system for you and your base. There are some great blocks to use for building such as curves and angles like most sandbox games along with turrets
column17: that are both automated or manned
column18: O2 generation
column19: water filtration
column20: medical bays
column21: cargo boxes and various other exciting things.\n\nShip building is probably my favorite aspect of the game. You can build various ships such as Hover Vessels (HV)
column22: Space Vessels (SV) and Capital Vessels (CV). Each of these are as you expect
column23: HV's simply hover over the ground and allow you to move around the planet faster than walking. SV's allow you to fly around the planet and even exit the planet's orbit and fly around a specified area around the planet including asteroid belts around the planet and any moons that the planet may have. CV's are the largest ships and allow you to add warp drives to them that allow you to visit other planets and systems. CV's also allow you to dock SV's to them so you can use your CV to transport SV's to other planets for exploration.\n\nExplorationThis is another great aspect to the game. When starting out you start on a single planet and can explore this planet finding alient life
column24: alien bases
column25: attack drones of various types
column26: ore deposits
column27: plant life and other players.  What I think sets Empyrion apart from some of the other sandbox games is the existence of numerous planets each with its own type of plants
column28: aliens
column29: POI's and ores.  Some items can only be found on these planets and are required to fully craft everything in the game
column30: so it makes for great fun hopping in a Capital Ship and warping to another planet and exploring it.\n\nIn conclusion
column31: I'd highly suggest Empyrion as it just does everything right and since it is still pre-alpha (surprisingly because the game is well polished) I can't wait to see what awaits the game in the future.  With what seems to be a very active dev team I feel purchasing this game would well be worth it if you enjoy sandbox style games or even if you just like space-based games that allow you to fly and build ships no matter how large. If you are looking for a great sandbox...give Emyprion a shot

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Open World Survival meets Tower Defense in the best 3D space adventure I’ve played so far. With realistic mining for rare elements, terraforming, exploration, & hunting; it provides a PVE experience that is a delight to play, even in early access.

State of the Art:
Empyrion has a full suite of heavy duty tools, equipped with lights for night/cave mining & terraforming, like a futuristic drill, & a Flatten/Fill tool for terraforming. It can drill in a pinch, but it can also repair holes in your mine roof to keep spiders out. In creative mode, your jetpack flies. In survival it has limited gravity jumps that can result in injury. You start with a handgun, but the assault rifle upgrade has a powerful feel. You can add other weapons, turrets & machinery as you upgrade. The interaction of component parts just feels great!

Flora & Fauna:
With the wide variety of indigenous plants & animals; you feel like you’ve just stepped into Arthur Conan Doyle’s Lost World, or the set from Lost in Space or Guardians of the Galaxy. But, there is no cool 70’s walkman or choosing music tracks, which would probably be a welcome plus. The game soundtrack is good, but the two scores will get repetitive if you play this much. (If you saw The Martian movie you know we need more music.)
There are edible & Medicinal plants, like Ahax fruit, Alien Spike Lemons, Space Oranges, Cobra leaves, Aloe Vera, & varieties of Alien plasma. Fearsome creatures become dinner, like the multi-headed Hydra-like Olyugh, the Desert Worm, Wood walkers who looks like Sasquatch, a warrior type AI, a baby Allosaurus & triceratops. Some are hostile, others will be if provoked.

Skill Trees & Game Modes:
You find yourself falling from the sky in an escape pod if you are lucky, or already on the ground in the pod if it glitches on loading. If you are still in freefall, you are able to steer the pod’s fall with the mouse. Once you get out of the pod you grab all your gear. The last update to 1.4.0 fixed the ability to open pods that land in water, as well as improving functionality of turrets.
The game uses an efficient Tech tree system to allow you to unlock equipment as you earn levels which reset for each game you play & augments the rewards of the strategy & resource management needed to survive on this level.
Game Modes give lots of variety with Creative or Survival Modes of PVE & PVP in MP. But, within Survival worlds, at the moment you are only able to choose between the normal forest planet of Akua or the Hardcore Desert planet of Omicron. Akua is Hawaiian for “god” & definitely looks like a lost world paradise. Omicron is where the intensity picks up, with more scarcity of resources that are spread further apart, & volatile terrain. You have a seed generator for terrain variety. If you land near the drones it’s all over before it begins. The drones are real techno-beasts & you probably can’t evade them early game.

Crafting:
The crafting interface can be confusing at first. Production flows right to left with the queue on bottom. Click the template you want, to move it to the queue to be constructed. Then the new item you wanted is output into the constructor's inventory space. You can move what you want from there to your own inventory or hot-bar.

Space Travel & Vehicles:
The game allows you to set up not only a home base on a planet or in space, but you can construct a “hover vehicle” which is a fully stocked mobile base, equipped with fridge & food facilities for mining & hunting. You can also build small aircraft & capital vessels which can equip warp-drive to visit other planets & mine asteroid fields. In MP asteroids land for mining elements. In early access only 2 planets are available, though you can see the full list on the warp map.
Each base/vehicle has a “starter block” with a core which emits a beacon when the power is turned on. When you build it, equip it, & power it up then prepare for an incoming drone siege that will last until you are able to dispatch drones quickly.  You must be well stocked with food before powering up that generator. This creates a game of tower defense. The drones will try to destroy the core starter block. Once you lose that block the game is for all practical purposes over, giving it a perma-death element. You have the option to restart at the location you die near your backpack. But, if drones were there, they will still be there when you respawn at half stats & they will likely kill you again before you can recover your weapon. The game also gives you the option to respawn near your base or take a fresh start, but the fresh start is a bad choice. It will put you in a falling pod with fewer resources. Best option is to exit the game & start a whole new world. You can build a clone chamber once you have a base that will set your spawn point. This is a great feature.

Mapping & Graphics:
The game runs on much less hardware than stated. The graphics seem to be similar on my screenshots to what people who have better machines are experiencing. There’s no lag. The first day I flew the small vessels I experienced holes in my terrain, but that was cleared up by the next day’s update. The scenery is lovely, but the graphics are subpar resolution in the current access state.
The mechanic of space travel is less well developed than the planetary aspects of the game mechanics. You experience a slideshow of backgrounds as you leave the planet’s atmosphere, enter orbit, go deep space, & finally approach a new planet. You move around in each slide, but it has a bottom of the picture. I accidentally fell off the space station in deep space. I visibly fell for a few seconds, & then my avatar just stood there among the stars at the bottom of the background scenery in a “stop the world & I’ll jump off” effect.
The in-game HUD utilizes a nice planetary mapping system with marker/beacons for different points of interest, like bases, rare elements, & drones. The space map needs work but does not affect the fun to be found in this great game. Visible location coordinates would be nice.

Tutorial:
The tutorial is really just simply the PDA info displayed one subchapter at a time on the right side of the HUD as missions. The instructions will not move forward until you do that mission. Also, it won’t remember actions that you’ve done early, so you have to repeat actions to get that mission objective to progress to the next step. You can deactivate chapters in the PDA, but you will lose subchapter steps. Also, there is no pause feature in the game, & reading or opening the PDA wastes your limited O2 & food while you stand around reading a TL:DR wall of text. I hope this is a priority because it leads to frustration trying to figure out what to do as a new player. Like Elon Musk says, “If it needs a manual it is broken.” I would like to see a computer generated voice-over speaking to you from your PDA, kind of like HAL in 2001, giving you an emergency briefing to get you started on the HUD mission log.

Pros:
•	Hardcore Tower/Base Defense
•	Workshop to share ready-made build Templates
•	Flight controls are intuitive
•	Plug & play construction
•	Planetary exploration includes excellent game mechanics
•	Underpriced at $17.99/ many games in this tier $30.00

Cons:
•	No weather & Space Travel is subpar
•	AI (except drones) are unintelligent
•	PDA not noticeable in HUD. Lack of real Tutorial
•	The ‘hit-boxes’ seem a bit small slowing collection

If you are dreaming of exploring planets, then Empyrion is the space sim for you. I rate it an 8 out of 10 for survival games, with elements of tower defense & resource management. I highly recommend this game for everyone. If the tutorial is augmented & the space mechanics are perfected I will change my review to a perfect ten.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Got a buddy who enjoys a good cooperative survival scenario as much as you? Give Empyrion a shot.

The Positive:
Me and my buddy Meowmix have been gaming for years and we both love a good survival scenario. This game really impressed us, it was the first game in a long time that had hooked us with the gameplay. Many early access titles hook you with the premise, then fail to deliver with the initial gameplay, but Empyrion is in a very playable state and there is actually a lot to do and figure out.

The game captures the survival scenario very well, I was impressed. It is not easy to create a challenging survival game, but the developers did well here. You need to assess, prioritize, and address your immediate needs or you will die. If you ♥♥♥♥ up and play fast-and-loose with your resources too much, you can paint yourself into a corner where you need to restart. That consequence looms over you as you play and I feel like the potential for a permanent end to my scenario was a driving factor to buckle the ♥♥♥♥ down and figure out how to sustainably address my needs for power, oxygen, food, and defense.

The oxygen system is worth commending. It felt balanced. I didn't have to constantly top off my oxygen or spend too much time managing it, but it was always a factor. In a typical sandbox survival game, your resource bars usually just become an annoyance; they are just another factor to survival condensed into a linear measurement. In Empyrion there is an initial concern of running out of oxygen and the clock is ticking, but once you figure out how to produce oxygen bottles in a sustainable fashion; your oxygen now limits how far you can travel from your refilling stations. It was brilliant, and it gave me a reason to invest my resources in a land vehicle that could serve as a mobile refilling station. This is necessary to explore the planet you are marooned on and reach metal deposits that are outside of walking distance.

There were a lot of moments of desperation and perseverance. When you die, you drop all your items on the ground in a backpack then spawn with nothing. There was one time I lost a backpack, and with it went my mining tool and firearm as well as all the ammunition I had. To make things worse, we didn't have enough material to create another mining tool to replace it. We were also low on the material needed to craft more ammunition, which was a major concern. Fortunately, I had a partner. My buddy Meowmix still had his mining tool and enough charge to go scrape up enough minerals to replace my tool and keep us in business. The act of losing my items forced us to shift our focus and adapt; I feel like that is the essence of survival. Well done.


The Negative:
The game looks like half-life. Boxy and generally unpolished, the developers clearly narrowed their focus on the gameplay instead of making it look super-polished. This actually doesn't bother me, but I could see it being a point of contention for some.

Wait.. Space Engineers just added planets recently. Did I just type up a review for the wrong game? No, I have hours played here I was right.. The look and feel of the bases and ships is so close to Space Engineers, it hurts. If you've played Space Engineers before you will know what I'm talking about. I wouldn't go so far as to call this game a clone, however. Space Engineers seems to focus on the physics of being in space and feels like a sandbox game at heart. Empyrion was developed with survival as it's focus. Though the game may look and feel like Space Engineers at times, the gameplay as a whole is different. I would describe this game as 'Space Engineers with a purpose' but, some of the physics lack polish and make me wish I was just playing Space Engineers.

You can't transition from space to planet unless everyone is in the same vehicle. Typing that sentence made me sad, and as I read it through cupped hands: I know I have found a game-breaking flaw. They have to address this one, and I am confident they will in time. While playing, the main goal for Meowmix and I was to get our escape pod functional and get off-planet. It took us a while, but eventually we succeeded and decided to take our modified escape pod exploring. We made planetfall at a nearby planet and found that we were incredibly underprepared. I don't want to spoil too much, but we ended up getting shot down and found ourselves marooned on this new ice-planet with no food. The cockpit of our ship had been destroyed and we had no way to create a replacement because I ♥♥♥♥ed up and dismantled the constructor when I built the car. We did some scouting, got into some trouble, and won some battles. Without a constructor, we really couldn't do anything on that planet. We were essentially, ♥♥♥♥ed. So, we packed our inventories into storage and let the hunger finish us off. It was a huge setback, but we were able to spawn at the base we built on the first planet. Our new mission was to build a new, beefier ship and go back to ice planet to repair and recover our crashed space pod. Hours later we had mined and scavenged enough parts together to make a new ship. We shot back over to ice planet, found our crash site, recovered our items, and bolted a new cockpit onto the old ship. I hopped in, did a quick flight test, and we headed for space only to hit an invisible wall and a notification that we both had to be in the same vehicle to transition off planet. Seriously ...the ♥♥♥♥?

The game lacks content. I know, it's Alpha or early access or whatever.. Here is a fact though: it still costs money to buy it. If it costs money, I expect something playable and with content. I was happy to find the game in a very playable state, and to be fair it does have a decent amount of content. Once you get into space, there isn't much more to do. You can explore the handful of other planets, or try to mine them for the special minerals needed to create a capital ship, but there is no point at this stage. There is potential to grow the content further, but I would say there are about 12-16 hours of gameplay right now and after that you are just playing a mediocre version of Space Engineers.

The crafting takes too long. Space Engineers had a more polished system for this, and this was one of the times I wish I was playing Space Engineers instead. You can queue up a bunch of stuff to be made, then go off and do other stuff but sometimes you need to sit there and micromanage it. The worst part was that you needed to build all the small components needed to make a part, then build the part. You could run two large constructors, but they can only craft using the resources stored inside the machine, so it doesn't really work well. Again, Space Engineers figured all this out and gives you a way more robust crafting system, which I think Empyrion should adopt. Two players cannot access the same machine / container either. This was a generally annoying experience, because I want to make some bullets or mining tool ammo to go do my thing, but Meowmix is in the middle of fabricating complicated parts to create a spaceship. I have to wait for his parts to finish, then make him wait while I craft my ♥♥♥♥ so I can go mining because I used up the last of the magnesium on him making bullets. Think you like your room-mate? Try getting stranded on a hostile alien plannet with him.


Advice:
Rebind your 'Z' key to 'Number pad Minus'. One of the first things Meowmix and I did was go mining and he accidentally pressed 'Z', dropping his tool through the ground. If you don't have a mining tool, or the resources needed to create one it is game over. Literally. You need to be able to mine, unless you like twiddling your thumbs waiting for the lights to go off because you ran out of power and can't produce more without promethium.

Three is one and one is none. Keep spare tools, guns, and ammo handy. Trust me on this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Usually one should be wary of Early Access games, but this one... oh this one deserves your hard earned cash. You can just look at the developers updates/comments and see that they are pushing so hard to get this game to be something great.

Empyrion is one hell of a sandbox and space exploration game. If you want to do anything, you must cronstruct, construct, construct your way to glorious material heaven where you can sustain a capital vessel. The mining is intituitive, much better to me than the block based games like Minecraft.

Empyrion's constructions serve purpose. Your base, under threat of attack on different worlds, needs to be defended at all times. You are extremely vulnerable on different planets, and the game starts to get hard when you start to travel within the star system using a capital vessel. These behemoth vehicles take up massive space weighin in at over 1.5 Kilotons. For those of you who don't do math, that's 1500 tons. Let me put this in perspective... one of the heaviest aircrafts that man has built, according to Wikipedia, is a whopping jet that takes off with 640 tons. Capital Vessels and their glory weigh in with 2x as much.

Not satisfied with building massive constructions? Take the fight to your enemy and decimate foes using hover vehicles and small vehicles. Blast your way through the alien constructions, loot their glorious materials, safely return to your vessel, and clap and cheer with your friends at a job well done. Death awaited you at every corner of that base, but you triumphantly destroyed its outer defenses, blasted each of its automated turrets, killed the alien Krogohms, and stole their valuable resources.

I have clocked 100 hours, and will continue to try each and every single one of the updates that the developers put out. Empyrion is that addictive, shows extreme promise, and is worth it.

Let me share a story with you as well: My friend and I spent 19 hours building a capital vessel (yes 19 hours to get it to be how we liked it). Proud of our work, we named her Queen Bee, cristend the vessel and flew her off to space. There we kicked the hyperdrive into gear flew to another planet, Aestus (a lava planet filled with terrible nightmarish creatures), and hell broke loose. We dropped the Hover Vessel to the planet, had its auto turrets buzzing away, and we could not defend against the enemy onslaught. Queen Bee was almost destroyed entirely. We lost the Fuel Tanks, the core, and most of its canons.

11/10 would be destroyed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Survival games rarely grip me nowadays, but Empyrion brings a lot of cool stuff to the table.
Here's an in-depth gameplay & Review video showing off a lot of features that I'm talking about:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhZrU80vKXo
The crafting system is so detailed, requiring you build dozens of pieces in order to make the next piece, for the next piece etc.
Small details make the game really fun. Like putting an oxygen generator inside water instead of on land to generate more oxygen since H2O contains O2. Or needing to power your escape pod with fuel before you can use its crafting tool.

The mining system is very satisfying. Minerals are patches in the ground. You can flatten mountains with your drill, and see pieces of material roll down the hill and wait to be collected. It feels very real.

Currently you can only play survival mode on one planet, although the devs have said they plan to make an antirely randomly generated galaxy with which you can travel from massive planets to another.
Right now in creative mode, you have 3 planets to choose from, and CAN fly in between them through space. Entering the atmosphere and then landing on a new planet is almost seemless and feels badass.

A great game overall, looks very promising.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first picked up Empyrion : Galactic Survival I have to admit that I wasn’t impressed.  I had been playing another very similar title for quite some time and found Empyrion to be fairly inferior when it came to the game experience as a whole.  Recently returning to Empyrion I found many changes.  Let’s just say, my first day returning to this game I put 12 hours into it.

Empyrion : Galactic Survival is one of those games that you’ll either love or hate.  It’s a game based heavily on survival where you absolutely can’t sit idle.  You can’t just put up a few walls, toss on a roof, and consider yourself safe.  If you don’t keep up with your tasks (like gathering food/oxygen) you’ll quickly find yourself dying.  In addition, resources are fairly limited so you have to continuously push yourself to explore further and further away from your comfort zone (aka. Your base).

Crafting in Empyrion is a fairly simple task, with most machines requiring you to first craft components for those machines.  Even some components require components.  While some may find this a tedious task to perform, I rather enjoied it as it gave me something to constantly be doing.   You can’t just “click” and have yourself a cockpit (for example), you actually have to build the parts for it before it can be assembled.  I enjoyed this in the other title I mentioned earlier, and I like that Empyrion has adopted this crafting style.  There is a bit of a balance problem in crafting, however, and I hope that the developers solve it in the future.  While crafting items doesn't really have this problem, crafting food seems to be a little problematic.  Take a sandwitch"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With 65 hours of play time in this game I can honestly say the devs have done a brilliant job!!! And this for a pre-alpha. Anyone who says this is a Space Engineers knockoff or rip should get their heads checked. Now don't get me wrong. I love Space Engineers, but this brings something new to the table. There are so many unique features in this game that seperates them completely. The way mining is done, generating oxygen and hydrogen, the different enemy bases (some with defences I realised after getting my ♥♥♥ kicked exploring), planting plants to use in recipes for food, and more. If I have to go into detail I'll type all day.

Building my first base and hover craft was exciting. Especially taking the hover craft for a spin. The hunting for food and mining is also much fun, not to mention taking out drones with your base turrets.

After a while though it got pretty boring as I fell into a repetive pattern, so I decided to build a small vessal to see what else there is to offer, and oh man was I surprised by the different drone bases I found. Factories, fuel stations, and so on.

I decided to take my ship into outerspace, knowing that I'd need supplies, so I made sure I had enough resources like, food, oxygen, power, building material for repairs and for my first capital ship, and I went off.

Now first let me tell you, I'm not an average gamer who just plays to beat the game. I appreciate every detail put into a game from the mechanics to the gameplay, to the graphics. Due to this I spend much more time to achieve what other gamers do. Well I'm overwhelmingly impressed with what I've seen so far.

Before starting the capital ship I realised that I had to get away far enough from the planet to avoid gravity pull.
The view is amazing from space. There are currently only about 5 or 6 planets with an asteroid belt, but I'm sure it will expand in future. After building the capital ship I went to explore one of these planets and it was an entire different atmosphere, and as mentioned earlier, completely diffirent alien life.

Raided a base on that planet and found that you not only have to watch out for ships and turrets, there are infantry to take care of as well before you can start looting.

With everything I've experienced so far in this game I am so looking forward to future updates and I don't regret buying this game for one second.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Get ready to be immersed. This is less of a game and more of a tool for unlocking your imagination. A lot of others have already made great comments about the game so will just bullet out the bassics, as of 3.6. Simply put, it's one of a very few early access games I've felt is worth a purchase.

The great:
- Decent graphics for early release
- Do whatever you want, total sandox feeling
- World feels BIG
- No handholding - no in-game tutorial - learn and adapt or die
- Reasonably stable, easy to set up co-op gameplay
- Lots of stuff to collect, craft and test
- Good blend between walking simulator and combat when appropriate
- Slow pace, but always feel suspence
- Complicated where it needs to be, simple where it needs to be
- No quests or generic story, do what YOU want, when YOU want
- Easy to pick back up after a few days of absence
- Loads quickly, no time wasted waiting to play
- Game will punish you brutally for mistakes, poor planning can lead to hours lost

This game is a mature entity in a world oversaturated by family-friendly, hand-holding casual games. This game will not tell you a story, but inspire you to create your own.

This game is expectedly raw, in early stages, but if you like to get totally immersed in a world where you don't know what's around the corner, this game is definitely worth picking up. I am excited to see the direction this game will take in further development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Highly recommended! Minecraft meets a simple form of Space Engineers plus a dose of Interstellar Marines!

Beautiful Graphics (Unity Engine), a satisfying weapon and gear arsenal (Snipers, Shotguns, Pistols, Rifles, Automatic Turrets, Player Turrets - ♥♥♥♥, even Artillery) and the possibility to do and build whatever you want! (Hover-Vehicles, Small Fighters, Mining Fregates, Capital Ships, Surface-Bases and Space Stations - with big ♥♥♥ rocket launchers!)

Multiplayer is online and fully functioning.

Every Planet feels really different and the Flora and Fauna is beautiful or terrifying - in most cases both!

Procedurally generated Planets! (A whole Universe to conquer!)

I really love what they have done with the lights. There is so much Tension and Immersion because of how light and shadow is displayed.

A Must-Have for Fans of Subnautica or Minecraft!

Still not convinced? Watch this: (...the Big ♥♥♥ Robots and the solar panels are not yet inside the game! but the rest is! and the graphics are really far better now!)  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iabkfM5VZDk

Now buy the game and meet me online! We got a Universe to conquer!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Video First Impressions- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=asFCAUGbTcU

Keep in mind this title is Early Access! That being said its very impressive what the small dev team has accomplished.
In a short time the devs have designed a game that allows players to start on a planet with a crashed escape pod figure out how to survive. Planets have live, creatures and planetlife. To survive you have to build a base, and so on. Building works much like Space Engineers or minecraft. placing blocks that you have to create using a crafting station.

What seperates this title from rest are the currently working features.

Multiplayer that seems to work very smoothly in my testing using Hamachi.
Going from space to the planets Surface.
Buiulding Bases, above and underground, working survival mechanics like growing food. Generating Oxygen, Day / Night Cycle with a spherical globe. Terrain is formable and destructible. You can build underground.


Features As of this review...

Space flight & Atmospheric Flight, Landing on Planets
Basic Creature AI. Passionate Devs
Base building
Fighter / Large Ship building
Creatures with Basic AI - Some Hostile
Full survival system, Food, Oxygen, Stamina,
Crafting A veriety of Weapons.

The Ugly bits..

Its early access so don't expect a finished game. Things like weapons don't have reload animations, Ship flight model seems kinda wonky and not very smooth at this point, all players look the same.

Basicly its Early access and I'm looking forward to watching this game grow into something awesome. Much like Space Engineers each update will bring new Surprises. If your the kind of person who loves space sandbox games and enjoy watching a game like this build up over time. Then pick it up and help support its development.

If your looking for a finished game just wait till its out.

This is NOT a disappointing game.
This is also not your average EA game either.  The developers of this game have been working part-time on this game for years.  This alpha is the result of a love and passion to create this game.

Look through my EA games and look at my reviews.  I'm a very critical person over games because I use a very strict methodology of measuring and sizing up a developer on thier abilities to produce a completed and fun game.  So, my reviews are generally based on the games potential to release a badass game rather than is it currently fun?" type review.

The answer to that is of course
date:
hell yes.

But to the actual review.
1) Are the developers responding to the community: YES
2) Are the developers providing meaningful updates: YES
3) Are there serious flaws that would require a near-rewrite: NO
4) Are the developers timely in their updates: YES
5) Do the developers currently keep promises: YES

According to my metrics this game has a TON of potential to not just be a badass game but Game of the Year worthy if the developers stay on track.

But what can you do so far?
You can currently struggle to survive and use tools

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion - Galactic SurvivalDeveloper: Eleon Game Studios
Publisher: Eleon Game Studios

Note: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an informative review. No other compensation was given.

Introduction
==========
Over the past few years we have seen our fair share of survival games coming to Steam: Terraria, Starbound, TUG, Dig or Die, ARK: Survival Evolved, Savage Lands, and so on. They all share the same, base concept, but what sets each of them apart from the rest are either the mechanics, the setting, or the gameply. For Empyrion, it's all of the above! It's really a mix of the best of everything we've seen thus far, except dinosaurs. That's Ark's jurisdiction.

Gameplay
==========
Empyrion is a voxel-based survivial multiplayer game played in first person, though you can toggle a over-the-shoulder (sort of) third person view. Though honestly first person is best. Empyrion boasts a variety of environments in it's current pre-Alpha Early Access state, although they are a bit limited at this stage. You have a desert planet, a lava planet, etc. Each planet has different features, flora, and fauna.

The game starts with you exiting an escape pod that's crashed on an alien planet. Emptying your pod's storage units gives you enough to get started making your own way on this new world. Along the way, you will learn how to manage your oxygen levels, hunger, and stamina. Learning how to craft what you need to refill your hunger and oxygen is the most crucial thing to learn at first. Empyrion has somewhat of a learning curve, as most survival games do, but once you get a grasp on the basics everything flows very well.

Eventually you are able to craft a new ship, leave the planet, and travel to others--provided you have built up a stock of fuel. Travelling to other hostile worlds requires an assortment of weapons as well, and Empyrion has a nice handful of guns you can wield. A pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper rifle, minigun, and rocket launcher are just a few you can find or craft. Most survival games use tools such as pickaxes. Empyrion features a 'drill' that uses laser technology that's quite fun to handle.

Graphics
==========
This game looks really sharp. The visuals (especially for vehicles) give off a Space Engineers vibe, and that game looked great. Empyrion looks pretty similar quality-wise. The creatures look great, even if their designs are a tad uninspired. Some of them are pretty creepy looking though, especially the ones on the lava planet. The guns looks absolutely stunning though, as do the ships, tools, and devices. Water effects are pretty solid looking too. Overall this game looks pretty great for what it is.

Sound and Music
==========
Currently Empyrion is lacking in this department. There is only really music on the title screen, but that track is great. It really sets the tone of the game...inspiring a sense of awe and wonder. There are sound effects are for everything I've found, so far at least. I expect more to be added during th egame's development while in Early Access. Music really helps to set the mood for many aspects of a game, and can be the most memorable thing gamers recall about a game. I'm such a gamer, and music really stands out to me if it's good.

Performance
==========
My framerate ranged from 30 to 49 during my time playing, according to Shadowplay's FPS counter. I didn't experience any crashes, missing textures, or anything of that nature. I did experience a slight bug wher ea monster started pursuing me and just stood there, even while filling it with bullet holes. Apparently this glitch was fixed in a patch earlier today, showing that the developers are at least paying attention to their game and player feedback/bug reports. This is always a big plus for Early Access titles.

Using the mouse/keyboard is the the way to go. I didn't bother testing my controller as the default controls suit me better for this type of game. The same goes for most first person shooters. It's just easier to aim using the mouse/keyboard.

Final Thoughts
==========
Even though it's Early Acces, Empyrion shows a lot of promise. This is definitely a title to keep your eye on. Buy it if you want to support hard-working developers complete their game and watch the game evolve as more features and content are added!

Gameplay Demo
==========
https://youtu.be/7zPbyzADK7s

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion - Galactic Survival has been one of the most fun survival games I have played in a long time. Part Sci-fi, all Survival, Empyrion starts you off on one of Two planets, a lush and plentiful world with abundant resources, or a hostile and sparse desert planet where survival is even more of a struggle. Choose your planet, depending on how difficult a challenge you want. You need to hunt for meat, eat food, drink water, and manage your oxygen. While trying to live off the land you also will have to fend off creatures, alien soldiers, drones and more. Mine for ore and materials, craft and build ships and bases, there is a wealth of things to do in Empyrion.

Hover Ships allow for quick and easy travel across planet surfaces, whereas small ships allow you to leave the planets orbit and fly to nearby asteroids and moons. Capital Ships, the biggest in the game, can be built which will take you to other solar systems. There you can discover new types of planets, new creatures and more. You are limited in the types of materials you can build with, but this may be an issue fixed over time as the game continues to develop.

The game is still in early access, so there are some things which are subject to possibly change. The game doesn't have quests or objectives and is currently an open-world sandbox; However, for those who enjoy a challenge, the AI tends to be very aggressive, but predictable and can present a challenge to players new to the survival genre. I would like to see more objects you can build, more creatures, and more content overall, but as I said this game is still in Early Alpha, so we can expect to see some changes over time. Empyrion has quickly become one of my go-to Survival Games and I look forward to seeing how it continues to develop.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game right now is a pretty good foundation for a early access. However, it still has a lot of work before its worth the price. So far it is just too shallow. Multiplayer isn't yet fully functional. The combat is rather dull and repetitive. The building is pretty shallow as well with not many 'functional' or 'useful' blocks. The damage model is block by block, which results in combat simply being about tunneling to a critical component which isn't very deep and it is asthetically unpleasing when you have parts of ships just free floating still magically connected. The damage model probably should have been different. The crafting is rather tedious with raw mats to sub components to components and many of the features or mechanics of the game are also very tedious, such as the oxygen and power cell systems. Game will likely be another lobby based 'survival game' which means the servers will be run by butthurt kids that kick/ban anyone better than them. The game likely will not be a MMO by any means as much of the current testing community is hostile towards anything but single player.

Also careful, the fanbois apparently down vote all dissenting views.
