reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely recommended!


Bad > 1-10 < Good


These are not in any particular order of importance:

1. Fun factor:  8 (lots to explore and discover.  Tense yet exciting gameplay almost throughout the entire experience)

2.Creative factor: 10 (such great potential in designs, from full-fledged star ships to hidden underground bases and the ability to share them with the community)

3. Challenge factor: 6 (this is probably higher if the wiki is unavailable to assist your start.  Magnesium resource is a single point of failure however, meaning if you don't have much or run out, you run out of ammo)

4. Graphics factor: 8 (will be higher upon release I'm sure but still looks pretty amazing as is)

5. Music factor:  10!  (Two steps from hell vibe and I just love it!  I hold a games music as one of the most important aspects of experiencing a game.)

6. Cinematics factor: n/a (being a sandbox there are no cinematic events... yet at least)

7. Story factor n/a (as of early access, with current lore though it's a 6 with potential for more)

8. Content factor: 8 (lots of blocks and components with more being added steadily)

9. Control factor: 7 (I personally don't like wavy cameras which only happens in third person view anyways, otherwise controls are intuitive)

10.  Gameplay factor: 10 (it's already a pretty good survival game, coupled with creativity and terraforming capabilities the game play is through the roof for me!  Also there is multiplayer which I have yet to experience)

Issues:
1. Mechanically speaking there are none, the game runs great though I have a better than middling machine.  For an early access game there is quite a bit of polish it seems.

2. Capital vessels still fly a bit clunky sometimes, but mostly show no issues outside your own faults in designing the vessel.



My most intense experience came while raiding an alien power plant.  After delving down a few levels I came to a stairwell that led to an open floor below.  I took out a couple guards who were visible from the top of the stairs.  As I descended the screen turned red and gunshots were everywhere.  I blasted two more aliens with my chain gun then B lined to a door well to hide in and made it there with 1 hp left.  Much to their chagrin I was prepared.  I was able to heal up and clear the rest of the room.  I went on to salvage the rest of the base.

Empyrion strikes a near perfect balance between surviving and thriving.  There is always something to do whether that's mining more resources, creating and expanding your base, gathering and creating your necessities, or striking out to explore your world, then your solar system, and eventually on to other systems.  None of this feels like work, it's almost all play!

I give Empyrion in its current state a 7.5/10 and it gets better with each patch!  The dev team is great at communicating and the community is extremely helpful as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR - An early access title that initially had loads of potential but now seems to be falling into a 'commercial success' trap. The originally exciting feeling of being a lone survivor on an alien planet with nothing but your wits and skill has been replaced with to many mainstream, easy path, options that ultimately lessen the whole experience.

Like many gamers I really enjoy the surival/sandbox genre. The restrictions of linear, on rails, gaming seems to be rapidly falling behind us and a new era of 'do whatever you want' gaming is the current trend. However, this type of gaming is very time consuming for developers and as a consequence is probably not very financially sustanable.

When i first started playing EGS it really seemed to encapsulate the true feeling of survival sandbox. I actually feel really sorry for players who wont get to experience 'vanilla' EGS. Waking up on an alien world with nothing but a broken escape pod, a few emergency supplies, and rapidly diminishing oxygen supply (the environment of the original start planet was not breathable), and hostile alien life forms everywhere, created a real sense of panic and urgency.

You had to make fast decisions and weigh up pros and cons of your actions; for example, you can see a crashed captial ship in the distance where there might be more supplies but to get there and back on limited oxygen and with hostile creatures around is a real gamble. Do you make a run for it, hoping to get there and back in time? Do you waste precious resources to build a land vehicle to take you there? Do you boycote the idea altogether and think of something else?

EGS gave you these choices and the means to accomplish them but it left the 'how' entirely up to you. It was just as likely that your choices would end up getting you killed, but that was okay as it leant to the feeling of tension.

There was a definite feeling of elation once you had developed a sustainable source of food and clean water.

And then there was space travel. Wow, that feeling when you make your first craft space worthy and break the bonds of gravity - awesome.

And then there is now, The survival sandbox has gone, replaced with a starting world so habitable and 'easy' that there is little point going anywhere else. Your new construction module doesn't even need power for pity's sake! And tech trees? Really?? I dont recall Robinson Crusoe having a tech tree (look him up kids), or Matt Damon in The Martian.

The sense of panic felt when you spawned on a planet without air is gone, as is any sense of need to progress at all.

Yes, I am aware that I can still choose to spawn on Omicron but what is the point? Once multiplayer comes in there will be no incentive to have a harder start than your friends.

Ultimately it is just a real shame. I don't know what caused the devs to head down this path as this is certainly not what I paid for. You are no longer buying a survival sandbox but a FPS with tech trees and some base building.

The priority for the devs was supposed to be procedularly generated planets. That is what the game needed. That would have made it epic, especially as No Man's Sky is rapidly approaching. Without this feature this game will get quickly left behind, even more so  now the core elements that made it fun are gone.

I loved this game and the potential it had and a few weeks ago would have recommended it whole heartedly. Now i dont, and I wont. I feel quite sad about that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely wonderful game.  Most fun I've had in survival multiplayer since minecraft.  Hosting a server doesnt even require skills, and runs stable.

I HATE complex crafting games, but somehow this one takes that complexity and makes it digestable...thats important I think for the long term viability of a game like this.

The planets are generous with resources but they are used quickly - for a team of 4 or 5 that is many mouths to feed, and just keeping fed is a real pain in the early game when you cant leave the planet or have a food device in your base.

Make a capital ship and suddenly fuel is a real issue.

But the best part of this game, and its the same quality that minecraft enjoyed back in the beta when monsters first came out and were bugged, is that you can find yourself in genuinely star trek like problems and have to find a way out of them...somehow.

just the other night a friend of mine steered our new ship to a new planet while me and another person tagged along, the idea being to get food because the desert planet is lacking and were all starving.  While there, one of us turned on the ship then got out by accident, which led to the three of us looking at the ship floating away from us and into space.  We would have been stranded, except that one of us decided to shoot and destroy the RCS of the ship to bring it back down.  The ship landed, and took hull damage and lost a side thruster.  With a fridge on the ship full of food, one of us had to use the map to help the pilot navigate back home on no RCS or side thrust. Took a while but we actually made it back to base on the other planet.  We've had more adventures like this since....this game needs to be played multi with friends for the best experience.

Recommend you start on the desert planet first - make it harder on yourself and the rewards for surviving are that much richer...that is the point of a survival game, isnt it?

Abandoned mine = nightmare fuel.
Parking underwater = broken vessel

I embark on my treacherous journey to find magnesium and run from any dangers. I finally find a nice untouched Magnesium deposit. 50m from a hostile space port and 200m from a hostile ComCenter.

10/10 would play again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely incredible!

Pre-Alpha and it already has enough functionality to be considered almost a complete game, and to think of the fact that so much more is coming gets me so excited I can barely hold it in.

Pros:

Wildlife makes me terrified, I get the feeling some nasty creature is about to come around the corner and bite my head off.

exploring planets is incredible, the darkness of a planet at night really makes people need lights. it's not so dark as to be pitch black, but dark enough that seeing where you're going without a decent light is difficult. the terrain is beautifully formed and able to deform with explosives, drills and the flatten filler tool (incredible thing there)

sunrise is an incredible thing to watch as well as sunset.

I find myself sometimes just staring out onto the horizon as I watch the other planets past the atmosphere

Building ships and bases is possibly my favorite part with the systems they have in place. back in space engineers, I usually built in creative. here, I'm building small ships that I never thought I'd build decently! thank you for giving me the ability to work decently with the necessary tools to build survival capable small fighters! now to work on capital ships and space stations!

Energy is a very interesting system of mining promethium (very creative, I like this!) as well as hydrogen.

the need for food, energy, and oxygen is present and especially functional.

Food perishing times make the game realistic on a whole new level.

spoiled food hurts you if you consume it, but helps you if you apply it to making planters.

fairly smart AI and interesting enemies to go toe to toe with.

Drones that periotically come to attack you in addition to troop transports dropping off infantry to your location.

the sense of terror when hiding from drones and seeing their spotlight in a green tinge pass over your cover! I had chills!

Ships having burning re-entry! YEEEEEEEE!!! :D

and so much more! play the game to see the rest of the pros!

Cons:

blocked off poles of the planets, soon to be replaced.

Capital ships causing your death and their destruction upon planetary entry

missing animations (but hey, pre-alpha so far)

entering void space and desync mishaps (however entertaining)

in my personal opinion, a lack of a certain few weapons for infantry and ships alike, I.E. Melee weapons and general melee ability for infantry, and a wider variety of weapons available for large ships and small. some of those guns on bases would actually work well on large ships.

no large doors to cover multiple block sizes, for example, hangar doors.

currently no way to bring hover vehicles into the atmosphere and store away on larger ships.

water doesn't fill in areas if drilling extends the water's fill area

all of these I believe will be resolved in later versions, and so, I'll continue to enjoy this game for what it is.


If you love sandbox games and even more so, love watching something grow, get this game, it is well worth the money

Keep up the great work guys!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am pleasantly surprised by this game. It's not news that Steam is flooded with survival and builder games, but it's definitely newsworthy when one of them has real polish and content on launch. It's been described as Space Engineers but with more of an action focus instead of intricate build rules. However, the build trees are deep and the supply chain is intricate. It feels like a living universe and that's the biggest compliment I can give an early access title. Imagine if Planet Explorers and Space Engineers had a baby...and it was a genius.

If you buy only one exploration/building game this year, make it this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An amazing amount of gameplay and things to do- Allows you to be very creative and is a ton of fun.

Be warned- Its rough learning how the game works and there are some systems that seem complex at first (as you start learning it all makes sense and  becomes second nature) so time and experimentation will be required unless you have someone teaching you the ropes.

Multiplayer is also a blast and has an amazing amount of potential- Nice to have PVE and PVP areas so theres some safety but still risk involved to get materials from certasin planets (it seems the server admin can set many types of rulesets so everything from PVP to total PVE is represented on the servers-) this could be one of the most fun multiplayer games ever if this pre alpha is any indication.

Even spending hours in 'creative mode' building bases and ships is time well spent because you can make blueprints of your creations and spawn them into any game once you reach a pre requisit level and have all the materials...THIS is something all building/survival games should have since it makes you want to take the time to create truley unique things since you wont lose all that work when you switch servers.

Im loving it. Would totally recommend this to anyone .

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is AMAZING! Even in pre-alpha it has absorbed over 30 hours of my time without even a second thought. Obviously there are a lot of issues and the developers have a lot of work to do but the game is stable (on my machine at least) and loads of fun, so what more can you ask of a pre-alpha?

Pros:
- Great ideas implemented already regarding items, resources and constructables
- Build system is largely done and works very nicely
- Awesome concept, wanted a galactic survival game for ages
- Exciting possibilities for adventuring with POIs to explore and loot
- Cool weaponry like pulse rifles
- Already has a great atmosphere/ambience to it

Cons:
- Planets are a bit wee and you currently can't visit the poles plus there is a green barrier where the terrain has been wrapped about the planetary sphere and joined. Bit freaky and weird that!
- Memory requirements are vast; I have 8GB which overflows after a few hours play. Exiting and restarting the game dumps the memory for further play...
- Ship weapons are a bit difficult to use currently, no heat seekers yet...
- I fell though the ground into null space! Haven't done this since the days of the first Quake! Only the once in 30 odd hours though...
- Hover vessels can flip over when bumping into objects like plants = annoying and irreversible
- Need more/better animals and weather to bring worlds to life. Marine life?
- Not fully procedural yet and it is not 'galactic' yet either; more like a single solar system where the planets sit rotating on their axes and not orbiting their parent star at all. As an astrophysicist this is a little strange to me!

Overall the game at this stage deserves a 6/10 for entertainment and interest value, though falls down precisely because it is pre-alpha and there is much to do. With the right development, and it looks like the team are on the case with this, I can see this getting towards 9/10 quite easily over the coming year or so. If you enjoy creative games like minecraft then you'll get a lot out of this already. That being said you may wish to wait a little longer for its alpha release if the bugs and issues will frustrate. I intend to put it down for a few months soon so as not to overplay it in its early phase. Need to play it again now though!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Start with just a crashed ship and build yourself an epic base with epic guns and build yourself an epic ground cruiser to collect some stuff and build yourself an epic ship to go to other planets to get epic ores and build yourself an epic capital ship.  Okay, so that may be an overuse of the word epic, but you get the point.

This game is in Early Access and has it's rough edges and bugs, but so far, since the closed pre-alpha has started they have squashed numerous bugs and proven that they are willing to listen to the community.  The game so far is already fun, but if they implement even half the features they have planned for the future this game will definitely be amazing.

Don't look to this game for super complicated systems with 20 dozen moving parts, look to this game for it's namesake, intergalactic survival (or at least interplanetary survival for now).  Oh, and never go anywhere without a backup plan.  At this stage of the game it's much too easy to accidentally wreck your ship on an alien planet and have no way to get back up and going again.  My recommendation, carry a base starter kit with a constructor, generator, and fuel tank.  That way if you get wrecked then you at least have SOMETHING to start with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Being Early Access can be a bit of a let down nowadays and with reviews and traliers sometimes very misleading, I was pleasantly surprised how good this is thus far.

Short video detailing all the basic stuff you can do so far after a day's play.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SVpHszAwAII


Combining Space Engineers, fps shooting and some light survival mechanics. I did actually find this a bit more enjoyable than Space Engineers. The crafting is pretty in-depth but not too over your head.

Pro's
In-depth crafting system
Quite an array of weaponry
split second transition between planets
Takes some of the best stuff from Space Engineers
Great starting price for early access
Addicting gameplay

Cons
Save game bugs, for example your large constructor will dissapear after loading a save and taking all your stuff with it, but this is early access afterall.
FPS is kind of bland atm
Planets not fully explorable-Coming during early access
Limited star system too explore-Once again Early access so it is coming
True multi-player coming down the line.

I'd imagine you'll get 40+hours of enjoyble content before you'll start to run out of things to do so it's quite a deal at this point with more content incoming.

I believe this will be a game that doesn't falter in Early Access and will make the distance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:

Seemless World Transition.

Night & Day cycles that feel realistic. (The sun doesn't go down on the world, It goe's AROUND the world, Meaning you can travel to the dark side of the world or the day light side as time changes in a dynamic way)

Worlds that are round and seemless ( You can circle the world)

Seemless transition into space and from space to planet.

Good leveling progression thoughout the game.

A.I Monsters/Aliens/Drones/Ect feel really nice to fight and offer a challenge.

You can build a space station,a capital ship,a fighter and more.

You can harvest on: Planets,Moons,Astroids.

You can create a Faction and Fight other Factions on the server.  (This could mean big space battles on a good server)

Creative and Survival Servers, Creative is what you think it is and Survival is mostly based on Food & Air. )

Mining isn't voxel based it's terraforming in a nice way and harvesting feels really fun. (Just don't get stuck in a hole) LOL!

Did I mention JET PACKS? Because it's got Jet Packs and Yes they are FUN!

Exploration of Space is excellent ( You can warp to other planets, fly around them,land on them and kill everything living, Plus build a base with the stuff you raided from the aliens who now coware at your superior might )

You and friends can ride in the same ship together.

There is more but time for cons.


Cons:


The graphics look dated.

No weather.

Water is kind of bugged in the sense you can dig under it and it won't fill in the hole. (This is still earley alpha)

Warps seem kind of lack luster.

No economy system.

No explanation on how to play the game which leaves new player confused.

Minigun for the ships SUCK! 800 Rounds don't kill anything ever, No effect at all. We believe it's bugged and no longer use it as after 1600+ Rounds did nothing to an animal but a 10 round pistol can did wonders.

Server config is limited and admin support is kind of trash.

Needs more.


Final Thoughts,


If your into sci-fi games and are a fan of the survival games this game will make you very happy as I've been a ton of hours in it since I got the game. We enjoy it a ton and it's very fun if you got a ton of time to waste chilling in space.

7.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do I recommend this game? Yes. Under the warning that this game is far from finished and, certainly for the current price, I really expect the game to be more complete and rebalanced in the future.

Is it currently enjoyable playing? A bit I guess. Some things like crafting are tedious, but there's plenty content if you take the time to actually explore and play the game.

What I dislike in the current state (16-8-2015):
The game is very unfinished and out of balance. Things like crafting are tedious and boring, resources are scarce, enemies are powerful (especially drones and turrets), AI is limited (own turrets usually don't work), and so forth. This really is a pre-alpha and you should treat it as such. The current price seems a little high for a pre-alpha, although I guess there's plenty content already. Furthermore:
-Everything requires tremendous amounts of resources which are only sparsely available and have to be hand-drilled.
-The construction system is tedious and mediocre, requiring you to craft intermediate items from intermediate items before you can create usable products and blocks.
-(Enemy) weapons are overpowered. Drones and turrets can spam rockets with 1 per 2-3 seconds, from a 500-1000M distance, and it takes exactly 3 direct shots for a heavily armored ship to be shot to hell. Enemies (towers for example) often have multiple of these turrets.
-Physics are clumsy. Spaceships don't float, they glide sorta like airplanes, regardless of thruster setup and complete lack of wings. possible bug with broken inertial dampener system, only using the bottom thruster to fight against gravity?
-Characters are slow, especially with the jet pack, and it's easy to get disoriented as they can flip over when flying into objects or when turning on/off the jetpack.
-lots of little glitches and bugs, that can range from randomly causing the game to crash to just displaying errors, and just a very incomplete feel to the game.
-In my taste the planet implementation is weird. when you fly from space to a planet, you essentially transfer into a different map. All maps are flat, so the worlds may seem flat, but when you fly forward for a while you hit a green zone which teleports you to the other side of the map. Additionally the poles of planets are unreachable for the same reason, the square map would cause cluster♥♥♥♥ happening there. They say they're going to make the poles reachable, but with the current implementation I wonder how they're going to accomplish that.


What I do like about the game:
It's an interesting concept, a Survival oriented space sandbox, where you can choose the sky after you're done with one planet. This basically means you have your typical survival game where you must collect food and resources in a map with other players and creatures, but you can expand your horizons by choosing space, flying to another planet, or simply build a base in space. That alone makes it more interesting in concept than something like most zombie survival games out there right now, since you'll have infinitely more environments to play with than other games.
Furthermore:
-Voxel all the things, you can mine and terraform planets and asteroids, you can build your own ships, and everything is destructible.
-Plenty things to do for now. There's certainly more than a few hours of gameplay already in there, some things may be a bit tedious to do, but you can create a base on and explore every planet, and try to take all the towers and stations and bases that are setup across the different worlds and in space with your own creations, which will take you quite a while.
-Devs seem committed, even though I haven't had the game very long, there's been a few updates, and each update they've addressed issues and expanded the game.
-Promises seem lofty, this can be a gem of a game if the developers keep working on this.


Personally I'm going to wait a while and hope for content updates and improvements. When it has improved, I will continue playing. A little the same as with Space engineers, which some others here may have played, although space engineers has a much more advanced engine and physics, and the upcoming worlds should be a lot larger and better implemented than this game. Grr, why is everything awesome unfinished :P stupid devs! fix everything and make it perfect pls! I'm bored and require my antiboredom fix! zamg!
voteText: 25 of 31 people (81%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After having played over 70 hours in the past 2 weeks I can only say this game is a very exciting feature rich space survival game.
Packed with a massive amount of working features, this is an example of the quality games should thrive for coming to EA.
Read about the game features further below after the background story.

Background Story
By the end of the 24th century, world population had increased to over 18 billion exhausting most of the resources of the planet. Runaway climate change has caused extreme weather like hurricanes of unimaginable ferocity that brought widespread devastation. Global warming has reduced most of the polar ice and has induced a rise in sea levels by more than 30 meters submerging low-lying areas of the planet and flooding coastal cities.

The cascade of resulting changes had lead to political instability, riots and looting, war over resources, hundreds of millions of refugees, severe droughts, famines, mass extinctions of many species, and ecosystem collapse. According to the “United Council of Humanity” (UCH), the human race has less than 100 years before a complete breakdown of industrial civilization.

In the year 2402, a team of researchers discovered the wreck of a starship in the Antarctic, hidden up to this time under a thick cover of ice. Apparently, the ship belonged to a technologically highly advanced alien race and was powered by an unknown form of energy. Also a star map containing ancient symbols was recovered. Soon scientists realized that the symbols on the star map were similar to those used in ancient cosmologies to describe “Empyrion” – the land of plenty.

It took two decades until scientists began to understand the functioning of the alien energy cells and decrypt the map.

Decryption, however, was only partially successful and the resulting coordinates remained ambiguous. The star map seemed to point to a location far away in the Andromeda Galaxy about 2.5 million light-years away.

Given the increasingly desperate situation on Earth, the UCH decided to focus the remaining resources on Earth on a unified effort to build a fleet of starships with the aim of establishing contact with the mysterious aliens and finding Empyrion.

The hope of saving the Earth from apocalypse guided the endeavor, named “Operation Phoenix.” All ships were equipped with an alien energy cell to power their experimental hyperdrives – a technology never used before. The preparation and construction of the fleet took more than 50 years. Participants were selected at young age, contingent on showing superior genetic, cognitive and physical attributes. They received extensive combat training and broad engineering skills.

Finally, in 2473, the fleet of starships is ready and you are the first commander of the frigate “MS Titan.” When the fleet disembarks on its journey to find Empyrion, mankind has united to attend the event. After you activate the hyperdrive, however, something goes wrong and an unknown force takes control of your ship…

Subsequent to reappearance from hyperdrive, your ship is disabled and drifts in the orbit of an unknown planet somewhere in the Andromeda Galaxy far away from the destination that was indicated by the map. You have lost contact with all other ships of Operation Phoenix. Gravity pulls your disabled ship towards the surface where it crashes.

The impact completely destroys the ship and kills the crew. You are the only survivor. Find a way to leave this hostile planet and uncover the mysteries of Empyrion. Save the Earth before it is too late!

The Game
This is where we start, lost in the Andromeda Galaxy crash landed with an escape pod on Omicron, an alien planet. Your mission is to find Empyrion the new World.

Survive the harsh environment, fighting aliens and monsters. Build your base of operations, harness the planets resources, farm, hunt, mine. Mining has never been as much fun with each Planet allowing you to fully deform it mining out all those resources.

When you are ready build a Ground Vehicle to explore the planet, gather resources, invade and eliminate Alien Structures and loot the spoils for survival.

Build your own space ship and travel from Omicron into space, mining Asteroids, visiting different Planet with their own unique resource you need to harvest to survive. Fight alien spaceships and attack alien space stations.

Visit the dark side of the Omicron moon, who knows what skeletons of past events await you there.

Why stop there, build your own mothership and space station to dock your spaceship fleet on and take over space on your mission to find Empyrion.

The sky is not the limit, only your imagination is.

Want to know what the gameplay looks like, here you go:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hfWXLfR-pcI

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got the game on Holiday sale. Well worth the 10$.

I only played multiplayer. Your experience may vary. This in reference to 5.1 prealpha.

The game is very entertaining and engaging. There's a lot to keep you busy through level 20. Once you hit around Level 15-20 you get your space legs. The game becomes a colony game after that; visiting planets to acquire/collect its resources. There are four types of structures you can build: a base, a hover vehicle, a small space vessel, and a Capital Vessel (Space Base).

Central to the game is building. You're constantly building something. If you're not building something, you're collecting stuff to build something.

AI on mobs are trivial.
PvP leaves something to be desired.
The bugs. Being pre-alpha there are a number of them. I'm not going to list them all but I will share my experience: All told, across 3 or 4 servers, I've lost 3 capital vessels, 2 small vessels, and one base. Just poofed, vanished. Capital vessels are a huge time sink in regards to resource collecting, design, and build. It gets very frustrating having several hours of work wiped out. And then there's the issue of not being able to login to a server if you logged out on a bugged planet or orbit....

Without the current bugs I would highly recommend it. With it I would say maybe wait until the servers are more stable. If you can get over losing hours of your time to server issues/bugs, go for it. If not, wait until they fix server optimization.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

- Bought this game.

- Quickly tried it before going to work.

- Thought about it at work and how interesting it is.

- Came home and launched the game up.

- Went to bed without dinner (too immersed in game) and noticed my gf was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off.

- More concerned that work will pass fast tomorrow so I can learn more about this game.

It might be EA, complicated, lacks in game tutorials........but it's extremely fun. I just figured out how to make my ground vehicle and went of exploring the planet. I found a massive half wrecked ship and thought i'd go check what was inside. I Got into a gun fight with Terminator stye drones with fancy flash lights. The gun combat does feel very basic and is as simple as point and shoot. The enemy monsters/bots/creatures are decent enough to look at at this stage, but won't require much tactical planning. That's day one. This already feels well worth the money in it's current state.

I hope in time this will grow to the point of completion as it does feel very special as is, so I can only imagine this will be mind blowing on final release. This ran at a solid 60 fps. When I changed the refresh rate to 144hz, my fps would vary between 112 and 144 fps. For anyoone playing with 3 monitors, it scales quite well @ 5760 x 1080.

spec....

GTX 980 ti
i7 4790
16 Gigs ram
Windows 10

I fully recommend this to players that have a good attention span and are willing to learn how to do things in the game either through trial and error, watching the video guides, or reading the forums a little. Once you get going it is not as difficult as it seems. Quite fun learning by yourself too. If you get frustrated with micro managing or resource gathering, then this might not be for you. The same applies if you need the game to guide you as you go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion – Galactic Survival is an early access open world survival game set in space with tons of content, Steam workshop and a great soundtrack.

Empyrion starts with you selecting which world you'd like to play on out of two available: Akua and Omicron. They differ from each other aesthetically and environmentally (gravity, oxygen) but the main difference is difficulty; Omicron is not recommended for people starting out for the first time as the overall conditions of the planet are more challenging. Once you've chosen your world you can select your game mode from Creative and Survival both being relatively self-explanatory. In survival mode you must scavenge, craft, build and keep yourself alive whilst gradually building yourself a base, exploring the massive world and if you choose later on, making some kind of spacecraft. You can choose your seed, play with the predefined one or randomize it to add plenty of re-playability when it comes to exploration. Creative mode allows you to play without worrying about your health/food/oxygen and starts with your tech trees fully unlocked and all blocks and items available. You also have the choice when choosing your creative world to turn pre-built structures on or off; if you choose to have them on you'll spawn in the world inside a pre-built base with a spaceship already made for you outside. This is a fantastic way for you to see how a basic functioning base looks and also helps you to envision how you're going to build your own as choosing what goes where on your first few plays can be pretty difficult.

When you start survival mode you'll find yourself in an escape pod that is crash landing. You can guide your pod to a safe location, preferably somewhere near water or an ore deposit as those are crucial to your base building and general survival. Once you land you'll need to remove your starting gear from your now-destroyed pod and then it is up to you to survive alone. You'll find you have various stats of your own that you'll need to monitor whilst playing as they will decrease over time or with certain actions. These are your health, food, oxygen and stamina levels. Food is an easy one as you can find various food sources scattered all over the planet, either growing on the ground of from hostile mobs you may encounter. All food that you find or create has a perish time within which you'll need to consume it to stop it going bad. As you progress and level up you'll be able to unlock a fridge which will freeze perish times whilst food is stored inside it. Oxygen is required on some planets that do not have a breathable atmosphere and can also come in handy whilst you are underwater. While you have your helmet on you will consume oxygen which can be refilled at an O2 station but you can remove your helmet at any time to conserve your O2 levels. Though Akua has a breathable atmosphere you will still need oxygen tanks with you if you choose to explore other planets or risk possibly fatal consequences. Stamina is consumed when running and will auto refill whilst you are stationary and as far as I have seen has no other use. Lastly, health is pretty self explanatory, when you take damage you'll lose health which you can regenerate by using the various medical items in game.

Exploration in Empyrion is so far the most enjoyable part for me with plenty to be found already. There are multiple types of resources and mobs that you'll find, some which are peaceful and others that'll attack on sight. There are also pre-built structures such as settlements of other races, abandoned factories or buildings and crashed ships to explore and scavenge. Once you tire of your current planet you can leave and explore space and other moons (right now I wasn't able to find too much in space but I'm sure more content will be added to during early access).
You can level yourself via exploration and combat and this will grant you with unlock points to be spent within your tech trees. Your tech tree allows you to unlock various items that'll be useful but also grants you a way to control your progression rather than having predefined unlocks thrust upon you. This lets you to choose which gameplay style you prefer, prioritizing combat upgrades over base building ones for example if you prefer an aggressive approach to things.
Crafting is relatively simple, you'll need to the correct resources, have the correct tech unlocked and the correct crafting machine built. Once you input all the items or resources into the machine (it can store crafting materials there that aren't in use) you select the output item and quantity then wait for construction to complete.

For all the creative people who are torn on whether or not to buy Empyrion, I suggest checking out some of the Steam Workshop creations to see just what is possible as even I was shocked at what some people are able to create.

Despite being a fantastic game I must mention Empyrion is not without fault, though I am sure this is due to it's early access nature. Right now the tutorial is completely text based and missable if you do not pay attention within the first 10 seconds of the game. To access the tutorial you must press F1 which is explained to you in a tiny box beside the mini-map which disappears shortly after appearing. I cannot understand why this does not just remain there until you choose to close it. My first time playing I missed it and this led to me having no clue what I was meant to be doing until after ten minutes of running around aimlessly I restarted completely. Once I was able to work my way through the tutorial there were some important bits of information that I felt were missing and I was only able to find out what most of the buttons did by repeatedly switching back and forth between the game and key binding settings. Whilst completing the various tutorial objectives I was also switching between that menu and the game without realising there is no auto-pause feature so my oxygen and food levels were depleting whilst I was reading the walls of text.
My only other complaint is placing blocks can be very tricky at times and can end up leaving you feeling frustrated because they don't align properly or snap out of place as you left click placing it somewhere else entirely. This makes building a solid foundation for a base a little tedious at time, especially in survival mode.

Empyrion so far has a lot to offer in terms of content and has active developers who provide frequent updates. The gameplay is very fun and the appealing graphics, immersive soundtrack and multiplayer options are a huge plus. If you're a fan of any of the great base-building survival games then there is no doubt you'll love Empyrion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm currently on the Free Weekend with maybe an hour under my belt, and my impression of the game so far has been favorable.  There's obviously a bit of a learning curve with the game, as there is with any survival game at this stage of development, but once I found the in-game PDA with basic information, things started to fall into place.

There's certainly work that still needs to be done on the game, as I have seen several things things that are either missing (reload animations) or using low-quality placeholder assets (players w/o their helmets look rough).  But this is not the first alpha-phase survival game I've played, so I know the routine.  I've also seen some reviews from other long-time players that indicate the devs are fairly active with the community as well.

At the very least, I certainly play to put more time into the game this weekend when I get the time, and will update my review when I can.

EDIT:  It's been nearly a week now since my first review, and I've had a hard time tearing myself away from it.  The game has been very enjoyable, from exploring a given planet to reaching outer space and beginning to explore out there.  As I said earlier, there are rough spots in the game, but for the state the game is in right now, even for an early alpha, it's been very enjoyable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review will just highlight some key things.  My full, long winded, review is here - http://steamcommunity.com/app/383120/discussions/0/357286119116489333/

(Many of the issues I encountered have been fixed with update 1.6 which is a good sign.)

I tried the game, in early state, as part of the free weekend given out on 5/13/2016. ~5 hours. I started on the, hard, planet Omicron. I figured it would be the most most challenging and interesting.  In addition to exploring and doing my own things I followed the tutorial, built an initial camp, a base, a hover vessel, and ultimately a small vessel to visit another planet.  These are my initial impressions and my experiences throughout that time.

PROS
*Stability and performance - No crashes, errors, or slowdown.  Game ran great.

*Concept - A sci-fi game where you build ships and explore planets has a ton of potential.

*Graphics - Didn't  have the typical blockiness of the genre. Looked good.

*World Generation - The planets, despite being procedural looked natural. None of the normal strange in randomly made world stuff like large vertical dropoffs, odd floating bits, or opposing climates. Water looked great and it was relaxing to watch it lap at the shoreline.

*Game Start - You plummet down in an escape pod you can kind of steer instead of just spawning on land.

*Laser Mining Drill - Felt sci-fi unlike the copper pickaxe that other games hand you. Could do precise work or bore out large tunnels quickly.

*Jetpack - Fun to  to fly.  Essential for some terrain.

*The Drone - Hands down my favorite feature.  Deploy a drone which you can fly to scout and even build with.  Any builder game without it will now feel lacking to me.

CONS*Initial Survival - You start with a ton of supplies.  Weaponry, tools, healing, curing, food, oxygen, base stations, lots resources, flashlight, portable work light, seeds for crops, crop soil, crop lights, etc.  I didn't feel like I was roughing it" at all.

*Survival Overall - Never felt like I was trying to survive.  Start with a machine for  oxygen.  Can easily get lots of food by picking plants
recommended: or planting it.  The biggest survival issues were that its possible to get into situations where you are kinda stuck. Such as not having enough resources to make drill ammo to mine not enough to make bullets to kill creatures that are preventing you from mining to make more bullets

Early Access Review

Wow. I have been looking for a Space survival game since Starforge collapsed underneath me (RIP). Tried Space Engineers and felt like I needed an engineering degree, plus the pay-off for all that minutia just wasn't doing it for me. Starmade was too 8-bit for my tastes. That's great for Minecraft, but this is SPACE!

I've spent probably 60 hours in the game and I'm still loving it. The Survival part seems simple, but is tricky enough to enjoy once you get the formula down. The sunset and sun-up make you want to take screenshots and I'll  literally stop any project I'm working on at the moment. The variety of blocks are great and they have been constantly adding. Can't wait for Alpha and then Beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Damn this game is awesome. Sure, there's a ton of things still missing, but I wasn't that much hooked to a game in a long long time.

You start small on a planet with quite some ressources. First it seems pretty easy as you have a lot of everything. But if you aren't careful you might run out faster on things than you think.

As soon as you start building you get ideas. Bases, Shipyard, huge Capital Ships... possibilities seem endless. If you just would have the ressources for it....

There isn't that much danger for your base, and usually I don't like games without a threat... because they tend to become boring fast. But not this one. There's just to much things to do to bring yourself up to speed so you manage to get yourself juicy bases and enough ressources to concentrate on building the big things.

And on the hunt for ressources you get quite some action as there are enemy bases set around that fire on you. Also the wildlife is not that tame and a drone here and there is also a danger.

I had one smash my Glider while I was mining. Barely made it back to base, literally with my last breath on oxygen. Be careful out there, if you don't plan ahead you will be done for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This has been the most addicting and promising early access game I've ever played. Even in Alpha, it's got the content to keep you interested for quite a long time, and despite having some bugs, none of them has been game-breaking. It's definetly worth the money.

But the best is still to come. I have confidence in the developers. They're good. The concept, the tech, the controls, the way everything is put together, the many things you can do... it just smells good game design, they know what they want.
I really hope they can keep up and push through all the roadblocks every game has, because this game is what many people has been waiting for... even if they didn't know.

It's got the potential to become a cult classic, and I urge everybody with a love for exploration, building and survival, to give it a try and help the developers shape it all the way to the end.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and foremost, ignore the Recent flux of negitive reviews for this game. Most have come here from space engineers during the free weekend with the mindset that this game is like SE, and its not, and also foregetting that the game was just recently released to steam, and is currently still in beta/EA.

Now, with that said, I am giving it a postitive review because it has several things to offer if you are willing to give it a real chance.

Pro's:
1. Survival actually plays a role, at least in the early steps of the game.
2. Need to work for the items.
3. Need to manage resources in early game.
4. Neutral and hostle mobs to contend with.
5. Several planets/moons to explore, all randomly generated.

Con's
1. Building is a bit clunky until you get used to it.
2. hotbar switching is slow (I.E. switching from slot 1 to slot 2 for example)
3. AI pathfinding works, but no attempt is made to dodge your attacks.
4. In-game tutorial is easy to miss if not paying close enough attention.

Overall:
I feel that the game is worth it. The devs are very active in bug fixing and on the steam forums. Even for a game that is beta/EA, it is stable (only tested SP, haven't tried MP yet) and plays rather smooth. Keep in mind, at the time of this review the game is early in its EA release and more is yet to be added/addressed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I have about 21 hours into this game. I am one of the lucky ones who has had no major glitches (no runaway ships, falling through the world or that sort of thing). For a game that is using a lot of stock tools, textures, models etc it is really well thought out. Despite having a lot of placeholders in it it feels very unique and has a personality all its own. The flow of it is very good. You start off with a sense of hopelessness and panic, as any good survival game should have, but quickly learn to get over yourself and get to work.

Once you've beaten that initial fear of dying and gotten a rythm going you move on to bigger and better things. The game is excellent at creating a phased" or tiered growth
date: where each new plateau offers new challenges and new rewards. If this is a sign of things to come

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game to everyone, especially those that like Space Engineers or survival/build games. For a game in the pre-alpha stage it is extreamly advanced and if they never developed another line if code it would still be a very playable and addictive game as is.

The developers and player communitity seem to be very closely in sync. Based upon the past 2 updates that I have witnessed as a new player the dev team is implementing a very clear vision of where they plan to take this game with solid updates and new features.

If you have not already purchased it this will end up being one of those games that you will wish you had been a part of back in its early stage. Solid community, excellent devs, and outstanding playability make this arguably the best early access game on Steam today!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After some 80 hours of gaming in one week i have to say that i love this game so much. There are ofc some problems but with this game not being close to finnished i belive i will spend more time here then i am supposed to....

Start....

Started up in the dessert (Omicron) with nothing and died about 10 times before i figured out that i need to read something about this game.. After that i made my first home on Omicron with a large base and both HV and SV ships in hangar. Now it was time to go to space...

Space - The final frontier.......

Ive now realised that if you want to build something bigger its a good thing to draw it up on paper. Used up some 2000 blocks before i was happy with it and some 30 hours later i have a space station that works :)

For now -

After all my stations and ships that i have created i thought that it was time for a CV to be created. I loaded up my SV with rockets and alot of fuel and went to the lava planet to get some special ore... Oh so much fun i had there and then BANG. My ship got blown to bits by a rocket turret i missed when figting the big towers. Lost my O2 generator and my crafter plus rcs and core.

So here i am after 80 hours. Im left on a lava planet with no crafter and a butt load of stuff in the ship and need to reboot bak to starting point. I think i have learned something. Remember to have replacement parts in ship when you go out fighting or build a local base.

Still im loving the game. For now i think il restart and make everything better from start.

PS: Love the idea of MP but il wait until there is a good way to protect youre gear.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. I've had so much fun playing with buddies on our own private server. The excitement of slowly gathering the appropriate amount of resources to build a base, then a hover vessel for travel, then a bigger base, then your first small vessel to explore the moon and space, and then a bigger base, and then finally a capital vessel is so excrutiating and exhilarating.

Really.

For an Alpha, this game feels more than playable. Thinking up new ship and base ideas, or emulating whatever sci-fi film franchise you can think of is never-ending.

The crafting system is relatively simple, and the learning curve will come naturally with a few hours of messing around.

Truly the biggest excitement here is being able to leave orbit and warp to other galaxies and planets. It's such a wonderful concept I've been waiting years for.

Alien bases are challenging, figuring out a good plan of attack is fun as well. Coordinating with fellow players and building bases together doesn't get old. There is always some new goal to complete, or new place to explore.

The devs work hard to update regularly, and whenever I've had issues or thoughts on how the game can get better, they seem to read my mind.

I really recomend this game, and while there are a fair amount of weird glitches and bugs and workarounds (especially for server owners) I trust these things will get ironed out one at time as the Alpha continues its progress.

Early Access Review

I bought this game quite a while ago. When I got it I would definitely not reccomended it. It had no content, was boring and was not enjoyable at all. However I finally decided to pick it up again with a friend because it was the free weekend and he wanted to try it.

We put 20 hours into the game in the past 2 days and each and every hour was so worth it. We had an absolute blast. At first we had to get our heads around the slightly over complicated crafting system and the confusing faction system but once we got out heads around that we got to work. We build a relatively large base and then expanded it as we finished building ships and needed to place them somewhere.

It took us about 4 hours to finally get to space and that is where we spent most of our time. We colonised planet after planet taking resources and then we would move onto the next planet conquer that, mine it then repeat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion is a survival game in a similar vein to Space Engineers but with the addition of planets and moons to visit and build on. The game sees you start of crashed on an alien world and from there you must produce oxygen and food to survive as well as materials for bases, ground vehicles and spacecraft to get you around the solar system.

At present the game is very much an alpha - it's playable but unoptimmized and there's clearly a lot of additional content to be added to the game. That being said, it's quite playable as-is and definitely fun. I've put together a tutorial series on the game, you can watch the first episode below!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZAb3Tf9yGs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, I'm just going to begin with this. It's  bloody amazing.
I recall the dark days where I would stare at the store page procrastinating for hours upon end. Well, those days are over as I now own this superior game. It's perfect for all those people who love a challenge and attempting to survive in a hostile environment at the same time. Empyrion boasts a huge potential, as it is only in a pre-alpha state.
From what I've gathered from my short time playing (wrote at 4hrs gameplay) is that you, a lone survivor of a ship lands their escape pod onto one of two planets, one where oxygen is plentiful and the other a desolate wasteland of a desert with the only oxygen being in water. Shame there are no fishies. Tasked with survival in mind, you soon come across superior foes that utilise UAVs and other autonomous weapons platforms.
I hate writing reviews. Do yourself a favour;
Purchase Empyrion - Galactic Survival.
Let me know if you are thinking of getting this game, and I may have to persuade you even further.

-F

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Haven't played this for long at all...but here is something that for me made the game worth every penny even if it still needs work. Long post but I think worth it.

So I bought Empyrion's Galactic Survival for 16 bucks on Steam. Got into it a bit and finally got my hover car built. Went out to mine...now you have to keep oxygen tanks with you because the air is not breathable so you are In a suit. Mined happily for a while....then realized I was running out of air...so hopped out of the mine ran back to the car listening to warning alarms going off about low air...stepped into the drivers side of the cars Oxygen fill line connector...and nothing happened...remembered now that the car has to be running...so hopped in...turned it on and hopped out back to the connector...nothing...hmmm...oh yeah needed to put air tanks in...and had forgot...so ran around to the passenger side to put them in...turned back to my car and...it....was....GONE.

....panicked....the looked around...sure enough there it was racing off to my right...I had apparently parked on a hill...it has no parking brake....so chased my car down the hill...finally managing to jump in.......just as it went off a cliff......following a wild ride worthy of Disney....I crashed into a chasm at the bottom....

Glad to have survived but with almost no air left...I hopped out and ran for the connector....well that was the plan...this being a hover car I had not realized it was sitting on a deep river between two steep walls since this was now after dark...so I dropped like a rock 20 feet or more to the bottom...had to fight my way back up then out, then up part of the cliff to try and jump back into the car...3rd try made it...BEEP BEEP BEEEEEP....going off constantly...drove just far enough to find a way out...get on level ground hopped out and...AIR....survived barely.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hopefully the final game has a tutorial, I've grasped most of the game's mechanics but it sure took a lot of dying to get there.

+ The game Starforge failed to be
+ Surprisingly playable for an alpha. (I'm at 50+ hours!)
+ That moment you realise there are far scarier things out there than drones
+ Multiplayer already!
+ High Risk, High Reward vs Careful Survival, both are perfectly viable
+ Leaving atmo for the first time, then panicking because you forgot to put your helmet on
+ Becoming a space pirate
+ Wondering what the heck that blob is, then realising it's a huge crashed spaceship, and a perfect spot to set up camp for the night

- Your ship will get blown up at some point leaving you stranded. At this point you will probably run/jetpack around frantically looking for a solution while getting shot at, give up, die and ragequit because all of your stuff in the ship's cargo box just got annihilated, and all your personal belongings just got dropped in an unknown place that requires a spaceship to get to. I know this isn't exactly the game doing anything wrong, but it cripples gameplay when ships are SO MUCH more vulnerable than you are.
- Clicking Save" should create an entirely new save that won't get overwritten by your ship getting promptly exploded
- The options menu does not pause the game. If you pause the game
date: you can't use the options menu. Starving to death while changing settings isn't really my idea of fun"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion has great atmosphere, the feeling of isolation on a planet is well realised, the strange alien noises and the barren vistas help to absorb the player into its world. The mechanics, from the crafting to the building is reasonable enough, a lack of a decent tutorial keeps you guessing as to what much of the items actually do at times. This learning curve hides quite a deep game underneath, considering its early access it delivers a lot more content than a host of similar games.

+ Atmospheric
+ Engaging and progressive
-  Not very accessible
-  Controls aren't the best

I recommend Empyrion quite highly, its got a good amount of content and manages to be enjoyable and progressive. It reminds me a lot of Starforge but the execution here is much much better. Very excited to see how this game develops in the future.

Empyrion Galactic Survival is a great cross between Space Engineers, Minecraft and may be even Planet Explorers. If you enjoy Space Ships, Base Building and Surviving in a hostile enviroments you will love Empyrion. This game is not as deep as space engineers when it comes to building ships, bases or devices to fill your needs but the simplicity has its own charm and functions with what the developers are trying to create with this game. Its a great game as of yet and the road map the developers have up are full of features that are well grounded and achievable.

Even in its current EA state I reccomend this game for any one that enjoys action survival games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is simply fantastic, and has so, so much potential.

The fact that this is made using Unity, makes me love it that much more.

If you are looking for a game that involves interplanetary take off and landings, survival, combat against alien creatures and fascist robots, modular building, tech trees, and smooth voxel based (at least I think that's what it is) destruction, then this is thhe game for you.

Get it while it's not £39.99, which is the price this game will be worth upon completion.

Put it this way, I was so, so hyped for Fallout 4, purchased it, played it for two hours. I then saw this game on the store, bought it, and haven't wanted to play Fallout since!

I recommend this game whole-heartedly, and wish it the best of success!

This is hands down one of the best survival games ive ever played and its only in alpha. I have not been able to stomache any other survival games since early minecraft but this one did it somehow. Seriously its great guys.
Im gonna just copy and paste a story of what happened to me and my friends in the game that I wrote down somewhere else. (It all really happened)


So on a voyage back to our homeworld of earth on the U.S.S. Xanadu we come under attack by what appears to be alien like drones
date: our ship was lightly armed so we didnt stand a chance. They took out our engines first and we were locked in a descent towards a desert planet that our archives said it was named "Omicron". In our descent we hopped into an escape pod and I managed to land us into a desert mountain valley next to a very large body of water. We had nothing but a few rations and a coupple of energy packs. We could see a few lit up towers and combat drones on the horizon and our crashed ship in the sand a few miles away. Me and my two crew mates Ensign Jeremiah Neilson
hoursPlayed: and me their leader Captian Evalyn Dykton armed ourselves with a few standard issue pistols we grabbed as the ship was going down. We set up a means of oxygen generation in the nearby shallow water and headed to the wreck of our ship. We were met with heavy resistance and a few drones took down Ensign Soc and we had to leave him with some water and food while me and Ensign Jeremiah headed to the wreck. We managed to find enough things to start our inssurection of the alien forces. Over the coming weeks we set up a base and hover craft with weapons and one by one
voteText: the towers fell and the alien prescence on the planet was slowly extinguished. With the peace we decided to start fixing up a ship to head to orbit and we construced the Dragonfly dropsip which was baiscially a mobile base. We did some test flights and loaded it with weapons
helpfulPercent: ammo

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI just bought this a few days ago and I am enjoying it quite a lot. The game has some polishing that needs to be done but the survival aspects are real. You start with a generous amount of supplies when you land on your starting planet and it may seem easy enough making progress but once you've made some of the basic machines and a small base your resources are going to run out and quickly...so you'll need to make a vehicle to find resources and take them back to base because the planets are BIG and the ore veins are reasonably spread apart. Either that or you can make some weapons and try to assualt some of the alien bases you'll encounter which btw are actually quite nerve wrecking to infiltrate. Mainly because they are guarded by automated turrets, drones and infested with alien soldiers as well as their Pets". but the rewards are definitely justifiable. Give this game a go if you love building and even more so if you love space exploration. This game has a very distinct tone and although there's no story

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The focus of the game was clearly outlined on the store page as an galactic exporation and space game. So far they have just catored to the PvP crowd and made one big PvP arena (only one solar system in the game). This to me is not galactic exploration. I imagined building creations and exploring the galaxy.

I really wish they would have said they were making a PvP survival arena instead of a galactic exploration game like the name implies and I could have saved myself some hard earned money. I would wait to pick up this game and see where it goes, as maybe down the line they will make this the game it should be.

I also want to mention this is not a bad game and their is some fun to be had. It is however not at all finished. Some of the top reviews are over sensationalizing their experiences. The game needs a lot of work still. I see no reason to rush your purchase in its current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game with very lofty goals.  Disclaimer: I'm playing this for free during their free preview weekend.

Overall: It still needs work, a lot of it.  It's Early Access Alpha, but it still needs a lot of tuning.  However, the gameplay itself is reasonably stable and what's there is quite functional.

The game's general premise is crash land on a planet and eventually build yourself up into a galactic menace.  You'd think the poor guy really would like to just get home once he's got a warp engine, but it gets a bit open ended.

The biggest problem is the grinding of materials. You have to make every pipe, every eletronic component, every everything.  That's fine, for a game like Factorio or Big Pharma where it's all about automating the pipeline.  For a game like this, where I find myself making 200-500 of each item before I go on a mining mission just so I don't have to wait again, it's a huge time sink for a game that has a core gameplay of 'make cool things and go blow them up'.

The fix for that is to simply make more constructors, but each constructor has its own inventory of materials to use for constructing which is incredibly micro heavy, and you can't give orders along the lines of Keep 200 each of Pipes
hoursPlayed: and Electronics in supply" either.\n\nThen there's little things
voteText: like your character is too distracted to reload on his own when you use up the 10 shots in your starting pistol.  You have to manually reload.  Mining

votesTotal: which you can only upgrade AFTER you've built a ship

column18: which is a 500 value bar).  You can't build 'under' a vessel until you've got it halfway built and can hover it with power.  Your inventory in the constructors are non-searchable and have no sorting
column19: making for a game of hide and seek when you build a component or to figure out what supplies you have available.  A few dozen more of these small things add up to tedious exercises that just shouldn't be there.\n\nFinally
column20: there's a gameplay choice I'm not sure I like

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a great space survival, adventure, and construction game. You can explore planets, mine resources, build ships and bases, and attack aliens. There are several planets to explore, all with their own unique features.

The best part about this game is the light system requirements. It should run fine on a 5-year-old laptop with decent specs. I have played many hours of Empyrion, and I'm sure I will play many more in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is fantastic! 9.5/10

It run really well on my 5 year old PC. Core2Quad 2.4ghz with 8gig RAM and a GTX660 2gig gpu getting me around 60FPS at 1080p on 'best'.

The crafting system is fantasticly involved and pretty well thought out. I am well on my way to building my first small ship.

There are one or two small issues but they are tiny and will no doubt be tackled in due course. It is far too early to be moaning and groaning about anything in this game. As the saying goes, rather be a part of the solution and not a part of the problem :) ie, report bugs using the correct methods.

I am so excited to be following the progress of this game over the next few years :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay Spawned in.... Look around to find out i am in an escape pod plummeting to the ground, on the way down i realise.... I dont know how to talk... so i button mash everything until i accidentally hit Enter... It drops me out of the drop pod into a nest of monsters.... all my gear is in the drop pod so no gun for me.... Then the drop pod lands and right before i reach it, a giant monster with 3 arms eats me.... 10/10


Serious review: This game is amazing, it is LIKE space engineers however those two games do not compare as they are on different calibers, this game however is like space engineers in the fact you can build your ship as big as you want but unlike other space games, in this game you have to make sure you have the supplies to run such a large ship as other games i have played once you get a large ship... it is end game as you never have to do anything to sustain it.
You have tons of weapons to fight off alien hordes and your ship can be what you want it to be without lagging your computer badly (Looking at you SE) this game also has very minor Block deformation, if you smash into an asteroid at 100m/s the front of your ship will be dented badly... and some blocks flatout break when you hit asteroids, Bases on this game are also amazing, want an orbital platform that can blockade the planet and stop people from landing on it? You can do that (However most server players would turn against you if you acted like the Empire....)

So for the amazing Dev team and game i give this game 9/10 and i will boost it up to a 10 when they allow small ships small warp drives that let them jump 1 AU (AU is a measurement of distance i believe) as right now small ships must dock to a capital ship to warp.

Main highlights of my game.... Launching the millenium falcon while being shot at by drones is one of the best feelings ever.

11/28/15 Update:

The tech tree was slightly adjusted but this game is still unplayably broken. I'll do a short explaination of how my attempts went after giving the new update a chance.

Landed on the planet, gather the supplies out of the pod, start searching for food and iron to setup a base. Stumble across the crashed ship mid section, kill a couple of drones. Get an alert about a dropship, 3 dogs and 2 NPCs land, I killed one before having to run away, being chased by drones.

At this point my current situation is that I have no building materials, no upgrade points" to even start a legitimate base

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

Empyrion - The Salami Simulator

I cannot recommend this game at all. The multitude of problems it has aren’t just because the game is early access - they are fundamental design issues.

Starting the game hurtling towards the planet in an escape pod is a nice touch, even if the controls for guiding it seem a little... uncontrollable but the game then proceeds to fill your inventory with enough resources to last for days, which seems slightly counterintuitive in a survival game. Since the pod then mysteriously vanishes you’re left carrying thousands of tonnes worth of metal around in your backpack whilst the game tells you to go pick plants and such. Naturally that is a priority because whilst the escape pod designers decided that the absolute minimum amount of iron necessary to survive was enough to build a 1:1 scale working replica of the Eiffel Tower they neglected to include more than a handful of rations. I picked some aloe vera, some fiber and some... corn dogs (?) and moved on with the tutorial.

One of the first things it has you do is build an oxygen generator, so I naturally assumed the planet did not have a breathable atmosphere. Oxygen was a big problem at first and I found myself constantly having to pick up bottles from the generator and wait the achingly long time it takes the constructor to convert a 200 unit O2 tank into single 50 unit bottle whilst pondering what it does with the other 150 units. Then I discovered I could just take my helmet off and breathe perfectly fine without oxygen bottles, throwing into question why building an oxygen generator was the first priority on a planet filled with oxygen and indeed why it needs a water source when it could evidently just suck oxygen out of the air...

The next issue was one of food or rather - an overabundance of it. Whilst resources like iron and copper stack in hundreds food items don’t seem to stack at all. So half my bag was literally filled with salami. The salami situation became increasingly problematic as every time I needed to craft something I was having to juggle salami back and forth between the constructor and the inventory just to make space. That or eat it.

So needless to say I passed the ‘Survival Cooking’ part of the tutorial with flying colours. Then it decided the next priority after stuffing myself with sausage was naturally to craft an assault rifle. Forget where I’m going to sleep tonight or what I am going to do with a dozen artisanal sausages - the priority was clearly weaponry. Up until now the local slimes hadn’t been a particular issue and apart from one mildly menacing dinosaur it hardly seemed like my 50 cal pistol was on the weak side.

To craft an assault rifle however I needed to level up and this meant actively seeking out slimes to shoot or plants to pick and that meant walking about half a mile to find any. By the time I finally got enough experience to build the rifle it was night and I couldn’t see to shoot it anyway. Surely, I thought, the next thing to do must be to build a shelter but no, the tutorial decided to tell me to go collect some ore from the mine which was 400m away across the other side of a lake. If there is a swim button I haven’t found it so this meant either sinking to the bottom of the lake and walking across the floor and out the other side like some kind of swamp monster or saving the O2 and hiking a mile through the woods.

As I still had 300 ingots of more or less every metal known to man I decided neither option was particularly sensible and enough was enough. After wildly mashing every function key on the keyboard I managed to get the tutorial log to pop up and found I could just skip to the next chapter: Build a Base.

Ah, I thought, now the game will finally get interesting. How wrong I was.

It told me to place a generator, fuel tank and large constructor... conveniently missing out ‘build a generator, fuel tank and large constructor’ - a process which must have taken a good half hour of waiting for things to finish building. The very first thing this game should tell you to do is to construct 200 metal components and a mile of cable because you’re going to spend about ten minutes alone waiting for that to finish with nothing to do. This problem is hampered hugely by the constructor requiring you to manually manufacture every intermediate part for everything you build. You can’t just click ‘build generator’ and go do something fun. You have to build the computers, the control devices, the reactor and to build each of those you have to make the cables, the metal components, the electronics the... god is this actually meant to be a game?

Still I persevered and actually built the base only to find I was entirely unable to activate it. The tutorial says to simply press Y to activate the base but this results in absolutely nothing happening. Even after getting the generator going, the base glowing green (for some reason) and the constructor churning out thousands of bullets without making a dent in my starting resources the base is apparently still not active and the tutorial remains incomplete. So I give up.

I thought the game might suddenly show its hidden potential after building a base but all that happened was that a minigun drone showed up and started shooting me whilst I was AFK (because you cannot pause the game). I’m not sure how long it had been going at it only that my screen was so filled with blood and night time is so dark that I wasn’t sure precisely what was going on - only that eating salami didn’t seem to solve the problem. After actually managing to work out what was attacking me and from where I tried shooting it with my assault rifle but it didn’t seem to work. Then I remembered the game doesn’t automatically reload the guns. I reloaded, killed it instantly and dived into the lake to loot it’s corpse only to find it was loaded with half the required materials to build a base that I’d just wasted half an hour making...

I then decided the best course of action was to stay at the bottom of the lake... and take my helmet off.


EDIT: Some ammendments based on the comments.

Apparently you can swim but only when empty handed, otherwise you just immediately sink. Clearly 'treading water' wasn't a part of his training.

Apparently you can pause the game but only with the Pause Break button. Clearly the developers decided that this was the most sensible place to put that function and that pausing the game whilst editing the settings or with the escape key would be totally insane...

Salami goes in the fridge, not in your pockets. Happy now?

Seems like the sort of things a tutorial might have wanted to point out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine making a game where your unique selling point is that you can experience survival across the expanse of space, build spaceships and land cruisers, hunt and mine anywhere... then shroud the entire thing in the dullest crafting experience known to man.

I've just spent the first (and last) 3 hours looking at sub-dependencies of sub-dependencies of sub-dependencies of dependencies of the item I actually want to craft.  By which time, I forgot what I wanted to craft!

This game is in dire need of a crafting overhaul.  Don't make me mouseclick 300 times in order to click once on the thing I want.  Just let me click once, and auto craft all the sub-dependent components.  Show me those sub-components being crafted so that I experience the semantic learning... but don't put me through the pain of doing it manually - it's excruciating, especially using those tiny windows that barely display components.

Ack!  A great premise, but the reality is that it's layers of button-clicking tedium.

Save your money, wait for the process to be rationalised.
