reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has grown a lot since the pre-alpha release when I purchased it. There are always things you can do. Empyrion is in EA and shows it, with a few bugs and features missing. However, as far as EA's go, the Empyrion team has done a wonderful job.
The biggest compliment is that the dev's listen to the players and build around our wants as well as their vision. Ever since the private release this has been true and has remained so.
While there are a number of features still in the planned phase, the game as it is is quite enough for most players to get a handle on what the game is about and how to survive. Since the inclusion of randomly generated planets, this can only get better!
So, TLDR

Pro:
Devs listen and respond to players.
Game doesn't take a whole lot to play (PC wise)
EA title that hasn't abandoned it's goals
You can build multiple different vehicles and bases
Can be a challenging game, but also lets you use your creative side.

Cons:
Still in EA. Don't think this game is done being polished, it isn't.
Can be a bit hard to learn the controls at first, but they are fairly easy after you get use to them.
May be to challenging for some, especially if you don't watch any of the tutorial videos.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game.  There are some reasons that make me consider a negative rating, but the overall enjoyment I've had with this game is outweighing.
The devs update frequently, and the game has changed quite a bit since I first started playing.
It can be difficult to set up, but I strongly suggest playing this game with 1-2 friends in co-op mp.  As with most survival games, I strongly suggest against using a wiki.  This game is about discovery and creativity, all while trying to survive in or around planets of varying hostility and brutality.
The game is also completely enjoyable playing by yourself in single player, but for new players, you will probably appreciate friends to help the progress.
I suggest getting this game on sale.  Don't expect any kind of storyline, ultimate goal, etc.  This game is about surviving, crafting, mining, getting so rich and powerful that you don't have to worry about mining for weeks, exploring, taking bases, creating bases, creating any kind of space ship you want, hell, even farming.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent game from a small team of devs that is seriously competing with other games of a similar genre. Having played a lot of EA titles I have become very wary when it comes to purchasing them, I went out on a limb and bought Empryion, it was the correct choice.

The first thing that greets you as you enter your lovely fresh planet is the planet itself hurtling at you as you zoom down in your escape pod, manically trying to land somewhere nice to start building, if you're lucky you will even spot some resources on your flight down.

Once you land you are free to do whatever you want, firstly you will want to grab your backup supplies from your escape pod, you will have EVERYTHING you need here to work through the tutorial which holds your hand quite nicely through everything you will need to know, ranging from:

- Crafting
- Building your first base
- Kitting it out with essentials
- Teaches you multiple ways to get food
- Building your first ship / hovercraft / capital vessel

If you follow the tutorial you really cannot go wrong, I am seeing some daft posts about placing o2 generators on land etc. well read the tutorial, clearly states it has to be placed in water, not fully submerged but on the edge is generally fine.

The base building and ship building in the game is partly my favourite aspect, I have been using workshop content as honestly I am not always the most creative, by god there are some nice ships out there. You have a vast amount of styles of blocks to work with to make your ships / bases look beautiful, lots of interior items if you want to go for the nice cosmetic / at home feel.

Leaving the planet for the first time has to be one of the most exciting things, you finally are free, power up that warp drive and head for the stars.

So far I have jumped lightyears away and found a hostile research facility, parked up my capital vessel and investigated with my smaller attack ship. I took out the research defences, docked up and hunted down the core of the structure, after swiftly demolishing the core I returned to my capital vessel, crafted my own and zoomed back, powered that baby online and got to work repairing and extending the landing bay to fit my CV on.

Another part I love ^ see a nice alien base? Take that ♥♥♥♥ over, destroy the core, place yours and you have a new home, just make sure you don't go in rockets flying as if you plan on taking it over, you'll have a lot to repair!

Tl:dr

1. Solid game considering it's just entered alpha

2. Very friendly community on the official forums (Lets be honest, steam discussions are horrible everywhere)

3. Tutorial will answer any questions you have, if you think you need a little bit more helps just join a server instead of going in single player - You will have more fun and be helped out a lot should you need it / ask. (UG Galactic Stuff - Friendly server ran by myself, if you can get on you will be welcome with open arms)

4. Space exploration that works really well

5. Hostile takeover of bases

6. Customise everything

7. Workshop content galore + easy to upload your own stuff

8. Hard working devs for such a small team

9. Exciting PVP

10. Constantly being worked on / updated.


Exactly what I want out of an EA game, cost less than a takeaway and have already gotten 55 hours on record, I did not expect to have this much fun, thought it would be a play for a few hours then come back in 3 months" type of game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion: Galactic Survival: Pre-Alpha 2.0.1

Survival: After crash landing your escape pod you find yourself stranded on a desert planet which happens to be full of lakes. In your escape pod you have everything you need to survive the harsh oxygenless planet at least for a little while. The race is on to build a shelter that can protect you from the hostile inhabitants of this rather moist desert planet until you are prepared to go from hunted to hunter. Slowly getting back to your technologically superior roots.

Building a hover vehicle to get around to resources quickly, is a good idea once your base is established as walking everywhere isn't the funnest of activities. Once you have a good amount of resources its time to leave this H2O filled Desert planet behind and explore the semi confined atm reaches of space.

Empyrion is a fun game that will only get funner with updates. It has all the classic features of a good survival game with a few twists like oxygen and with the add on of a game like StarMade or Space Engineers it gets even better. Multiplayer work flawlessly as long as you either port forward your IP or use a VPN like Hamachi or Tunngle. It is suspiring how stable this game is for only being on EA for a day. You can tell the Devs put a lot of love and thought into the game and I can't wait to see where they take it.

7/10 - The score is rated as if this game stopped development right now as it's still a very playable game, if not feature full.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Playing for the free weekend, and want to get a review in before the sale ends. I have only played solo so far.  In short...is it worth the $10 it is now?  YES...is it worth the full price if you miss the sale?....Hell YES!

Try this game if you like sci fi, survival, exploring, sandbox games or doing things the way you want.

Are there bugs?  Of course there bloody are!  It's an alpha game.  I have not run into any game breaking bugs yet, all small or annoying things but nothing that would stop me playing.

I've played a lot of survival games in various stages of early access and release on Steam and this is so far my favorite.

So the obligitory pro/con list:

Pro:

-No zombies.  Animals, dinosaures (I think maybe the triceratops should go, it's an alien planet), and alien natives.

-Factions (not sure how this works or if it is fully available yet), seems you can set up your own factions as well.

-Detailed and extensive craft system.

-Good selection of starting items and food/meds to get you through you first couple of days.

-Good tutorial.  YES it is a good tutorial...just read the dirrections in your PDA like it says.  Push F1, read, do, done.  The people complaining about the tutorial are not using the PDA or following instructions.

-Player leveling and  a tech tree to unlock new gear, you choose the order.

-Blueprints.  I have looked at the stock ones, but I belive you can make your own.  Want a nice house but not a build master?  No Problem, get a blueprint, add all the mats and off you go.

-It's $10 bucks on sale!  More than worth it.

Con

(Early Alpha - much of this will be fixed)

-Complex crafting system which I like!  But some people (the impatient ones) may find it annoying to have to build all the parts before building the item you want.  And your parts take parts too....so it can be slow at first.  Sometimes you are waiting around for stuff to just get made so you can move on.  (If the devs are reading, I hope there is or will be a craft station up the tech tree that can speed this up somewhat)

-Inability to move things once placed.  You need to destroy them back into their componenets.  This will probably be addressed as alpha moves on.

-Building is a bit hmm...awkward to me.  Again something I think will be addressed.  It is sometimes hard to get your blocks to snap into place...and the are large and it can be hard to see where you are putting them.  Along with the above issue it can be a little tricky to get the hang of.

Really I'm struggling to find cons.  I could list more but it's just stuff that will improve as the game is fleshed out.  Give this a try.  I don't think you will regret it.  It costs about $15 to go to a movie....$50 if you buy a snack...and that's 2 hours tops of entertainment....Even at full price you will get far more out of this game than a movie...and virtual snacks...made out of seaweed...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion - Galactic Survival is an ambitious sandbox survival game. We've been getting quite a few sandbox games lately. I even wrote an article just pointing out whether or not they can be fun here[www.earlyaccessmedia.com]. So what is it that makes Empyrion different than the other dozen or so sandbox games that came out recently? I'd have to say the scope of the world. Much like the much anticipated title 'No Man's Sky' the projected scope here with Empyrion is cause for concern and excitement.

Eleon Game Studios is trying to do something on a scale that makes me concerned for the future of the title. Currently, Empyrion sits as a great base for a sandbox game. A deep crafting system, mining system, combat system, and survival system. It's all in place. Now it comes down to moving forward into what the game promises to be.

Much like the aforementioned No Man's Sky, Empyrion promises to make a sandbox game that has many procedurally generated planets to explore and you can travel between them and build bases across the universe. Ambitious right? Even more ambitious is that they plan to bring this all to dedicated online multiplayer servers. Something No Man's Sky has decided to instead make into a single player experience and push all that data to a server for exploration purposes. So is this the multiplayer version of No Man's Sky? Potentially.

Empyrion so far is promising, with the crafting systems in place to create vehicles, spacecrafts, food, cosmetics. Actually it's one of the deeper sandboxes i've played in early access. I'm having a lot of fun. However, I fear the day it goes online. Poor communities and hackers tend to ruin sandbox games for me.

https://youtu.be/dz4MNLXJUG8

Most the problems I've had so far aren't really game problems just poor explanation problems. Lacking a coherent tutorial and poor item descriptions makes watching a video tutorial or reading the forums a necessity. This is why my review video ended up being more of a tutorial video. I usually do my reviews live and record what the first 30-60 minutes are like to give you an idea of what to expect. However, I decided to give the game the benefit of being a sandbox game and played a bit more before recording the video. Most games have fairly simple mechanics so an honest first look usually is enough to get an idea. Sandbox games don't really fit that bill.

Empyrion is a promising deep sandbox title, it already has systems in place for a universe wide galactic space odyssey. Let's just hope Eleon didn't bite off more than they can chew.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minecraft with a time-based crafting system ( Don't worry, it only costs time no $$$ allowed)
Death is not permenant but can be a setback.
I hate all survival/crafting games. This is one of them and I don't hate it. :)

No clear tutorial, here is some advice from what I've learned in a few hours. Will help you alot.

Don't scrap core compenents on starting ship! All you need is an RCS(?) to fix it, saving you alot of time.
Don't try and build a land vehicle you cant access all the ore you need on the starting planet.
Starting planet tall tower is very deadly and totally a buzz-kill if you just built a ship so you can get to it.
You can loot machines once killed for nice compenents
Build a base ON THE WATER(makes life simple)
Be very very careful the module you are building goes on the right structure you want.

Have fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best early access games in development, worth every penny.

I could write paragraphs about how brilliant this game is, but I will keep it short.  Eleon Game Studios is simply creating a masterpiece, for an early alpha I have never seen such a solid stable content loaded game ever.  This game should set the new standard on how ambitious games should be from now on.  You could literally sink hundreds of hours into this game mining, farming, crafting, ship building, base building, exploring, hunting, foraging,  exterminating hostile aliens, travelling from planet to planet, and that is just in singleplayer.  Imagine doing all of these things online with your friends and foes..

Brilliant game...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion; Crash land, get your starting gear and Survive.  Excellent survival game (from someone addicted to the Genre; Starbound, Minecraft, The Long Dark, Stranded, Stranded II, The Forest, Terraria and many more...), is as advertised.  Somewhat complex Crafting.

Good game for solo play, much better with friends.

IMHO Scoring:
Graphics: 7/10 (9/10 for Alpha)
Animations: 5/10 - Alpha; Lack of immersive animations i.e. reloading
Customization:
- Character 3/10 (5/10 for Alpha)
- Bases 10/10
- Ships 10/10
Audio: 7/10 (Great ambience, good sound effects, musical score still lacking)
Crafting: 8/10 Simple, yet complex

Overall: 7.5/10 Highly recommend to anyone interested in the Survival Genre

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If space and survival and construction is your thing, this game is absolutely a must have.
As of alpha patch 1.5.4 (played survival):
It. Is. Amazing. Played the game the whole weekend straight. There is so much and the game isn't even done yet!
What got me the most is the seamless transition between planet surface, space and other planets. Game also has:
Crashed ships and abandoned bases to explore
Alein fortresses to assault
Survival and resource collection (of course)
And most importantly: spacecraft creation is just spectacular. After gathering the ingredients, putting everything on my vessel, and carefully arranging the thrusters for over an hour I finally had something that looked like a flying garbage can and that I can call my own and be proud of. Took it to orbit and back, a drone shot off my main thruster while I was mining some ore, so I had to fly to my base sideways.
Seriously, just look at the screenshots, get this game!

Developers : 10/10  -  I love your active style and frequent updates
Community / workshop : 10/10 for creating great toys to put to use in my quest for Galactic dominence

10/10 would be again

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

Empyrion - Galactic Survival seems so far, to be a really neat Sci-Fi survival game, and I have enjoyed my time with the game. I cant go into huge details about the game yet, having only played a few hours however I do recommend survival fans check it out. I did not get nearly as much time with the game during the free weekend as I wanted to, that being said I only have good things to say so far.

- Nice, but rough visuals

- Combat is not bad, many survival games have trouble getting it just right.
While it still needs work, its at a place I find acceptible.

- Nice crafting. there are a good variety of things to build and a lot of freedom in what you build ship/ building wise it seems. I have not done a whole lot here yet, but it definitely seems decent.

Honestly, my biggest beef was that I think there should be better/ more detailed tutorial and new player tips. Everything else went surprisingly smooth for me. Overall I would still have anyone interested in a Sci-Fi survival try Empyrion out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been wanting a game like this ever since i wasted money on starforge! This game runs pretty smooth and I have not run into any major bugs yet.  Whether you play single player or MP your bound to have a great time if you enjoy free roam, exploration type survival games. It does take a couple days to learn how the crafting and building works i reccommend the tutorials. Also press F1 in game for help. I also recommend playing PVE 20 hours singleplayer to fully get the hang of the game before you jump into MP. If your not planning to play MP this game has TONS of single player content as well!

+Singleplayer & MP
+mostly bug free
+Good Graphics
+in depth crafting system
+ build the base of your dreams piece by piece
+Open world
+AI animals and bases
+almost limitless build options
+mining, farming, hunting!
+Great for Co-op
+Great for singleplayer
+build any type of vessell you wish! from the massive capital ships to tiny fighters or large transports.
If you got this on the free weekend and were disappointed i still recommend buying this game takes a few days to learn!
10/10 :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I usually don't do reviews to often but I have been wanting something like this for a while now.

Let me start off by saying that I had bought this when it first came out and returned it asap, I gave it as much of a chance before I couldn't get a refund, but I just wasn't impressed and I have lost a lot of trust in indi devs after being burned so many times (I really want to support indi devs when they give us a good product, mostly because I feel like they haven't been jaded with their art and take the safe road to earn money, indi devs are more likely to take risks, and create a game that is pretty much as close to their image of the perfect game as possible). That being said after several months I got a craving for something different then the floods of same old ♥♥♥♥ different artist. I came accross this because of the sale, 10 USD is pretty damn cheap so I looked at recent gameplay and did  small amount of research on the recent development. I was pretty damn impressed and the reviews were damn good so I took a shot in the dark. I am hella happy I did, the game has fixed a lot of the gameplay issues that were making me cringe before, and I think I am starting to see this games vision. That being said here is my first impressions.

I REALLY needed something to quench my thirst for star citizen, I have Elite Dangerous, which fixes my space flight needs for HOTAS Track ir 5, but, there is no EVA or fps in it as of the moment, this game takes my favorite genre (survival) and although light on the survival potion it produces greatly on crafting and cool game mechanics. Obviously the game is in alpha and some things leave a bit of desire, such as a better flight model, I love to fly in games, I don't really know what this engine is capable of, but they should add in decoupled flight for us dogfighters and proper hotas support, nothing crazy but the basics like being able to use a throttle for adjusting speed and pressure sensitivty for the stick. I see great potential in this game and I hope the developers still have love for this game. As a matter of fact, it gives me reason to keep playing even when star citizen is completed, because this allows me to build and use my imagination, I don't expect the mechanics to reach the scale of other titles but I am actually impressed by the fact that we can all move around with gravity when the ship is moving. I think this game would be one of my favorite titles if they added track ir support and hotas, I can also find find a script with freepie but I bet they would sell more copies to a wider audience if the devs the support in themselves. I rate this a 7/10 as far as indi games go, remember this is a first impressions, I will write another review in the future to give a long term impression.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I only have a handful of hours invested in this game, I *have* been watching the pre-release Let's Play videos on YouTube (mainly Kage848 and Games4Kicks) for a few weeks now. From what I have watched (hours of it) and played, this game is absolutely worth your time and money. The crafting is detailed without being burdensome, base-building is fun without being too complex, vehicle-building is a trip, and combat is decent enough. The game is only in Alpha/Early Access, so I fully expect all of these things to become more and more polished as time goes on, but already everything works well.

The only REAL negatives I have encountered thus far is the flora/monster spawning. Like, it just fades in in front of you, but I think that's an EA thing. I doubt they'll keep it like that.

Thus far I have not encountered any game-breaking bugs or any crashes. And while people compare it to Space Engineers, Empyrion is WAY more fleshed out and exciting. So yea, despite being an Early Access game, it's worth the loot already.

About time we got a good survival/crafting sci-fi game...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recall fondly my memories of playing Frontier on the Atari ST [and then PC]. Space combat mixed with the option to explore new worlds however, one thing was always missing however, the ability to build and create your own vehicles and indeed, buildings. Empyrion Galactic Survival covers exactly this issue and then some.

In Survival mode, you start from a small crashed escape pod, barely equipped with the bare essentials to get you started and yet, start you must.

You have enough resources to create your first base, albeit small to start with, soon, you will require additional materials. Thankfully, all the planets in the system have just the items you need but, be warned, not all the materials are easy to obtain.

During your first daylight foray into Empyrion, you will face native wildlife, both docile and hostile alike so, be prepared.

As night approaches and the stars literally come out you may find yourself peering upwards. Well, that will be your next step. Building a Small Vessel capable of extra-planetary travel but, for now, your base needs building.... Live above ground, if you prefer or, tunnel beneath the surface and become a subterranean dweller. Choose whatever suits your needs. Plasma cannons through to Gatling guns, your arsenal will determine your fate. You will also need to consider growing your own food instead of relying on the wildlife. Power, Oxygen are also primary concerns, which should you prioritise?

Empyrion features some truly stunning vistas. From atop the mountains, soak in the view of Omicron [Desert planet] through to the foreboding Aestus [Lava world]. Each world containing its own risks and rewards but, eventually, you will need to visit them all.

Although only in Pre-Alpha 2 [at the time of writing this article] Empyrion has already established a dedicated fan-base. With numerous features yet to come, Empyrion promises longevity rarely seen in games these days and, with multiplayer support, co-operative has a whole new meaning. On some planets, resources are scarce and must be divided among your team-mates if you are all to survive. Alternatively, you may want to become overlord of the planet and destroy any that stand in your way. The choice is yours.

Updates to Empyrion are VERY frequent. With player input and suggestions read on a regular basis. Empyrion has a [currently] unofficial forum that is closely monitored by the Development team and the list of suggestions that have found their way into the game is truly inspiring. This is not to mention the WIKI that is constantly in development.
Empyrion is definitely a game to grab now. With many other games offering early access, it is safe to say there may be issues along the way but, with your help and support, maybe YOU can help shape the future of this truly stunning game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of you are probably thinking 'this looks like Space Engineers'.

Yes, it does. But it offers a different experience. Space Engineers has been more about the building and the physics. Empyrion has been made to be more about Survival.

This game has been a hobby project for the developers for a long time, so I have a lot of faith that they will stick with this one. They have been very communicative with the pre-release testers and have taken their ideas on board.

This game has a long way to go, and can only get better at every turn.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent a good 23 hours - In one sitting -  lanning this game from scratch with a close friend.

I can say that the awe and wonderment of the game at the start is fantastic.

Picture the first time you played DayZ, its a very similar feeling.

This game is a bunch of exciting firsts for the player. First base. First Speeder. First space ship. First space visit, etc.

It brings a charm I haven't felt in any building games since minecraft beta.

I highly recommend keeping an eye on this game. Because it is pre-alpha it is not without issues.

If you are considering buying the game, i'd say do so. But don't expect anything after around 25 hours. It took two of us to complete every piece of content that the game has to offer, which is a fair amount of time considering some games last 7 hours for 3x the price tag.

Please note however, it is PRE-ALPHA. That means broken. Buggy. Barebones content.
Don't buy this game expecting to love every second, the devs are pushing updates constantly, but features will be added over time.

TL;DR;
Buy game. Enjoy game immensly. Don't complain about lack of content, Dedicated servers, features etc. Its pre-alpha.
Know that you're purchasing a game they may take 2 years - or may never be finished.

But for what it is now, its a very enjoyable game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

People keep mentioning games like Ark, H1Z1, Subnautica... I've been so hooked to these survival games and have tried all of them.
The first game I played was Subnautica. Loved it. You want to explore, not just for resources, but to see the great mysteries in the deep sea.
Then I played this.
I absolutely loved feeling like I am being rewarded for everything I do. First you are stuck on a planet where your escape pod crashes. You have to hunt and defend yourself to survive and eventually build a shelter.
Then you slowly gain enough resources to help you get around the large world with a hover ship.
Then you finally build a ship that takes you off the planet and into outer space where you can explore other planets for other resources.
Then you build a capital ship that allows you to discover other systems!
The feeling is so rewarding and makes you feel awestruck when you leave your ship in outer space to spacewalk and do repairs and get dizzy from not knowing what is up or down.
This game deserves plenty of praise!
I haven't yet played multi player because I believe the single player needs to be good for multi player to be any good, and it is very good.
There are bugs of course which is expected in the release. When you board your ship, make sure you are on level ground. Because when you get out, you may fall through the ground and into endless sky. This will be fixed of course, but it sucked losing two ships because of it.
This is far better than many of the survival games out there. You don't feel as proud as do in many games as you do in this. Accomplishing something has never felt this good.
Then I went on to try other survival games like Ark, and they do not compare to the sense of accomplishment as this game.
There are already so many things you can craft and build, but it seems they stopped. I worked hard at making the final crafting machine, only to find it just builds things a little faster. But these will improve in time, and hopefully more cool ideas for things to craft will arrive. The ideas of what to craft is pretty impressive. Can't wait to see what else they create.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Think I got this game as part of a pack or bundle and didn't give it much thought for a few months until I decided to give it a go. No regrets whatsoever about having this game, or about having bought several copies for friends. Came in expecting little, and was amazed, frankly, by the depth of gameplay involved in this multiplayer survival title. Survive your first night, expand across one planet, fighting hostile flora and fauna, plus an omnipresent alien force. Mine minerals, collect plants, set up farms for food, manage your oxygen supply, and build Bases, Hover Vessels, Small Vessels, and Capital Vessels. I run a private server for a small group of friends and the PvE is compelling enough that we've built a small fleet and spread amongst the planets in the system. The gunplay is solid: not outstanding, but solid.

There are the sort of negatives you'd expect from an early access title. There are numerous glitches, like textures tearing and sucking you through the world, landing gear not allowing you to dock correctly, and players sometimes despawning and then being trapped in a cockpit until a server reset. And, while I understand that this title is early in development, I'd like to see the loading screen transition between planets and space vanish. It would be excellent to have a seemless transition between space and the ground a la Space Engineers, though that is something of a monumental task to accomplish.

I would recommend this game if you're a fan of the survival genre and games like 7D2D, Minecraft, etc. This game may not wow you if your'e not a fan, but it damn impressed me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played the free weekend during alpha with a friend. It's clearly not a finished game, and will need a lot more content and care for me to want to play it long-term, but it definitely was a fun experience for those couple of days.

At first, I thought it was just another crappy sci-fi survival type game that didn't have any depth or creativity to it. Fortunately, I was wrong, as this game lets you build tiny ships mounted with 14 gatling guns, 8 rocket launchers, and a massive railgun all attached to the front of them if you so choose.

Seriously though, it's pretty cool. If you get the chance to play it for free, definitely try it, or even just buy it if you're really really into the genre. It's a fun experience and I think in time this game's gonna become way bigger and better than it is now in early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty great for how early it is in its early access status. Far better than many other early access games of this genre.

Game pros:
+ Engaging
+ Fun
+ Not a chore
+ Already well built
+ Shows incredible promise
+ Worth every penny
+ More great things coming!

Cons:
- Early Access

Pros and cons of the game are ever changing during development though because its early access. So its more important to list out the pros and cons of the developers behind it! As they are the real people who will get this game to completion.

Developer pros:
+ Competent
+ Listen to users
+ Get on pressing bugs
+ Respond quickly to issues
+ Act on intelligent suggestions
+ Have the desire to do well with their product (they work through weekends!)

Cons:
- They don't talk much on their forum (because they would rather spend the time working on the game than answering every random post, pshaw!)

I have played the competition, and I have to say the developers of Empyrion really are a qualified and dedicated group. They got what it takes to see this through, the game just keeps getting better, and they mash bugs quicker than the pros (because they have no bureaucratic overhead to jump through just to make one change!). So many other dev groups doing these kinds of games are simply a joke and not worth supporting.

I see promise in Empyrion, I see progress, and I see my money well spent already and having a blast with it.

I will update/revise the review on Launch Day! See you all there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought this game two weeks ago on sale and have racked up 105 hours. How good is your math, kids? Oh nevermind, you dullards... it's an average of 7.5 hours a day. While you're thinking about that think about this: I work full-time, 6 days a week. Starting to get the picture of how it takes root?

It's still early-access, sure, but I've yet to notice any bugs and in the short time I've had it the developers have made significant updates twice; unlike some early access titles that sit neglected and bereft of updates for years.

It has some things to be ironed out, though I'm confident it will all be addressed the final stages. The framerate is a little stuttered, the equivalent of a 10-15% lag in my opinion, and I run a tight ship so I know it's not my machine. I'd also prefer it if there were both PVE and PVP realms available for all planets. Presently, the rare minerals require travelling to planets that are PVP only.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As it stands right now I can not recommend this game to people, this may change in time but  from the devs attitude on the matter I doubt it.

The game showed a lot of promise I liked the ideas they had and the direction they where going  to go with the game. Which makes it hard to leave a negative review.

In most ways it's not a bad game and I did have fun playing for awhile. But the newest update  was a turn off for me. They added an xp leveling system and tech tree, most may say thats cool  whats the problem. The problem is no place on the steam store page community disscussion page  or empyrions website did it ever say they where going to add an xp leveling system and tech  tree. I am sorry but for a pre-alpha game to not list that as a major feature that will be  added to the game at some point was a huge fail. Either you want that feature in a game or you  dont that is a huge make or break for a lot of people when deciding to buy or not.

Now before the tech tree I think they where going in the right direction. You start on a planet  and lots of stuff is craftable their is nothing to hold you back in surviving and you could  write your own story so to speak. If you wanted to get to the higher teir tech suff like better  equipment and better guns and what not you had to build up and craft a ship to get you off the  planet to go explore other planets and moons to find rare resources to mkae the higher tech  stuff. Which was great and made sense. Now not so much you have to gain xp to open up things in  a tech tree that you have to spend points on so you can build and make stuff. Pick a bunch of  flowers to gain enough xp to level up then you can pick what you want in the level class to be able to build. Or  shoot a bunch of creatures to get enough xp to again unlock things like thrusters and cockpits  and food proccessors. Sorry I dont want a system telling me what I can and cant build in an  open world sandbox survival game.

The real problem comes down to that many have a problem with this system in the game to.Some  people are for it and some are against it to be expected. Now I thought early access games was  so us the consumer can buy into the game and test it and leave feedback and report bugs which  should help sculpt the dircetion of the game. I have posted and read a bunch of ideas on the  posts about ways to change this feature or make it work for everyone. One of the best is to  make it an option you enable or disable either you start the game having to level up or you  dont. The devs basicly said it is to hard to do that and it is already in the game and is  staying in the game. Basicly a take it or leave attitude. Now the really funny thing is someone  posted you can use hex or a program like it to go in and make one change to one character and  disable the leveling system. Yet the devs said it is to hard to make it an option.

A sandbox game should have lots of options so we the players can taylor a game to the way we  want to play it. Thats what a sandbox game is all about to me using my own imaganation to  create my own story to emers myself into my own world. This game really has no snadbox options  and by the way the devs talk I doubt their will be options for people to create the type of  game they want to play. No you are forced to play the game the way the devs want you to play  it. Which as it stands is either survival mode or creative mode. With no options to fine tune those modes to the way you want it to be. Having just those two options  does not make for much of a sandbox game or atleast not one I really want to play atleast.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a great game, I really enjoyed playing it a few months ago.

Also I've spent countless hours playing Space Engineers. While Empyrion really lacks the technical depth and complexity, it compensates that with some great planetary mechanics; something almost like a story; a little bit of mystery; aggressive aliens; and great optimization.

Surprisingly, when I played the game today, I noticed that graphics was downgraded significantly. The water shader is especially ugly now, making water look like wobbly jelly up close and like a perfect mirror in the distance. Such a downgrade makes me worry about game's future. The textures on Aqua look like they are too pixelated, but I am not sure what causes such effect.

Also I don't like another new feature - experience based tech unlocks. You have to basically shoot wildlife to unlock new building blocks. It does not seem logical nor it is fun to play this way. Maybe it makes endgame more fun by making you shoot your enemies to unlock powerful blocks, I'm not sure, couldn't get past that ugly water shader :)

At this point the game really makes an impression as if it is being developed by a single developer, and, maybe, some modeling or texturing gets outsources to cheap third-parties. That's fine, but I really hope that the development process will evolve in future.

I have a few simple suggestions:
- Concentrate on the game design of the early game stages (crafting of basic blocks and resource collection).
- Weapons and weapon animations really need to be finished/improved ASAP. The game forces the player to use weapons to survive, so using the weapons must be enjoyable.
- I don't care about loading delay on atmospheric entry, that's fine, it does not break the game. Loading that data asynchronously and doing crossfade transition would make everyone happy.
- Add more depth to crafting through more realistic mechanics.  Maybe some blocks could interact with each other to create new functional effects. Maybe resources could vary in quality" or "purity". Or maybe detecting resources could require orbital survey. In my opinion
date: any of these ideas is much better than XP-based tech unlocks. Don't limit your game to what other games already have.\n- Add more depth to aliens and wildlife. Inter-species conflicts. Races of aliens. Communication and diplomacy. Trading.\n- Expand the mysterious component of the game. Alien artifacts

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMost of the reviews here tend to be of the I liked it
date: I didn't like it variety" but what I'm going to do is try to explain to someone who has never played Empyrion
recommended: exactly what Empyrion is. At it's core
hoursPlayed: Empyrion is a sci fi space exploration and survival game
voteText: what this means is that it is several games put into one. While most games that attempt something this ambitious don't usually make it through development
helpfulPercent: Empyrion's approach is to do things simply and let them contribute to the greater whole. To better understand why this works
votesHelpful: I will explain each part of Empyrion and then explain how these parts come together to make a greater whole.\n\nThe Survival Game: This starts off in much the same way that most survival games do
votesTotal: you crash land on an alien planet with some basic tools and must address the basic needs of your survival. This involves scavenging for food and mining/collecting resources
votesFunny: if you start on Omicron it also involves managing your oxygen supply
commentsCount: if you start on Akua this is addressed by removing your helmet and simply breathing deeply
column16: Akua has a breathable atmosphere but many planets do not. While most survival games tend to give you the most basic tools by which to accomplish your survival
column17: Empyrion gives you many advanced forms of technology to start out with. This is a shame I think because there could be a whole rudimentary tier of stone axes
column18: bows and arrows to get through before moving on to automatic drills and firearms that would extend this portion of the game
column19: but that is a minor point. Over time you will build a base
column20: stock it with provisions and advance your technology level until you're able to manufacture most weapons and building components
column21: after defending your base from a few drone incursions
column22: you may set out to address the hostile forces on the planet.\n\nThe Action/Exploration Game: Scattered about the planet are a number of installations manned by hostile alien forces and automated defenses
column23: eventually you will seek them out and attempt to raid these installations of their valuable supplies and tech. I will say that while this whole aspect is pretty rough compared to actual shooters (it's no Doom) the gameplay does require caution and a tactical approach. Aliens tend to be pretty accurate with their weapons
column24: so if you try to just stand there and shoot at them you'll probably lose. Ideally you approach them from their flank or take some shots and then heal yourself with a medpack between kills. If you die
column25: it is extraordinarily difficult to retrieve your backpack and items
column26: so only bring the essentials and have plenty of backup weapons/medkits in reserve where you can easily access them if you die. Most of the time building a small vessel or hover vessel with the appropriate armaments can help deal with the heavy automated turrets guarding the outside
column27: but usually you'll have to hoof it through underground corridors if you want to secure the delicious loot at the bottom.\n\nThe Space Game: Around the time you finish ransacking every base on the planet you should be the master of your domain
column28: all alien critters who were such a threat in the beginning are little more than cannon fodder now
column29: it's time to shed your earthly bonds
column30: make a small vessel and travel to space. The resources that you're able to mine from the planet don't include some of the more advanced materials to make large spacecraft and heavier weapons. You may salvage a few from the Alien bases
column31: but you're going to need a larger supply. Leaving the planet's atmosphere you'll find a ring of asteroids which contain a material not found on the planet
column32: a nearby moon will contain other such resources. These areas of course present their own dangers for you to overcome
column33: but eventually you'll have what you need to begin construction of a capital vessel
column34: and everything else you need for interstellar travel. This of course brings us to the building game.\n\nThe Building Game: Base building is pretty simple
column35: you can create a rudimentary wooden shack or a full scale armored installation. You can even invade an enemy base
column37: and then place your own core inside and make the base your own. If you don't like to build
column38: you can always download other people's creations from the workshop and construct it in the blueprint "factory" by simply adding raw materials and waiting. At first the construction system may seem a little daunting
column39: over time as you build it becomes more intuitive and you begin to appreciate the new approach they've taken to construction which has veered sharply from the more common Space Engineers approach. At this point I think it's important to differentiate these two games
column40: both of which I deeply enjoy
column41: Space Engineers is a lot more technical in it's building approach
column42: opting for realism and demonstrating a design based on physics. Empyrion is a lot more Sci-Fi
column43: almost completely fore-gos realism for ease of use. You don't need to build a full conveyer system in Empyrion to deliver fuel to your reactor or ammunition to your weapons the way you do in Space Engineers
column44: all you need are the basic components like power
column47: throw in a warp drive and you're good to go. This allows you to make ships with aesthetics in mind over function and as you grasp the basics of the building tools
column48: you'll be able to recreate most of your favorite sci-fi ships for use in your game.\n\nThe Multiplayer End Game: Ultimately a game like this shines the brightest when other players provide the content the AI simply cannot. Here the potential is greatest
column49: you could have factions in a solar system warring over resources with huge fleets of player controlled ships
column50: everything from fighters to capital dreadnaughts. These battles could be decided through the skill of the players or the efficiency of their starship design. Once the fleet has fallen
column51: could the enemy bases then be stormed by soldiers on foot armed with a variety of powerful weapons
column52: would that fight ever truly end? What surprises would lay in store for you in a base completely designed to thwart you by another human being? Once you take their core and plant your own
column53: and the base falls to your faction swiftly followed by the planet
column54: and your fleet hums in orbit
column55: ships designed and built by your own hand
column56: through your own sweat and labor

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is like Space Engineers, only more focused on survival than building. I really suggest you get both, as they both have much to offer in terms of gameplay.

As for this game: It’s in early access so there are a few bugs/optimization issues, but from what I see in terms of update history, not only will those bugs be fixed, but there probably will be double the content there is now 3-4 months from now. 2.2 hours in and I haven't experienced a crash either.

I'll update this review when I get further into the game.

A little about the game:  2 modes, creative and survival.  Survival currently only places you in a fixed spawn location in a fixed 3 planet 1 moon solar system.  (Will be a randomly generated universe eventually)  That being said, you have to manage your oxygen and food while scavenging for resources to build whatever.

Early game, I had to forage for a lot of my food, only to eventually get enough resources to build weapons/ammo to start hunting, and finally grow my food in a greenhouse.  There is a lot of promise in the survival mode of this game, especially if this is one of the more hospitable planets there is.

TL;DNR:
If you like Space Engineers, you will like this game.  I'm definitely looking forward to future updates.
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the game I have been waiting for since my teenage years when I played Elite and Freelancer. I always wanted a game where you can explore both planets AND space to feel absolute freedom! Why did I have to wait for so long? Thank you Eleon for making my dream come true.

The immersion is there from the beginning: You crash land on a desert plant with only basic equipment and you have to survive. I really got scared when the night fell and the scary creatures came out...I had not yet built my base. Wow - what an epic moment.

The game has so much to offer and it is still in Pre-Alpha...it has more content and complexity than many other games out there that are already fully released.

PROS:
- Planets AND Space
- Great survival
- Building -> Express your creativity!
- Crafting and farming
- Combats against creatures and robot drones
- 60 FPS even with several large ships in one scene
- Very responsive development team that listens to player feedback

CONS:
- Mediocre graphics
- No PvP yet -> however, the devs announced dedicated servers with full PvP support

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked this game up for nearly 11 bucks during the winter sale and I definately feel like I've got my money's worth.

I have yet to explore every planet so there is plenty of exploring left to do.

The game can only get better from here.

-Follow up-

Me and some buds of mine got to go planet exploring and ravaging alien bases for material. We ended up building a Captial Vessel that was sore on the eyes but functional and now I will tell a story of an experience I had.

I got stranded on the Moon of the starting planet Akua. Me and my buddies small vessels both got destroyed so he spawned back on the starting planet to quickly build another small vessel (or my nickname for it, The Essentials, the essentials to solve my quickly running out of oxygen situation) from our stock pile of material back at home base.

So there I was stranded on them moon of Akua patiently waiting as I was down to my last tank of H20 not to mention my food supply was diminished as well.

In the end my buddy showed up to the rescue with more H20 and foods to save me from pending doom.

I bought it becouse of the comparisons with space engineers, its kind of similar in some aspects yeah, but also not quite, im gonna compare them both becouse thats what got me to spend money on it...

The building and going to space part is not... when you leave the planet theres an obvious change when you pass the atmosphere, and when youre in space things feel small, the planet, asteroids, moons, all look too close and too small, wich is ridiculous... i mean, im going to space to feel small myself lol
Anyways, i actually had a bit of fun with it, but went back to space engineers after a while becouse i was looking more for the space experience than the survival experience, still its a good game and in a very early stage so it can get a lot better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nExcelent piece of work in-progress, pre-alpha status leaves a few important things to be desired personally, but overall this is a pretty functional game, providing a lot of aspects of gameplay that upcoming titles like Star Citizen have promised, albeit on a much smaller scale as of the moment.. Still, I have not played a game that allows you to go from on foot, to the atmostphere, outerspace, and then back down to the surface of another planet, and set up a new base there yet. Impressive. Combat both on foot and in vehicle is acceptable, and mostly bug free. Graphics could definitely use an overhual at some point, but the engine appears to be DX11 capable, leaving a lot of room for future improvement. Enemy AI needs work too, but again, in pre-alphs state, is very playable, and enemies still provide an irritating challenge, if anything else. Playable universie is rather small at the moment after a while in game, but also will grow significantly in the future, and is big enough to provide a solid number of hours worth of gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After feeling betrayed from the disappointment known as Starforge, I decided to take my chances with this game and I'm glad I did.

Even in such an early stage, there's already a decent amount of things to do, and the concept of building your own vehicles  the same way you would build a structure is really cool too. Speaking of structures, I really like the way bases work in this game, where components need to be powered by a generator in your base.

One of my only complaints as of right now are the graphics, which are pretty ugly to be honest. However, due to the quality of the graphics, the game runs very well on my computer (Intel i5 + GTX 960), with pretty much no slowdowns. That being said, I'd easily pick performance and optimization as a priority over graphics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Aug 19, 2015. That is the day I got this game. There have been many ups and downs through all the updates. The developers have done so so much for this game, I havent played a game where devlopers had this much dedication in a very long time. The work they do is exeptional. The updates are frequent. The game always will have something to offer. It gets hard at times, things can be unbalanced. But hey, this is only Alpha. I started in Pre-Alpha, and even then the game was spectacular.  I have bought this game for friends, and we have had tons of fun. I have played single player offline on steam, and played with friends when there was the trump wall on the planet. I played when all your friends had to go into space with you. The game has come so far. It will continue to grow, I love this game. Games are meant to be played forever, this game will let you do that. (Sorry but when No Man's Sky comes out im no lifing it so rip every other game)

Everything has potential.
Graphics 7/10
Gameplay 6/10
Animations 5/10
Exploration Factor 7/10
Survival Factor 6.5/10
Update Frequency 9/10
Cost vs how much its really worth 10/10 (Overall its pricetag is a perfect one, it was cheaper in pre-alpha, but now its in alpha I expected higher price, after alpha I would expect it to be $24.99 or $29.99, for full release out of beta $30 seems practical.)
Building Aspect 7.5/10
Crafting Aspect 8/10
Potential 15/10
Overall Rating 8.1/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An amazing game, at first it may seem extremely similar to space engineers, a game I also made a review on, however unlike space engineers were it's mainly build stuff have fun with physics, make your own weapons etc, this is more... battle(?) centered, were you don't depend on ships to do everything, you also have better build physics, with things collapsing if not properly supported, now here's the pros and cons

-More advanced than Space Engineers (currently)

-Cons

-More like an FPS (only applies to some)
-pain to make ships (really needs an option to quickly make a panel/floor/ you know what I mean)
-Maybe to simple at times

I rate it 9.5/10, needs more potatoes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an early access game this is a gem, there are so many things to explore, craft, fight and loot that you wont be able to see everything in just 1 day like in other early access games, i really enjoy the game ( especially with friends ).
You can explore literally for weeks and find new stuff you havent seen yet.
The Graphics arent that great but always keep in mind.... gameplay > graphics.
Crafting in this game is pretty complex and ( i assume ) hard for new players to figure out, its not as easy and obvious as in other games, and it will requier some time to get the materials.
You can download Workshop ships and bases ( you will still have to farm the materials! ) if the building process is too hard for you and trust me it is hard, my first ship looked like ♥♥♥♥.
--------------------------
+ Crafting System
+ Multyplayer ( Really fun to play this game with friends )
+ Gameplay
+ Exploring
+ Content ( Many things for an early access game )
--------------------------
+ Graphics
+ A.I isnt programmed well sometimes.

Overall a pretty fun experience with lots of stuff to find craft and fly, it wont get boring after 1 day, especially not if youre playing with some friends.
My rating for this game will be a 7/10
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked this up when it was on sale a few weeks ago on a whim.    I didn't expect much as the week previously I'd bought Space Engineers and I had huge trouble with that game, I just couldn't get into it and pretty much expected the same from this.

I was wrong!  From the off, Empyrion was totally different, mainly it was fun to play, yes it might not have the best graphics and it might have small issues but the fun value heavily outweighs the problems.

Collecting resources is fine as it usually is in survival games but mining in this is really fun as the landscape deforms as you drill down into the ground in search of precious ore.  Base building is fun and pretty easy to do, I started off with a tiny base but within a couple of days it was like 5x larger with multiple levels, a lift and its own garden growing fruit to keep me fed.

Once you 'activate' your base it comes under attack from drones after a few hours, these are pretty easy to destroy (base gun or your own guns) and you can collect some nice items from them, there are also random things scattered around the planet you start on, crashed ships to explore and uhm.. rob ;)   alien bases, fortresses full of loot and other stuff.   Making your own vehicles is also great fun, a couple of hours after buying the game I'd build a tiny hovercraft and used it to explore the planet,  later on I built my own spaceship and left the planet, I have to say that being stood on an asteroid in space admiring the view as you drill into it for ores is just amazing fun.

There is so much to do in the game and in the time I've had it, we've had several large updates fixing probems and adding tons of cool stuff.

My last ship was a huge one with a hyperdrive fitted..   finally I left the system I started in and jumped to a new system..  landed on this awesome desert planet and died within seconds..  (it was an airless world and I'd forgotten to stock oxygen bottles as the starter planet has oxygen. lol)

Overall I give this gam a huge thumbs up and recommend it to people who like space games, minecraft clones or sandbox games.   its really good!

I don't usually play free weekend games, but this time I was instantly hooked. 32 hours in free weekend..... that's a record.

The best part of this game is the mystery and sense of adventure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion is like a slow cooked meat joint.
I mean this in the sense that it takes a bit of work to prepare, and then even longer to cook, but once it’s cooked, it’s great, and you get to enjoy it for days afterwards.

Empyrion is a survival game, where you have to survive on a planet with only the few supplies you had when you crashed. Building a basic base, you have to feed yourself, gather resources, and build something to get yourself off the planet. All the while trying not to anger the local wildlife too much.

It’s also probably a good idea that i mention that the developers on this game seem quite active, and had also let everyone play Empyrion for free all weekend.

As soon as you start a new game, you are in an escape pod, hurtling toward your new home. You can steer the escape pod only slightly. Immediately a hint pops up telling me to grab my supplies from my escape pod. Underwater i fumbled with unfamiliar controls, trying to access my gear.

Within my backpack was a basic constructor, which you can place wherever you’d like. At the constructor, you can add resources, which you will have to turn into basic components, which are then in turn made into the machines and blocks that you use to build your base.

This was about the point that i surveyed my surroundings, and realised that the graphics weren’t the best, but as with any good game, you eventually stop noticing. The tutorial was telling me how to build my base, and with time, lots of building, and about 7 different machines, i had a working base, with a brand new shiny “large constructor”, to make my base a fully functional home.

It looked terrible, it was a massive noob hub...
...and to make matters worse, the machines were attacking each night.

You only start with a small amount of magnesium, which you use to make ammo, and i had wasted it on less important enemies. Knowing that i had to find more, i decided to make a small craft, which i made have made the worst small craft that ever existed. I didn’t know anything about thrusters, so i ended up with a ship that could only go forward and turn. Despite this, i went … well... forward i guess, and after a short search, i found magnesium, mined as much as i could before the machines found me, then headed back to the base.

Get magnesium and make ammo. Ammo is the initial cost to get everything that you need to survive.

And if ammo was currency, i had some bills to pay.
The important thing to take from all this is that Empyrion is an unfinished game, but a good one. I’ve still not made it off world, but the thought of trying to get there is exciting. The very idea that i can go into space and do everything wrong all over again with a different set of rules entices me to carry on. I have really enjoyed Empyrion, and will continue to do so, and i can only hope that other people will read this and try the game. Just don’t get disheartened, when it all seems too complicated.

Empyrion is great, and when it is finished, it will no doubt be greater.

Grow a beard, play Empyrion, and instantly become awesome.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Highly recomend this excellent game! 50 hrs to date..
Best value for the year!!!

Deep build and crafting system..imagine Mine Craft in Space with planet exploration.. without the blockyness...

Pros:

1. Pro Game Dev staff in game and avialable to help load balance and break/fix - support use reported game issues
2. Proceduraly generated universe
3. Mostly stable game releases - for a game still in development.
4. Working universe that is multi player and highly customizable and feature rich.
5. Lush universe and planet environments.

Cons:
1. Server Resets can reset your ships/delete/move your game items.
2. Large game objects currently affect server rendering - game performance = lagging and slow frame rates.

Looking for adventure in the expanding universe of space...the last frontier >>

Remember there is NO FREE LUNCH >> you will reap the rewards of your actions
IF you can build it you can do it!!!
Enjoy and Journey onward and upward - worlds without end!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game truly shows potential! :)

Starting off on some desert Planet with a mere escape space ship in a foreign Galaxy with the necessary basic equipment to survive.

It is a bit difficult if you are just a beginner and hardly saw any video materials of this game before.
Like figuring out what exactly to do and where to go.

But if you give it some time you will find your way and start to love this game as I do.

As for right now it only has three Planets (including the one you are starting on called Omicron) And one Moon to land on with your very own Space Ship you worked hard for to create!

Also the Planets and the Moon has some restrictions on it. So basically you cannot fully fly around it in every direction.
But that's fine since the idea alone to travel around through your galaxy to the other Planets is fun.

And if you saw everything later on in survival mode and got everything then you can still enjoy the game by creating new and more complex things and maybe publicize them and proudly share your creations with other people!!

Also the developers keep on updating it and fixing bugs non stop!

If you didnt buy the game yet, I would recommend to do so.

If you think 17.99€ is too much you may also wait for steam sale. :)

Either way works. Give it a shot. It's worth it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSpace Engineers with enemies! I've played over 600 hours of SE, so don't mistake this for a knock on that game. Keen has done a great job of pioneering the space vehicle building sandbox genre. Empyrion takes more of a holistic approach to game design. From the beginning they built this game to be a complete experience. You start out with an escape pod on an alien world where you have to initially struggle for survival, then slowly gather materials needed to build an escape ship. Once you escape into the atmosphere of the planet you need to build a larger ship capable of intergalactic flight. Then the game really begins! I played a bit in closed beta and, while it clearly is a work in progress, the potential is clear. This could become one of my favorite games!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game still lacks a lot, since it's still in alpha stage, but it suprised me when I found the rather large huge tremendous amount of stuff to do, and I'm sure it will only get better.

I haven't gone too deep in the game because the initial difficulty is too high at the moment, and that's a big setback for me. Here's a little summary to get an idea how the game feels at the beginning:

You start next to a crashed ship that I understand you have to repair to set off and leave. The ship has several parts, including supply containers, fuel tanks, the cockpit, etc. and you have to start crafting some metal to build a base where you will spend your time around. Then you have to build a lot of devices inside the base that will help you carry on with the game.

That sounds pretty easy but the only help you get at the moment I'm writing this review (Might change in the future) is a video-tutorial where they explain how to do all that so you can go exploring, and here comes the reason why I haven't even played for 1 hour: You have to spend about 1 hour watching videos just to get started and understand some of the basics in the game.

I'm not a fan of survival adventure games, and on top of that it's not very noob-friendly currently. Those 2 reasons were enough for me to stop playing for a while until a patch introducing a proper tutorial is implemented, but if you like this genre go ahead and try it out because it has a lot of stuff (I actually had fun digging even though I had no idea what I was doing).

The final verdict: The game is enjoyable but it lacks some aspects to catch my attention at the moment. It's well-done and has a lot of stuff to do.

You will love it if you are into survival adventure games and hopefully they will introduce an interactible tutorial zone where you build a basic base, power it up, get everything ready to start excavating and go around to find resources and kill a drone or two to access a wreck.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Greetings Empyrion fans, or to anyone just starting out. This is one of the best survival games that I have played, and enjoyed from day 1. I actually started playing this game the month it was released, and from the get go, I had seen a LOT of potential for development. Most of the reason that I have enjoyed this game is due to that the Devs are keeping tabs on the interest that players have in game, and the actual development of the game overall. I do not really enjoy playing games like this alone, and have loved the fact that serveral of my friends are now playing as well. The game is extraordinary in adventure, and exploration. The possibilities of what you can build is AWESOME. Bases, hover craft, small vessels, Capitol ships, Space stations (bases), etc,,, The list goes on and on. The 3D environment, and overall optimal visual effects surpass the upper most games that I have played. It just keeps getting better everytime I log in. Game play runs smooth, and any bugs that get discovered, the devs are quick to fix them. Playing a game is one thing, but playing a game and watch it grow, and develop into something wonderful is the best way to spen an evening, morning, or an entire day. I am fortunate that my wife also enjoys the game, so we spend time together in game at home, and help each other with ideas on what to build next.

So, for the most part, the game is worth every dime that spend on buying it, and I HIGHLY recommend this game as your next survival interest. Sum it all up into one word... Enjoy!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For around $10 on the steam sale and after some free hours playing the full game, I'm happy to buy this game.  At first glance I was skeptical, and since I already have put hundreds of hours into space engineers I wasn't sure I wanted to invest any time in a game that looked at first to be very similar, especially since the visuals in Empyrion are not quite as good.  However this game has a few things that make it a little more interesting and fun than space engineers.  I jumped right into a survival game and went through the tutorials step by step and I was up and running very well.   A really important difference between survival in this game and space engineers is that this game is actually playable in this mode.  Survival in space engineers is far too slow, as collecting resources and building things would take you a lifetime, which is I guess a bit more realistic but far less fun.  So I've only really played it in creative mode, and after you build a ship or base there isn't much to really do.  In Empyrion the game is designed around adventures and exploring a little more, everything is paced a lot better and so it is a lot easier to have fun with the game.  I kind of have a similar feeling like when I first got into minecraft, the game is not visually incredible, however the gameplay is fun for the most part and makes up for it.

I'll make a list of pros and cons comparing this game to space engineers.

Pros
- The overall pacing of the game is good and there is a lot more adventure in this game.
- Lots of places to discover, various points of interest ( POI ) are scattered all over the place.
- Alien factions attack you over time, and if you find their bases you can eventually take them over or scrap them for parts.
- Variety of planets to discover, though I've only been to the local moon so far.
- Planets are large but not too big, you can get around well enough on foot in the beginning to get the items you need.
- Building a small ship lets you get around even faster and find more POI as well as collect more resources.
- Hunger system is cool and wasn't too difficult to manage, building a garden makes it easier to stay fed.
- Decent XP system and skill/tech tree to unlock.
- Variety of weapons and new tools to unlock with XP.
- Mining resources is easier, and especially when you unlock the auto collect drill.
- Dinosaurs you get to eat?
- Exploding drones, I like!

Cons
- The save system is a bit wanky, and I've still not entirely figured out what the deal is, so sometimes I loose a little time reverting back to a previous save if something horrible goes wrong.
- The graphics and models are not that amazing, a little bit cheesy in some cases.
- Weapon animations are not amazing either.
- Main character movements are not well done yet, sliding across the ground in 3rd person.
- AI animations are also not super great but at least there is something unique for each one.
- AI inside of bases still needs a lot of work, enemies get stuck on walls and it makes them easy to kill ( but I kind of like this since it makes taking out a base not an impossible task ).

So it's been fun so far, despite the cons I'm hoping the game gets more polish and development continues over time.  There is already a lot to do in this game and all of the tech systems work well, so it seems to me the foundation for this game is already pretty good.  I'm just building my second base now inside the peak of a mountain and it is going to be cool.  Space engineers planets are more of a real world scale than this game, and that is pretty cool but it also means it takes forever to explore, just getting to outerspace from the planet surface is pretty boring and takes like half an hour.  In this game it only takes a minute or so to get to space from the planet in a small ship, and it doesn't take an hour to fly to the moon either.

Space engineers has more complex systems for builders and crafters, in this game it's not so much about building a crazy space ship with pistons and rotors, as much as it is just to make something functional to help you survive and explore further.

Since I mentioned minecraft, there is one thing this game lacks that minecraft had.  This is the feeling of fear.  When I first played minecraft it was a race to build a little cave to hide in once the night came because of the bad creatures that spawn and come after you, even though they look so simple visually, something was very effective about that experience.  This game has some creatures that will chase you but nothing that is quite as relentless.  Hopefully in the future they make something that comes after you at the night time specifically, if they haven't already done this on a planet I've not discovered yet.  From what I've seen so far, the creatures in the game share the same AI for the most part.  Some creatures are passive and others chase you down and try to kill you once they see you in range.  AI cannot yet climb on blocks, so if you build a base that is above the ground you are pretty safe from them.

Cool game, I like it so far.  Good luck developers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Downloaded this game for the free weekend...skeptically, but just not purchased the game...heres why:

The learning curve for this game is fairly steep, the tutorial does help but still is not very descriptive on what you need to do, I basically had to start over 3 times after learning from my mistakes (e.g. Placing H20 on land).  But after getting the basics down I started moving along fairly well.

When you start the game you are crash landing in an escape pod, you leave the pod, grab what you can from it and then search the immediate area for a decent spot to get started,  then like most survival games you craft build a base, make sure you are fed and depending on what planet you are on...make sure you have Oxygen.  You discover mining nodes from exploration, you also discover Alien villages fortresses etc, this is where I am very impressed certain alien villages are hostile and spawn drones that will attack on site, if you are winning they then call for backup and troop drop ships come in dropping alien A holes off you make life hell....btw if you decide to attack the friendly aliens...these drones also seem to coem to you're base seeking vengeance...yeah pretty cool.

You can also discover crash sites, these can be fully taken apart for resources, and have tons of nice loot in them...typically from what I have seen they are massive in size.

Once you are comfortable with the game the next step is building you're ship, this is a steep learning curve as well...if you play make sure to read the PDA guide...step by step.  Once you build you're ship you can then move into space...discover space stations, land on other planets with new biome types that are more hostile than the starter planets, this is where the open PVP comes in, which I have not experienced so far...but looking forward to it.

The game is fairly masive and I have yet to see it all, it is a true sandbox and...well a true alpha.

What I mean by that is there are bugs in the game, but this is Alpha...and in it's current state I am still having more fun that the countless other games I have tried out over the last 6 months.  at the price its a great buy...but make sure to expect bugs....you can stil enjoy the game, but like many of the negatice reviews here...there not based on much aside from things that are expected in an Alpha state.

I highly recommend supporting this game...its one of the few with a great idea behind it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note : The devs game me a key for me to test it.

If you like immersive sandbox games set in space, you'll love Empyrion.

Empyrion - Galactic Survival is a game much like Space Engineers, but unique in many ways. It introduces many awesome mechanics, such as reentry effects and water, and is great.

Here’s a video I made on it, showing my little house, a fighter, a hover car and a warp drive ring, for interplanetary travel, as well as showing a few bugs and glitches :
https://youtu.be/zDXNMi_ziHY
In survival, you start off in a drop pod, which has just landed on a planet. You need to get resources to build your base and survive, making sure to not starve of death or suffocate (unless you want to of course). You then try to build hover, small and capital ships to explore the galaxy and take it over!

I really like how immersive the game is. After getting used to the weird controls, which I personally rebinded to be like the Space Engineers ones, you really get into building great things. You gets access to a lot of blocks even in Vanilla, like fuel tanks and elevators, but you also get to use lots of decoration blocks, like couches, beds and TVs! These decorations are great for building your own base.

Also, I’m a big fan of the sheer amount of weapons in the game. There’s something for everyone : pistols, assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, rocket launchers and even A MINIGUN! How else could you feel so badass?

However, much like most Early Access games on the market, it has a lot of bugs and glitches, and some are quite game breaking, like trees disappearing from the world (apparently now fixed) or falling through the ground (sometimes happens). Though, I am sure the devs will work on fixing these soon.

In a nutshell, it’s a great start for a game which I believe has a glorious future up ahead. I strongly recommend you get it to support the development! Who knows what the devs will add in the next update?
