reviewText:
Early Access Review

The following is copied from my review on http://pressa2join.com
This preview is for an as yet unreleased early access title"

[Disclosure: Game copy supplied by Developer]

Empyrion – Galactic Survival is a 3D open world
date: space survival adventure game with construction and shooter elements. Published and developed by Eleon Game Studios
recommended: Empyrion is currently in Early Access on Steam.\n\nAt the beginning of the game you find yourself stranded in an alien world beside your crash landed escape pod. Your first task is to build a hovercraft
hoursPlayed: thankfully there are some essential materials stored in your pod. This however will only get you so far
voteText: as you are running low on food and oxygen you will have to build an oxygen generator and scavenge the local flora and fauna for food. Players will eventually be able to build a base and either repair the crashed escape pod or build a new one of their own design (probably with a weapon or two). There is also the option to leave the atmosphere and explore the different local planets and from there build the capital vessel.\n\nFlora and fauna are numerous and planet specific (some resources/ores are also planet specific). Meaning the player will have to explore the various different planets in order to obtain the resources they require to build the more advanced items. As with most survival games there are a number of passive and aggressive creatures as well as a seemingly cybernetic race in the form of the drones and turret emplacements. The player will be provided with meat and healing items from the animals
helpfulPercent: various food from plants and crafting resources from the drones and turret towers
votesHelpful: to add a decent reward to the risk of taking on a tower
votesTotal: the player will usually find some difficult while also expensive to craft items inside.\n\nDespite being in pre-alpha as mentioned earlier
votesFunny: the gameplay is solid but understandably restricted. The crafting system is surprisingly well structured and fleshed out. However it should be noted many of the recipes are likely to change
commentsCount: with some recipes feeling a little bit over powered
column16: this is likely to give players a feel for the game before perhaps a more complicated system is introduced. You are given a full set of tools that will aid you in your endeavours which are: a mining tool
column17: remove & repair tool
column18: a filler & flatten tool and of course everyone’s favourite
column19: the colour tool.\n\nYou can also construct a number of extremely useful and often essential devices that will allow access to more advanced crafting materials which will in turn lead to more advanced blocks and machinery. Unlike most survival games there does not appear to be tiered tools
column20: it is unknown whether this will change
column21: however there are tiered weapons. There is a substantial farming mechanic in which the player can plant seeds and grow various plants which may also be expanded.\n\nI had a different number of weapons to choose with machine guns
column22: pistols
column23: sniper rifles and even the futuristic pulse and laser rifles. The choice is similar when it comes to the weaponry for vehicles
column24: there is a choice between standard mounted weapons
column25: versus turrets for larger bases and a spacecraft. Whilst certain weapons such as the rocket launcher are a little bit buggy they
column26: for the most part work perfectly fine. The enemy drones and emplacements have of course access to the same
column27: if not better technology so care should be taken when assembling the different vehicles in order to protect the various modules such as weaponry
column28: engines or indeed the “core” which
column29: if destroyed will disable the vehicle. One thing worth noting is currently vehicle and turret weaponry does not use ammunition
column30: which will be changed in a later update. Speaking of ammo
column31: the ammo for the tools I was able to use is a little on the expensive side
column32: care should be taken to not waste it too much.\n\nOf course being in Alpha there are the occasional bugs. In my playthrough I didn’t notice very many
column33: but the bugs I experienced included falling through the world infinitely
column34: which was fixed by exiting and reloading. A strange bug that caused my first small vessel to glitch and not allow any further blocks to be placed on it nor allow the use of the removal tool
column35: this may be part of the known core-block issue
column36: a reload however fixed this and lastly a bug that causes the game to crash upon exiting. However obviously being a pre-alpha these issues are to be expected. It’s worth noting that other players are reporting a number of different issues that I have not experienced.\n\nOnce I got into the game a bit more I discovered that the mechanics and gameplay that currently exist are extremely fun. This is obviously where the developers have implemented most their time. I found I barely noticed the lack of graphical fidelity due to this which more than compensated for the said lack of graphics. Obviously being so early in development the developer may improve the graphics further down the line. The soundtrack that is provided is again because of early development but quite basic
column37: but works well. The machines purr nicely in the background
column38: the music is good and unobtrusive.\n\nOverall
column39: whilst this isn’t my first ever pre-alpha game that I’ve played it is definitely the first I’ve properly reviewed. I must say I’m exceedingly impressed with how stable the game is as well as how extensive the crafting and building mechanics are. Whilst there is a wiki and tutorial provided there is currently no in-game tutorial beyond a few help messages that sometimes appear. Of course as this is a pre-alpha there is noticeably more work needing to be done on this title than any other that I have currently reviewed. All being said I have no qualms about recommending this title. Especially if you have enjoyed titles such as Space engineers or one of the many other similarly themed games.\n\nStill very early in development
column40: but defiantly one to keep an eye on."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRight now its one of my favorite space survival games to date. The fact that you can just exit and enter planets feel so great. Almost every mechanic seems stable so far. There is the infinite ammo glitch on small ships (SV) and the fact that alien Base turrets still attack you even though you've shot down their power supply? (unless they run off their own power but im not so sure} Hopefuly the devs can finish the gamebased off what was promised *Cough* Starforge* Cough* because if they do finish they may actually take the space survival genre by storm!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good game with all the basic crafting and survival elements you need to keep you playing and interested in exploring. There is no real end game content at the moment apparently, as it is in early access, but once procedural planets are implemented, there will be a tonne to explore.

The crafting is simple, but very well done. There is none of the very deep crafting of for example Space Engineers, but it benefits from giving us a more complete survival game at this early stage. The game is well balanced, and gives you time to enjoy the pace and pressure of gathering and building without being neurotic about your oxygen, water, food and so on.

I can't wait for procedural planets, but apprehensive as to how it is implemented and what there will be left to do past 20 hours gameplay.

Early Access Review

Very early days yet. This is a great foundation for an emersive game. There needs to be much more added before i'll go full on into this game.. but certainly is enough for me to invest money in it. Good luck to the Dev's, there on to a real gem here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If the stars do not convince you, then read on for a min or two... but not too long, a great game awaits.  Rated almost 5 stars, and justly deserving.

For a Pre-Alpha game this lil gem is just that, a gem.  After reading the reviews I figured I would go for it, and I'm so glad I did.   The building is in-depth and fun.  Planning of resources, expanding, and exploring a hostile alien environment... all with the knowledge you have to survive with the small amount of resources you have, in your now crash-landed escape pod.  The stars beckon, but can you survive long enough to get your escape pod functional and break free of the planets gravity?

For a Pre-Alpha I am very impressed.  And for the price ... you can't beat it.
It will be fun to watch this one evolve.

voteText: as you are running low on food and oxygen you will have to build an oxygen generator and scavenge the local flora and fauna for food. Players will eventually be able to build a base and either repair the crashed escape pod or build a new one of their own design (probably with a weapon or two). There is also the option to leave the atmosphere and explore the different local planets and from there build the capital vessel.\n\nFlora and fauna are numerous and planet specific (some resources/ores are also planet specific). Meaning the player will have to explore the various different planets in order to obtain the resources they require to build the more advanced items. As with most survival games there are a number of passive and aggressive creatures as well as a seemingly cybernetic race in the form of the drones and turret emplacements. The player will be provided with meat and healing items from the animals

I must say I’m exceedingly impressed with how stable the game is as well as how extensive the crafting and building mechanics are. Whilst there is a wiki and tutorial provided there is currently no in-game tutorial beyond a few help messages that sometimes appear. Of course as this is a pre-alpha there is noticeably more work needing to be done on this title than any other that I have currently reviewed. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good game with all the basic crafting and survival elements you need to keep you playing and interested in exploring. There is no real end game content at the moment apparently, as it is in early access, but once procedural planets are implemented, there will be a tonne to explore.

The crafting is simple, but very well done. There is none of the very deep crafting of for example Space Engineers, but it benefits from giving us a more complete survival game at this early stage. The game is well balanced, and gives you time to enjoy the pace and pressure of gathering and building without being neurotic about your oxygen, water, food and so on.

I can't wait for procedural planets, but apprehensive as to how it is implemented and what there will be left to do past 20 hours gameplay.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is a lot like Space Engineers, but with a survivalist twist. It has all the great building aspects of SE but with this additional gameplay, which includes 4 planets to explore, as well as a lot of asteroids, enemy ships, turrets, drones and bases to fight and loot, it has more staying power over SE. Its also only in pre alpha stage and its already great. This game has a ton of potential and will only get even better with time. Highly reccomended, also try playing it with some friends, although setting that up requires you to use logmeinHamachi. If you can get it working its worth it. If this game gets the proper funding and support, this game could be the best game of its genre on the market by the end of the year. easy 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

since i played starbound , im searching more sandbox games as like starbound but 3d , i bought planet explorers which mad e me love survival games , usualy i dont like sci-fi survival games , but im searching more like these 2 games , and i found this , it looks different but i also liked tp explore more planets ( waiting no mans sky release ) , so this game looks good to me , 1st , this is very early alpha game which released on steam before less than week since im writing this review , it looks good at start , but you would get confused 1st time how to survive and this game lacks of in game tutorial , graphics looks like on early 2000s which means old but whatever , the game have some fun , you can build base and vehicles , farm plants  teraformable terrain to get ores , and you can go to other planets too , i didn't bult a space ship yet but as on creative mode , you would attack spaceships too , the good thing of the game even its in alpha the dev balanced things well , he gave you enough or more than enough materials to start , ge spread the materials well like for example if you build a ship you cant arm it untill to get materials from another planet which force you to discover and build before attacking , he also gave you chance to farm some materails from enemy  , there sre some crashed ships near you which have some loot instead of spending your mats to craft  , the game isn't completed yet and there are some locked places and there are now only 4 planets to explore , ui need a lot of improvements , crafting some items would take very long time and its very slow , many many material types needs to craft and combine to make something usefull , for this kind of crafting system it needs moore advanced ui than now .

well as long as this game is less than week released , i would give it 6.5 / 10


+ no fps problems

+ you can also get material by killing and guardians and monsters and loot from crashed ships

- crafting system and ui needs improvements takes long time to craft some advanced things and need much more improvements
- no tutorial and its confuses new player  especialy who is new on survivaland crafting type games

there are some points , but these what are important now which affect on gaming , i would change the review later when the game get more updats

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is simply amazing even for pre-alpha ,theres alot to do and you can  create anything you want!
i spent hours on the game and im pretty addicted to it already with what you can do on it.
The planets what are available on pre alpha are pretty big, i like the way what they have done with the day and nighttime cycle on the planets too.

Theres loads of items you can create so you'll never be bored. however personally it takes long time to make things like building blocks (hull block).For example, it takes 7 secs to make iron ore iron ignot then another 7 secs to make the iron ignot into metal plates then 2 secs to make hull block from the metal plates you got. so at the beginning you have to wait for the stuff to be created but don't let this put you off.

the coop system works great too. My friend and I played this for hours and hours making stupid ships and killing anything in our path.
personally i would always back up your saves, because for me when i was in coop  i got stuck in the blocks  on my friends ship after leaving the passengers seat which, when  i quit, an error message popped up after leaving the game. I tried to load back my saved game and it wouldnt work, I kept on trying to load on the loading screen. so the time building stuff went to waste.
the price for the game is a steal on what your getting with pre-alpha if your thinking of getting it! i'd get it now while its cheap.
great game and great concept. i'm so looking forward for future updates with this game. well done dev's

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EA- Review.


I've played a lot of sandbox titles recently, and this one has to be my definite favorite.  The game is still in Early Acess, but its a working EA.  I haven't encountered too many game breaking bugs.  Only a few placement bugs where I had to get creative, or actually go into space to fix.  Also, per this build review, there are only 4 planets to explore and an asteroid field. (Unless I missed some way of getting to another solar system, EA game's are hard to google any useful information about.) But the game works, and its easy to learn and play.

Starting in an escape pod, to the first base, into a ship, then that first flight out into space = well worth the price.  And I see they are still expanding, so lets hope the Devs stay with it, and/or at least give us a full universe.  I haven't tried playing with other people yet, but with such a small solar system to start with, it's a bit of a mute point.  Overall, if they continue development, this game will be amazing.  But even in its current state, it's still better than most of the other current sandbox titles out there in Early Access. (And some of those that have already launched.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, how do I start.

Bought this game to try something different, I have always enjoyed the space games all the way back to Freelancer (Which I managed to purchase again last month =P). I took my time reading up on the game and fully understand that it is in pre-alpha.

After an hour of playing I had built my first hub base. This was meant to be a temporary place to survive the night. But after a lot of constructing it has become my home. It now has a landing pad which has my first ship on. Which if you look at my screenshots you can see.

I have not spent a lot of time in space due to not putting enough fuel packs into the ships (Noob Mistake but I was so excited) But space looks cool.

Word of warning watch the towers I lost my ground vessel to one of them due to a mistake I made.

So in short this game is really good so I would recommend it to anyone that is wanting to be a part of a new thing. And that enjoys Building and Earning what you have.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun sandbox survival space game in early access pre-alpha. The recent addition of procedural planets was great, and I expect great things from this game in the future. It already had a lot of fun content. I have 88 hours in the game so far and expect many more in the future.

The game gets stale in single player after a while due to its unfinished state (random planets helped a lot with this, since new games have different terrain and different points of interest) but playing with buddies is a lot of fun. I was playing with a random guy I met the other day and we had a blast for hours.

Here is a sample of a few hours of random coop gameplay: At first we set up a little base and repaired the escape pod, adding a passenger seat. Then we made some guns and flew around exploring the planet, assaulting alien bases on foot with assault rifles and rocket launchers and stuff. Then with the loot from those we made enough parts to assemble a couple of small agile fighter craft, and flew into space with our pod. At that point it was getting late so we stopped playing. The next day we played we assembled our ships (two totally different designs, we each made our own) and went off to kill the space drones and take the asteroid base. The two of us made short work of all the space drones. Then we went after the other big base with tons of guns. We managed to take out all the guns from one side of it and get aboard, then explored the station - shooting the turrets with our personal guns. Soon we had captured it and collected all the stuff from it, and using parts from the base modified our fighters a bit. Then we armed up to the teeth and had a war. I had the advantage since I was hosting (my ship was better too imo, but he insisted it was all because I was hosting lol) and I managed to wreck his. But when I flew up to pick him up he shot out my fuel tank with his handheld rocket launcher. So then we were both stranded way out in space, and decided to call it a day again. We still hadn't explored the first planet fully or explored any of the others in that game.

The positives:
Procedural generation. They are still building on this, but the initial pass of making planets procedural is nice - the solar system is currently still set with a lava, desert, temperate, ice, lifeless moon, and asteroid field. Soon it will be a larger system with more planets, and eventually a procedural galaxy full of systems.

Nice survival core. You have a constant need for food, but it's not so quick that it gets tedious. You can satisfy it with hunting, gathering, or farming. And you can preserve extra food with refrigerators, or just making long lasting food (canned food lasts for about 6 real life hours, or emergency rations that don't spoil at all). You also need o2. Starting temperate planet is breathable, but space and other planet types require you to collect o2 and keep your meter filled. All planets have o2 you can collect, you just need a generator placed in the right spot and powered. And all your stuff needs fuel, so you have to find promethium ore either via mining or looting aliens.

Various alien wildlife on all planets except the moon, hostile and docile, as well as hostile alien drones everywhere (even in space). These can keep you on your toes. My first night in the new temperate planet had a swarm of plant monsters roam in on me, before I had built better weapons. So I had to run around shooting them with my pistol and almost ran out of ammo there were so many of them. I have had alien drones come up on me while mining and not paying attention, and blow out my fuel tank on my hover vehicle (which exploded and blew up a thruster too). Leaving me to walk all the way back to my base, construct a new fuel tank, thruster, and more fuel; and walk back to repair it (now I always armor them and carry basic spare parts, haha). And trying to mine on the lava world can be a dangerous prospect, with the dangerous and very aggressive wildlife and large number of drones.

Growing variety of points of interest to explore and loot. Crashed ships, alien gun towers, complex alien bases. They keep adding more of these, most of which are made by the community. Finding a crashed ship to scavenge can provide a lot of parts to build your own ships, as can looting the alien structures. Currently no aliens actually inhabit the bases, but I believe that's planned for the future.

Crafting is very complex and satisfying. You gather raw resources, refine them into ingots, turn those into components, and turn those into blocks that you can place -  bases, hover vehicles, small vessels, and capital vessels. Putting together your first functional hover vehicle at the start and skimming around the planet exploring is just satisfying, as is taking your first small vessel into space and onto other planets.

The Negatives:

Crafting can be a bit overwhelming. You have to craft the components (mechanical parts, electronics, reactor cores, etc) before you craft the main parts (small reactor, fuel tank). If you can't do math in your head quickly you may find crafting tedious, since it would then be hard to queue everything up. I expect they will eventually change the UI here a bit to show what's needed to produce the stuff you have queued up instead of it just canceling the job when the item doesn't have parts available. Definitely needs work, but I personally don't find it bad. The latest update improved the UI here a lot simply by improving the look of the windows (more stuff displayed at once, less scrolling required).

Save system. You can't make multiple saves from within a game, you have to exit the current save and make backups of it if you want a separate save. -Edit 9/8/15- They just addressed the main issue with the save system, now you can do manual saves in game without having to exit.

Multiplayer is currently limited to coop, as dedicated servers aren't ready yet. This comes with several limitations, like being unable to move between planets unless you're together. But this is just because the game is pre-alpha, dedicated servers are planned for the alpha.

Game is a bit easy as it stands once you learn it. Alien turrets can be dodged and shot down if you have any FPS experience, and wildlife is easy to take out before it hurts you if you see it coming as long as you are prepared (well armed). This is kind of expected in an early alpha though, we'll just have to see what comes in future updates to up the difficulty (larger, more dangerous wildlife and dangerous alien threats occupying some of the bases would be nice).

Overall:
It's a pre-alpha game and is missing many of the planned features, but is already a fun game. I would say if you like this sort of game and don't mind a game in a state of flux (early access, rapid changes), buy it. You'll get at least a few hours of fun from it right now, and more to come as the updates roll in. Is there a risk buying early access games? Sure. But the devs are doing pretty good listening to their fans so far, and as-is I feel I have already gotten my moneys worth out of the game.

If you don't like early access or playing games that are constantly changing, wait for a later release. Alpha release is set to have larger planets, a larger system with more planets, and dedicated multiplayer without the current limitations. Eventually it will have an entire procedural galaxy and lots more to do. The price is also planned to go up (but then again if you wait long enough I'm sure there would eventually be a sale).

You start off screaming towards an inhospitable alien planet in an escape pod. Pretty soon, you are screaming away from that planet and out into the solar system. Or in my case, you forgot to place reverse thrusters on your first experimental ship and ended up crash landing on top of your base at 10 m/s.

This game appeals to your inner explorer, engineer, farmer, and dog fighter. It's already well worth the money, and the devs work hard (they've updated it around 4 times since I purchased it just over a month ago).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I do recommend this game, even though it is still under development.  From other comments I've read, the Developers seem to take the user's view points into account as they shape and refine this game.  If you just want to hit my highlights then skip to the bottom section of my review.  Otherwise I'll share with you my experiences in playing this for over 18 hours straight not counting a couple of hours when I first purchased it.  All of my adventures take place on the Easier planet (with oxygen).

I read part of the recommended starting guide just to get a few basics down, and then jumped right in.  Following the guides advice, I started flattening a piece of ground near a body of water.  I then started building a base.  Along the way, about 2 hours into the game I ran out of ammo for the Flattening tool.  I couldn't find anyplace online that mentioned how to make more ammo, and due to where I had started my base, I really needed to flatten more terrain.  I took a break, did some errands and came back to the computer several hours later.  I still hadn't found any place online that actually told me what ingredients were needed to replace the ammo, so I started a new game.  I did much better on this second one, and found by accident after leveling up my tech tree that at level 3 I could make new flatten tools, which also gave me the ability to make the ammo!!

I played for 5-6 hours, building up my new base but I ran out of iron from my original starting alotment.  I hadn't found any iron deposits yet, so I started raiding the broken Titus ship of useful parts.  I stocked up on first aid, food, and ammo, and went on walk about in a large circular pattern both looking for iron, and also missing parts of the ship.  I found both on my adventure, and was on my last leg back towards my base when I got swarmed by several drones, and dropped troops at the last part of the downed ship.  I managed to escape with my health below half and out of needed medical supplies.  I was swimming across a small sea when I started taking damage from a drone that for some reason had spotted me.  He killed me by following me underwater.  No big deal I thought, I just restarted from near my dead body, but of course when you restart, you don't have any weapons on you, and I couldn't figure out how to swim down to collect my box of gear before that drone killed me again.  Right after this I did a quick search and found out online that by holding the C" key down

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a very good start. A lot of games don't have this much development after a month of Early Access. Of course the term is meaningless, it's indie marketing for, “give me money now!”, but I digress... I hear that one guy complaining about how it's the best way for poor indies to make games and it supports a growing market. I'd say niche market but whatever... I'm an AAA fan but the indie is growing on me. Ah yes, review... right...

It clones certain aspects of Space Engineers fairly well, though I haven't gotten to the space game on my own yet, it plays nice. The main difference I've noticed is that there is something like a plot. (Well, other than actually having planets!) The classic crashed [escape pod] story. Space Engineers fails at any real story but then again it's highly [in world modifiable] and has a scenario system. It'll be very interesting to see the two develop side-by-side.

The atmosphere is good and the look was OK. It didn't really make me go wow... which can be a downside to many games like this. The graphics are, and should be, very basic and improve over time. But unless the developer saves the big REAL graphics update for last we never get that big WOW factor when discovering a beautiful game for the first time. It just kinda grows into it rather than hitting you hard with visual candy. Graphics don't make games though.

I don't think you can get FPS type controls wrong without the gaming community locking a middle finger on you, then quickly turning the other way. This game is good in the First Person, lacks a little in the third person on foot, but works pretty well in vehicle mode. At least you can tell that kinda thing in 2 hours and get your monies back if it's a big deal. It is pretty cheap considering that there are hours of exploration, stuff to kill, and the ability to craft your tools, bases (both ground and orbital), ground vehicles(hover craft, no wheels... yet?), and ships both large and small.

The thing I don't like, and it maybe just most games like this, is the crafting. Bare with me, I want to point you to an [example: Fantasy Life]... OK, there's that one guy who can't let a person finish complaining again. I know it's apples and oranges but it's more for the sake of a stale mechanic... just let me finish. Fantasy Life, on the 3DS, has a very engaging crafting system (look it up on youtube if you haven't played or will never). You move from station to station, pushing buttons actively, quickly, and your performance effects the quality and outcome. I'm not saying do this but do something new and engaging. Like, I dunno, a game! Most games crafting systems are exactly the same as copying files in your Operating Systems Desktop to folders and waiting for them to complete. That's all and there is no game there. It's like having to do something very dirty to get your fix. A game should always be a game, simple. No work, just game. Someone please hear this and change the crafting mechanic for games. I know someone disagrees, but they are wrong. They just haven't experienced anything better. It's like that old Apple commercial where the lady tosses the hammer into the IMAX screen. Someone toss their tool into the lazy crafting mechanic, PLEASE! You are working not playing when you craft stuff in this game and others like it. At least make some kinda puzzle out of it or something that makes the players' brains work in an interesting way and not force tedium. It's fine if you automate it in mid/late game but it's the early game that people will play first. Make a good first impression and do something different for a change!

The overall game-play experience is this: Someone turned down the lights, lit some candles, and put Space Engineers and StarMade in the indie honeymoon suite. The babby was formed, got mommy's brains and daddy's good looks, but it's still very sticky and wet with amniotic fluid. If you want to see the space/survival/sandbox/etc. genre excel then I feel this has potential and is worth tossing dosh at, but we have to raise this one right.

UPDATE:
After going alpha 1.0 (don't get me started on the new age of development and distribution, I'm old school on that... I'll just leave it at that) I'm putting a little comment here. I really like how things have gone. I got a bit mad when leveling was introduced but I have grown accustomed to it. The addition of wood and concrete, are frankly what I miss in building material in Space Engineers. That's very cool. Still, none of these games get crafting right. I like how you have an assembler/techno crafting table that makes the per-requisite stuff but it's far to later game for me to be satisfied. Seriously, this game needs an entry tier assembler to do the work for you. Make it 50% slower than the current base constructor, I can ping dinos until my stuff is done. But seriously, tedious isn't game-play. Gamers who like that tedious stuff need an option to get off on, sure. But no. I refuse to jack to your standards. It's numbing. It's re-doo-doo-donkys. The survivalist constructor can do that but once I work to get a large scale one it should make whatever item I want, make the prerequisites for me, make a damn placable/usable that I need in one go, and then I work to make that faster over time. I'm really turned off by inventory management these days as an engaging game-play element. I've said it once, for most crafting games, and I'll say it again now: This is just an Operating System GUI trying to be a game element!". Only OS devs generally try to make things easier with batch files or scripting and actual solutions that make sense. I really wish devs would stop that crap. I mean it makes sense
recommended: in a game that is pay-to-play like a "SAGA" title puzzle bullcrappery... to bank off hypnoses but I don't fall for it and it bugs me raw and makes me not play this game for months on end. Please do something new and cool for crafting! PLEASE!"
hoursPlayed: September 1, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the time of writing this, i have played 45 hours of this game. It has to be said that this is easily one of the most engrossing games i have ever played. It's one of the most exciting, fun and time consuming (not in a bad way) games i have ever played but at the same time it is unforgiving for stupid mistakes.

It takes quite some time to get a grasp of the basics for surviving, but once you've got those down the game opens up massively and you begin to realise just how large the game world is. At the time of writing this review, there are only 5 worlds to play with, all with unique resources, gravity, inhabitants and scenary.

The world seems huge to start off with, like you'll never be able to travel the entire planet on foot, so you gather a few resources and build your first basic hover craft to get around easily. From there you're able to gather resources more efficiently and speedily to then be able to build a small vessel, which you can then use to fly around the world or even fly into space and onto another world!

It's my understanding that the game Devs intend to expand the universe and the size of the planets, meaning the game world will be infinitely huge! It has already taken me roughly 30 hours of gameplay to explore those 4 planets and gather enough resources to take over my home planet.

All in all this game is absolutely worth anyones time and money, the graphics are beautiful to look at, the gameplay is extremely engrossing and unforgiving yet fun, the sounds are a little bit off but acceptable and satisfying for the most part. I would 10/10 recommend getting this game and just enduring the first few hours of learning the basics. Brilliant game. Looking forward to it's future!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThere’s so much to do in this game. I’ve spent hundreds of hours just designing my underground base and ships; I’ve hardly scratched the surface in survival. It’s like a cross between Minecraft and Space Engineers. Farm food and process it to feed yourself, install those farms on space stations or a capital ship and sail out across the galaxy discovering all sorts of different and detailed planets with their own environments and life forms. You can create smaller hover craft and space ships that can then dock onto capital ships. And if you don’t feel like spending the time to build out your own huge capital ship, there’s tons of content in the workshop. The list goes on. Definitely recommend checking it out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With 968 hrs on record so far...and many more to come...I can honestly and whole heartedly say this game is the funnest, most diverse, and unique sandbox game I have played so far.

During pre-alpha, before we even had dedicated server support, I spent hours surviving, exploring, building, and raiding in single player. Now with dedicated server support we were able to start doing all of those things together.

Eleon Game Studios has done a marvelous job at developing this game! They listen to the community, answer feedback, fix bugs, adjust PVP and PVE to diminish griefers and hackers. The workshop support from in-game is an awesome achievement as well, allowing newer players or players who don't want to design a ship access to basically whatever structure or vessel they desire.

Like I said, I've been into this game for a long while now, running my own server, playing many hours of every aspect this game has to offer, and haven't gotten 'burned out' yet. Again, very nice job to EGS for developing this game with the community's suggestions and submissions taken into account!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game still early in development.... much more feature complete than most early access games.

Pros:
Seamless transition from space to planets
Great progression system (Ground vehicle > ground base > space small vehicle > space base > capital ship)
Lots of unique buildings and decorations for builds
Very hard to crack bases/enemy towers
I actually spent time to build an awesome space station... and I never do that in these kinds of games.

Cons:
I need this game to be finished/more features so I can keep playing it... its seriously addicting.
Need more planets/things to do in space but I understand thats coming.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Join our facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/empyrion.galactica/
We are a PVP group always looking fore more PVP-centric players.  Hang out with us, get help, share pics, chat with us in the Mumble server, and join our PVP raiding parties!

My Updated Review with a few Starter Tips:

I have over 500+ hours into Empyrion so far, and I do not plan on ever stopping playing this game completely.  I have played a couple building/survival games here and there, but this is really the first one that I fell for; hook, line, and sinker.

Do I wish the graphics were AAA? Sure! there a lot of things I could wish for in this game, like when it becomes night, there should be more Xenomorph attacks like in Aliens or Starship Troopers, to make it a little more tower defense like.  I could go on and on, or maybe just on...But bottom line is, IF YOU ARE NOT A SHORT-ATTENTION-SPANNED-BUTTON-MASHING-THREE-YEAR-OLD (Thanks for letting me get that off my chest), and like Science Fiction survival/building games with lots of crafting, you probably will enjoy this game.  Star Wars Galaxies crafters who enjoyed crafting, surveying, building etc. will most likely enjoy this game.

Surviving - You have to manage Food, Oxygen, and Health levels.  Some planets have breathable atmospheres, others don't.  If you are on a planet with a breathable atmosphere, hit U to toggle your helmet on and off to save O2.

You can hunt for food by killing animals for meat, you can pick edible food items to consume, and you can grow your own food at your base with grow plots and starter seeds. Personally, I grow lots of tomatoes, pumpkins, and durians, which are the main ingredients to make a canned vegetables.

Canned vegetables give you max. amount of health of any food item in the game (150), and its totally sustainable since you grow it, and you dont have to worry about finding meat if you are in a sparsely populated area).

Surviving in Empyrion can be tough at first, but it can also be a walk in the park later on.  If you are newer, I recommend starting on planet AKUA, because it has a breathable atmosphere.

There are all types of NPC entities in the game, from Aliens to Xenomorphs,  Wait, those are the same thing. Ok, there are all types of NPC entities in the game, from Animals to Xenomorphs.  Better.  Some NPCs are not hostile, and some are KOS. Killing different types of mobs will give you different types of loot of course, but basically animals give meat and other organic pieces, plant monsters, etc. give other types of resources, and drones/vehicles give crafting components and parts, etc.

Once your base is created, drones will eventually start coming in incremental waves at your base, and they want to kill you, and destroy every piece of equipment you own. Make sure you are ready to defend your turf with an upraded weapon, and a turret on your base for defense.

Of course none of that matters in creative mode because that is strictly for building, and you don't have to worry about food/oxygen, etc.  You are free to work on your creations without having to worry about survival.  But what is the fun in that?  For the rest of us, we crave a little ACTION!  And that's where things start to get interesting in Empyrion.

PVP in Empyrion brings your stress levels to a whole new level when your precious ship you have been working on for two weeks gets shot down in your over-confident bid to attack an enemy players base!  Good thing they have a full templating system in place you can simply throw in a stack of resources into the factory, and any templated ship or base you have stored can be deployed without having to rebuild it from scratch.  Plus you can use many of the templates from the Steam Workshop in your library as well!

This game is a lot of fun if you are looking for a fairly in-depth survival/building experience in a sci-fi setting.  Personally, I wish the graphic engine were something a little more robust, such as what they are using in Star Citizen, but hey, the Unity 5 graphics are still fine as far as I am concerned.  PvP is showing to be an interesting experience in the Empyrion world, I have already had a lot of fun attacking, raiding, pillaging, pirating and building in space, and I can't wait until they release larger galaxies/sectors, etc.  I have so much more to tell you, but I will have to stop editing now as my friends want me to start playing Empyrion right now!

Most important:
First I was very sceptic because of the Early-alpha, but damn..
the devs actually listen to the community & the game is updated frequently.
I can only see a bright future for this game.

The game itself is amazing, make your base, get some defenses down, build a ship, pack the ship with 21 rocket launchers, fly out of the orbit, try to PvP, get destroyed, respawn, build a new ship, and the circle continues.

Pros:
-easy learncurve
-much to explore
-awesome guns
-tech/skill tree!
-easy building-system
-you can fly/mine in space
-0g is simulated awesomely, it's smooth and so fun to fly around in 0g
-just ♥♥♥♥ing play it already

Cons:
-its insanely heavy for the CPU, running on 85°-90° is just.. ouch.
-no voicechat in-game.. too bad
-alien AI is just.. wth. They just watch how their mates die and just stand there, confused (or maybe happy?). Or is that how aliens are? Who knows..

This game is worth every cent/penny/ruppee

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game. It's the space faring, native culling, planet raiding, resource harvesting, ship building survival sci-fi adventure, all in the glory of three dimensions, I've been waiting for since I began gaming really.

If you've come from games like Space Engineers or Elite, and found that they just didn't turn out to be what you expected in your dream Space Sim, then look no further because Empyrion literally has it all. You can find native aliens wonderiing the fauna of different planets, and slaughter them, you can discover crashed capital vessels and assault hostile Alien settlements and installations, you can mine a variety of ores, and build bases, hover craft, space ships and enormous capital in order to explore the rest of a vibrant galaxy, vessels while experiencing next to no lag at all, it's already an amazing game packed with content and stuff to do.

Like every early access game, it comes with its fair share of bugs and awkward placeholder models. But if the game is already amazing now, then I cannot wait to see what the final product will be like.

Early Access Review

If you like exploration and survival games, this is your jam. Unfortunately for new players, the wiki seems pretty out of date so there's a fair amount of trial-and-error.

A tip: Shift+click will keep you from having quite so many drag-and-drop inventory nightmares, and right clicking a stack will halve it; further left clicking will drop single tiems from the stack in hand into inventoy spaces.

I do wish it was a little less resource-intensive to play since I can just baaarely play it now and my FPS rate is pretty awful. Even so, I've been having a grand ol' time with this, and I can only hope it gets better from here!

Need more planets/things to do in space but I understand thats coming.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Join our facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/empyrion.galactica/
We are a PVP group always looking fore more PVP-centric players.  Hang out with us, get help, share pics, chat with us in the Mumble server, and join our PVP raiding parties!

My Updated Review with a few Starter Tips:

I have over 500+ hours into Empyrion so far, and I do not plan on ever stopping playing this game completely.  I have played a couple building/survival games here and there, but this is really the first one that I fell for; hook, line, and sinker.

Do I wish the graphics were AAA? Sure! there a lot of things I could wish for in this game, like when it becomes night, there should be more Xenomorph attacks like in Aliens or Starship Troopers, to make it a little more tower defense like.  I could go on and on, or maybe just on...But bottom line is, IF YOU ARE NOT A SHORT-ATTENTION-SPANNED-BUTTON-MASHING-THREE-YEAR-OLD (Thanks for letting me get that off my chest), and like Science Fiction survival/building games with lots of crafting, you probably will enjoy this game.  Star Wars Galaxies crafters who enjoyed crafting, surveying, building etc. will most likely enjoy this game.

Surviving - You have to manage Food, Oxygen, and Health levels.  Some planets have breathable atmospheres, others don't.  If you are on a planet with a breathable atmosphere, hit U to toggle your helmet on and off to save O2.

You can hunt for food by killing animals for meat, you can pick edible food items to consume, and you can grow your own food at your base with grow plots and starter seeds. Personally, I grow lots of tomatoes, pumpkins, and durians, which are the main ingredients to make a canned vegetables.

Canned vegetables give you max. amount of health of any food item in the game (150), and its totally sustainable since you grow it, and you dont have to worry about finding meat if you are in a sparsely populated area).

Surviving in Empyrion can be tough at first, but it can also be a walk in the park later on.  If you are newer, I recommend starting on planet AKUA, because it has a breathable atmosphere.

There are all types of NPC entities in the game, from Aliens to Xenomorphs,  Wait, those are the same thing. Ok, there are all types of NPC entities in the game, from Animals to Xenomorphs.  Better.  Some NPCs are not hostile, and some are KOS. Killing different types of mobs will give you different types of loot of course, but basically animals give meat and other organic pieces, plant monsters, etc. give other types of resources, and drones/vehicles give crafting components and parts, etc.

Once your base is created, drones will eventually start coming in incremental waves at your base, and they want to kill you, and destroy every piece of equipment you own. Make sure you are ready to defend your turf with an upraded weapon, and a turret on your base for defense.

Of course none of that matters in creative mode because that is strictly for building, and you don't have to worry about food/oxygen, etc.  You are free to work on your creations without having to worry about survival.  But what is the fun in that?  For the rest of us, we crave a little ACTION!  And that's where things start to get interesting in Empyrion.

PVP in Empyrion brings your stress levels to a whole new level when your precious ship you have been working on for two weeks gets shot down in your over-confident bid to attack an enemy players base!  Good thing they have a full templating system in place you can simply throw in a stack of resources into the factory, and any templated ship or base you have stored can be deployed without having to rebuild it from scratch.  Plus you can use many of the templates from the Steam Workshop in your library as well!

This game is a lot of fun if you are looking for a fairly in-depth survival/building experience in a sci-fi setting.  Personally, I wish the graphic engine were something a little more robust, such as what they are using in Star Citizen, but hey, the Unity 5 graphics are still fine as far as I am concerned.  PvP is showing to be an interesting experience in the Empyrion world, I have already had a lot of fun attacking, raiding, pillaging, pirating and building in space, and I can't wait until they release larger galaxies/sectors, etc.  I have so much more to tell you, but I will have to stop editing now as my friends want me to start playing Empyrion right now!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Enjoying the game so far and since its Early access I expect it to keep getting better. I do have some things I hope they add to the game.

1: active drones on more planets, the drone bases are too easily defeated and then you have no more drones = boring.

2: A uniformed inventory, by this I mean on your ship I would like to see the contents of all containers of a type, even in a multipage window. It sucks to search through all your cargo boxes to find something. OR be able to lable individual items, IE a cargo container labled iron ingots etc.

3: The ability to not only see the resource cost of a blueprinted ship but an itemized list of what is needed to build it, incase you want to speed up the process but dont remember what you put into it.

4: Drills for sv/hv PLEEEAASSEE!!

5: A more threatening entity, since 95% of hostiles are melee range and we use guns its kinda easy unless you mess up badly.

6: the ability to terraform water (I cant imagine this isnt being worked on)

7: and Lastly but not least Workshop access for modders to add items to the game with functions, this honestly should be #1 by far. It would help the game devs a ton to allow modders to help design items and just toss their name in the game or somethin. I would be pretty happy if my name was something similar to a 'modder assistance' area for credits or somethin.

Anyway, great game, still early but huge potential. Almost 70 hours into the game and only owned it for a few days. Thumbs up!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With over 120 hours logged into the game in early access I can say this game is simply amazing. The dev team is contently working on new updates and making improvements as well as listening to the players on what is good and bad.

If you enjoy space games and you like to build things with your imagination then this is a great game for you. Games such as minecraft and space engineers seem to be huge influences on the game.

Overall i give the early access of this game currently a 8 out 10. With more content and polish it will easily become a 10 out of 10 title.

Pros -
Customization and the ability to build whatever you want wherever you want.
Survival that actually means something and if you don't pay attention to it it can easily kill you.
Base building that matters with drones attacking your base as well as creatures you need to plan out your defenses so you can survive
Tons of things to craft that make building your ships and bases very engaging and fun.

Cons -
Has some minor save game issues
Lag at times while moving between planets
Lack of true multiplayer (currently the system allows you to play with friends but you must all be on the same planet and to leave must all leave in the same ship)
No story and campaign

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With 968 hrs on record so far...and many more to come...I can honestly and whole heartedly say this game is the funnest, most diverse, and unique sandbox game I have played so far.

During pre-alpha, before we even had dedicated server support, I spent hours surviving, exploring, building, and raiding in single player. Now with dedicated server support we were able to start doing all of those things together.

Eleon Game Studios has done a marvelous job at developing this game! They listen to the community, answer feedback, fix bugs, adjust PVP and PVE to diminish griefers and hackers. The workshop support from in-game is an awesome achievement as well, allowing newer players or players who don't want to design a ship access to basically whatever structure or vessel they desire.

Like I said, I've been into this game for a long while now, running my own server, playing many hours of every aspect this game has to offer, and haven't gotten 'burned out' yet. Again, very nice job to EGS for developing this game with the community's suggestions and submissions taken into account!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Empyrion - Galactic Survival Review
Graphics: There Pretty Good.

Gameplay: If You Played Space Engineers, You Played This, But Slightly Better.

PROS
-Fun To Play, Easy To Understand.

-Lots Of Stuff To Download On The Workshop

-Building System Is Mostly Like Space Engineers

CONS
-Certain Planets Kinda Eat Up Your FPS

-Sandbox Isnt All That Powerful (Keep Having To Refill You Blocks, No Powerful Tools, etc.)

-When You Start Building Your Ship, It Doesn't Stay Up In The Air, Which Makes It Difficult To Build Under It.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notes--------------------------------------------------------------------------
This Game Is Very Easy To Play And Very Good, I Didn't Know That Buildings Had Structural Integrity, So The First Time I Was Building My Base, The Silent Gameplay, Then A Loud Breaking Noise Gave Me Quite A Jump, Just Remember To See If Your Very Long Walkway Has Support.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Overall, I recommend this game. 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Drilling in the morning should not be my new favorite thing... But there you have it folks... I find myself getting up before the family, making some coffee, and tip-toeing to the computer just to get in an hour of pure indulgence.
Empyrion: Galactic Survival
As a new friend of mine put it, this game picks up where MineCraft leaves off. Crash land on a planet, and get through the quest driven tutorial, learning how to survive on an alien world with very few supplies and materials in a single player, open Solar System. Not an open world,... a WHOLE SOLAR SYSTEM to explore!
The graphics are fantastic. While you can make your structures completely boxy as hell; you are not cornered into it. Different tools you can make can give you a VARIETY of shapes of blocks to craft with, colors to pigment, and letters to work with. The higher up the tier you go in technology, the faster and better tools you can make.
Gather your friends, and watch your game play fly as you build team skills, fight enemies, strategize, and coordinate. The sky is NOT the limit when you hop into your Starship and warp to other planets. Or even BETTER. Hop into creative mode to have unlimited resources, and make blueprints of any vessel OR* structure you create. (Sometimes, it's both... Just saying...) Simply put in the required resources in the Factory"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I brought this game on a whim. I am a sucker for early access survival games, so it was a toss up between this and two Zombie titles. I am glad I went with Empyrion - Galactic Survival.
I put up my own server and before long there were other people playing. It was fun, we all began building our bases and getting familiar with the game. I logged off to go and do some chores, and when I came back a bit later I noticed one name on the server, the other people were all gone. I logged on, said hi and he left. Fearing the worst, I checked out my early base. All my starting metals gone, everything I had gathered, and a huge hole bored by my doorway. I mean... I know that these games allow you freedom to play how you want... ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

SOOOO ANYWAY... I started the server fresh and locked it down. I needed to get my head around the game without griefing going on at such an early stage.

I just want to say that I'm 17 hours in and loving it. I have made my first crude ship, which looks more like a Space-Ambulance lol. My base has turrets set up which I hope will deter griefers (but probably won't).

The crowning jewel of my early game experience so far was the moment I too my ship into space for the first time. It is very rewarding, blasting through the atmosphere and into the void. On my second excursion I went to the closest moon, and discovered.... well you will have to see for yourself.

I'm giving the game 9/10, it can only get better. Grab it in this sale, it is the best value for money you will find in the survival genre.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ive played a few EA survival games in my day, from all across the spectrum of high fantasy (like savage lands) to futurisitc (Empyrion) and hardcore (DayZ) to simplistic (unturned) and as im sure anyone in my position knows, they are usually devoid of meaningful content after about 4 hours (such is the curse of EA, you know what you bought).

Empyrion however deserves some recognition, with the implmentatio of .5, the solar system, they fulfilled many many promises and dreams of space-loving nerds like me where their competitors (ike starforge, Space engineers, starmade) fell short.

The solar system is massive and constructing a capital vessel to traverse the growing universe is an awesome experience when you actually get to it fly it around, bring your firends, and dock your small fighters on it.

Empyrion is satisfying, a worthy time-sink, and each update substantially improves its playability. In my opinion this is the easily the best EA survival/construction/exploration game that you can buy. The groundwork they have laid in the early versions could really lead to something truly great.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In short, I love this game. It has a lot of (brace for it) potential, HOWEVER it's still a great deal of fun as it is now.

I wasn't sure whether to go for it at first, I don't have as much time nowadays for learning complex builders, but I'm glad I made the plunge, as it proved very accessible and didn't require a great deal of alt+tabbing to read the forums for help.

It is worth noting there are a lot of bugs, none massively game breaking. Things like accidentally exiting a moving ship in space will mean you'll watch your last several hours/days/weeks worth of work disappear into the dark recesses of space. This wouldn't be a massive issue if it were not for the saving system being very ropey at best, so you'll likely have to suicide and start again with what you have left on your home planet.

But you know what? Out of all the similar games I've played, so far I've been okay with that clean reset, the potential for pouring your new ideas into designs is really good fun and keeps me coming back.

It's a simple, unpretentious and fun builder/explorer, and the devs seem active enough that it gives me hope for the future.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI recommend this game, but user be warned. This game is definitly in Early Access! The bugs and glitches can be awful, like building a small space vessel then having yourself fall out of it for no reason well it hovers around in the sky. Other than the sucky bugs/glitches the game is pretty good. You can build massive ships in space to fly to different planets or build a massive space station. I also suggest not rushing to get to space, while its worth it there are more important things to do on your starting planet like gather resources, which you always need, get food, and create a base.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely fantastic, and for an early access title it has so many features and gameplay elements that you don't even find in AAA titles. The cool thing is that this game is only going to get better. The devs are really big on community feedback and implementing what it is we want; this is the way games need to be made!

Gameplay itself is really fun, your first few hours are pretty much scrambling around trying to get all your basic needs met. I actually had to start a new game because my first time I wasted all my fuel crafting before making any replacement fuel cells first.. oops. Of course that's the point, you have to manage resources and survive. I'm happy to say that once I restarted with a little bit more knowledge I was better able to adapt to life on Omicron. Of course staying on just one planet is pretty boring, and I have had the opportunity to explore some of the space stations and loot them for all their goodies :). Every time I leave my base it feels like a completely new adventure. In fact today ill be heading to Omicron's moon to see what there.

I highly recommend you try this game. Especially when it's under $20!!!! I would recommend you watch a couple of starter videos  on youtube before you start playing, that way you have at least a basic understanding of what to do and you don't waste a couple of hours like I did on your first play through.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start by saying, its hard to write a review on an unfinished product.

I definatly recomend this game for anyone who likes:
Building
Being creative
Adventure
Exploring

I would not recomend this to people who:
Lack imagination
Inability to create your own fun/experience
RPG's
Action (though it has it, I don't think its the strongest point of this game yet.
Extreme graphics

I personally love this game and have already had countless hours playing.  The dev team seems intent on using player feedback which is great.  It's still in a pretty early state but it is still tons of fun.  Everyone on the forum has been helpfull and (mostly) positive.  It is probably the best EA game I have bought and the one I've spent the most time in despite only being out a short while now.  You have to be creative though and enjoying building, if you don't then move along.   Otherwise, go for it, give it a try!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally! This game encompasses all aspects of what I have been looking for in a game. Survival, gathering, crafting, building, sandboix, planetary travel, and on, and on. From fighting to survive on the first planet to building your space craft to go explore the other worlds, to building space stations and living in space. Liftoff and landing on one of the moons to explore it for the first time was a monunetal moment in gaming for me.  For so long I have been looking to accomplish this in a game, thank you Devs!

For being in pre-alpha, the game runs smooth and seamlessly. I cant say enough good things about the game and the effort and thought the Devs have put in to this so far, and it's only pre-alpha!

Highly Recommended

Early Access Review

Really Great Game!

Some people say it is hard to play, it has the great feeling of uncertainty of how to do things like your first time playing minecraft.

Npc's are challenging and require you to upgrade your ships and equipment to take them on.

Many bugs in game but non i have experience that were game-breaking.

Loads of fun in multiplayer (Forward port 30000 and search whats my ip" on google to play)

Few downsides are that you must get all multiplayers in your ship to transfer to planets and space but is understandable to put less preasure on your pc and network until dedicated servers are out.

Food is my biggest problem in this game
date:
but you need less than oxygen which is good.

Minor bugs are decently common but minimal for an Early Access

Final Review= 8/10
Potential= 10/10

Once bugs are fixed

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game in very impressive. I've not tried Multiplayer yet, Still getting the hang of it. Had Minecraft been like this, I may have actually tried it.

Crashed on a deserted planet, You have to deal with basic survivial. Uses a block construction system that I suppose has become pretty common (Again, I don't play this kind of game often).

Highly reccomened, As its Pre-A stage, Its already a ton of fun to play. To know there's SO much more coming down the road only makes it worth a go.

Due to its early stages though, be sure to use the wiki links and videos if you need assistance!

Oh, and as I just learned, When you do decide to brave leaving your familiar world and going to another, Be sure to leave some kind of base supply kit at your starting point, Cause when that drone destroy's your ships fuel tanks and you can't run your assemblers... life sucks.

All in all 4/5 on a game thats not even in Alpha yet!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most of the negative reviews for this game...are either from people who have no idea what they are talking about, or are outright lying.

Devs are doing a phenominal job moving along with their vision while incorporating a huge amount of content requested by their players.

It is not game breakingly buggy, that's bu11$h1t. Sure it has things still being worked out. It's pre-alpha WTF would you expect?

For those that say it's just a PvP arena; explain to me how that works in single player? On multi player it is up to the server admin as to what areas are PvP or not. Sure there is no interface to change that yet...but rub a couple braincells together and use google....BAM!...you too can become a quasi expert at yami file adjustments.

Are the graphics optimised yet? No, it's pre-alpha. Optimisation is the stuff that comes last.

People are claiming the flight controls are aweful....chances are you built a crappy ship.

Put simply, if you are the kind of person that loves to see things improve over time and do nothing but get better, this game is for you. Well, if you like survival/building/exploration/PvE/PvP/FPS/TPS(admitidly third person view needs some refinement when you're on foot)/single/multi player games. It's incredibly inexpensive for all that, give it a shot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looking for a good survival builder game? This game is just about everything you could want, randomly genereated seed maps, full bases with defences, ground vehicles, space ships both fighter and capital ship sizes. Your choice of build sizes and styles matter, you cant just build a death star and keep it powered...at least not for long. The little things like food and health management are not so complex it removes from the enjoyment of the game play but  are just enough to add depth.

Before I picked this game up I was just waiting for No Man Sky"
date: now Im more interested to see where the devs take this game as it progresses through alpha.\n\nNo back to designing and building my first space ship."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've spotted this game because of SE. Tried it out multiple times. Don't bother with my play time, played a way lot more than that.
To be honest this game is half year old and compared to SE it has some weaknesses, but i remind you: this game is half year old, and an early access.

What you should expect:
-Fun
-Innovation
-Fast progress (this game is expanding really fast)
-Survival - > Crying - > Rage quit XD :D
-Some bugs
-Different approach

I enjoy this game way more than SE. It has better performance with enough attractive places. (With secrets to be explored)
There is a long way for it to be perfect, but Devs are on the best way to achieve this goal.

Give it a try, after some rage quits you will enjoy it's full potential.
If this game will get more exploring and a Save As" (ingame) button instead of backup ^^  then it will be 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I brought this game on a whim. I am a sucker for early access survival games, so it was a toss up between this and two Zombie titles. I am glad I went with Empyrion - Galactic Survival.
I put up my own server and before long there were other people playing. It was fun, we all began building our bases and getting familiar with the game. I logged off to go and do some chores, and when I came back a bit later I noticed one name on the server, the other people were all gone. I logged on, said hi and he left. Fearing the worst, I checked out my early base. All my starting metals gone, everything I had gathered, and a huge hole bored by my doorway. I mean... I know that these games allow you freedom to play how you want... ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

SOOOO ANYWAY... I started the server fresh and locked it down. I needed to get my head around the game without griefing going on at such an early stage.

I just want to say that I'm 17 hours in and loving it. I have made my first crude ship, which looks more like a Space-Ambulance lol. My base has turrets set up which I hope will deter griefers (but probably won't).

The crowning jewel of my early game experience so far was the moment I too my ship into space for the first time. It is very rewarding, blasting through the atmosphere and into the void. On my second excursion I went to the closest moon, and discovered.... well you will have to see for yourself.

I'm giving the game 9/10, it can only get better. Grab it in this sale, it is the best value for money you will find in the survival genre.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ive played a few EA survival games in my day, from all across the spectrum of high fantasy (like savage lands) to futurisitc (Empyrion) and hardcore (DayZ) to simplistic (unturned) and as im sure anyone in my position knows, they are usually devoid of meaningful content after about 4 hours (such is the curse of EA, you know what you bought).

Empyrion however deserves some recognition, with the implmentatio of .5, the solar system, they fulfilled many many promises and dreams of space-loving nerds like me where their competitors (ike starforge, Space engineers, starmade) fell short.

The solar system is massive and constructing a capital vessel to traverse the growing universe is an awesome experience when you actually get to it fly it around, bring your firends, and dock your small fighters on it.

Empyrion is satisfying, a worthy time-sink, and each update substantially improves its playability. In my opinion this is the easily the best EA survival/construction/exploration game that you can buy. The groundwork they have laid in the early versions could really lead to something truly great.

IMHO adding aspects of Minecraft, Techit, Space Engineers and a Research tree to the game as well as the ability to have programmable and automated machines will result in sales bigger that all the games I just mentioned combined.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing! I am mostly an RPG/FPS/strategy player and go through a survival space sandbox for first time. For a pre-alpha state the game like a standard release state. The dev team continuously update. The game is extremely addictive even just on single player/PVE. You can play any style you like, fight on foot, fight with crafts, mine resources to make a stock, build a lot, no problem. Anything you do you gain experience and unlock more crafting options. Oxygen and food however are a constant need so survival never actually fades.

I recommend this game 200%.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI don't normally play early access, so I don't know why i bothered with this.  But I did, and it's awesome.  If this was the finished product, I'd be just as happy.  This is hours and hours and hours of crazy survival open world space scifi insanity fun. I've sunk more hours into this than I did playing and finishing Skyrim.  And even though it's early access and you sometimes spend DAYS building a a base and a spaceship only to have a new update come out and in order to access all the new features (which come out with alarming regularity), you need to start a new game...you start a new game anyway and spend more days building new stuff in a different way because it's JUST THAT AWESOME.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very promising Sci-fi Survival game with a large scope of vision that is currently marred by it's incomplete status. Like many, I became aware of and played this game by the Free Weekend. Survival games are not my forte, I'm terrible at crafting in almost any game, the only survival game I've ever had any luck at would be MineCraft, if that counts.

Despite the complexity of this game, going from merely surviving to eventually building bases and even starships to colonize other worlds, the game has a nice enough guide/tutorial in the PDA feature that can help one learn the ropes and build the basic facilities and supplies to survive

Crafting is complex in scope but can be simple enough in practice with a fair crafting UI that while it has filters to make finding specific recipes easily, badly requires some manner of sorting, be it player-chosen or automatic, the inventory could also benefit from a sort feature.

Besides the usual hunger and health functions, Oxygen is also a feature. Oxygen is needed to survive the vaccuum of space or going underwater but on breathable worlds, one can easily just doff their spacesuit's helmet and enjoy native air.

Unforutnately, at this point in time bugs seem to run mighty severe. My first game I gave up on when my Large Constructor, a neceessary device needed to make a 'real' base functional and allow one to go beyond making the bare basics, basically disappeared when I dared to put some walls near it. My second game ended with my character falling through the world forever while I was mining.

All in all, it's got great ideas and scope but it needs work. Hopefully it will overcome it's errors and bugs.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Broad assessment:

I have been extremely pleased with the continual developent and refinement of Empyrion. I've played this game off and on for several months and whenever I check it out again, new features have been added, controls have been refined, etc. The pace of development is overall pretty fast too. The most important thing with game development in general, and early-access games in particular is whether you maintain an active cycle of game design and play testing. The devs seem to know this and are doing a good job on that front.

I have played a lot of early-access survival sandbox games and the core thing that makes these games fun is depth of exploration, broad creative ability, and facing a variety of core survival challenges. The game isn't complete, but as it stands, it hits those marks. To boot, it has a fairly straight-forward interface, and maintains a decent learning curve so you feel you're actually getting better at the game and improving your strength and ability. It's increbily enjoyable to explore your surroundings, find hostile alien bases, defend against monsters and drones, build your base and spacecraft, conquer the hostile alien bases around you, and finally build up to the point where you can make a capital ship to explore other worlds.

Some stuff that's cool about the game:

Something I like about this game is that you can actually screw yourself over - if you're not careful with your resources, let all your stuff get blown up by drones, etc, you will be stuck, especially if you choose the harder planet to start on. This lends a little bit of urgency to the game. Some people will find the game easy, some people will be frustrated.

When I first played this game (in a far earlier version) I let some core resources get blown up. I lacked basic resources to survive and had to attempt an assault on a nearby crashed spacecraft that was guarded by drones. I survived barely by the skin of my teeth. Frankly, I was just being stupid, but the fact that I needed to actually think about survival was cool.

Another example of the difficulty in this game is that if you get too cocky and leave your stuff undefended, it can get attacked. For instance, there have been a couple of times I left my craft to explore an alien base and had a rocket drone sneak up on me. I've read a couple reviews complaining about this happening to them. Is this annoying? Of course! But, what do you do? Whine, moan, and give up? Or, do you hike back to your base, learn from your mistakes, build a better ship, remain more vigilant, and take revenge on the base that killed your stuff?

Like any game, some people will find this easier than others, and once you have a nice network of bases and ships built, you're not going to

A few notes:

I personally think the new tutorial system they set up is pretty good. That said, I have never played a survial game where you shouldn't read the wiki.

Also, the multiplayer component of the game is pretty fun, but not super-built out or populated yet - I haven't done any PvP, but working on builds with other players is cool.

Stuff that still needs to be better:

My main complaint about the game is that depth of play still needs to be massaged. You will probably max out your tech tree before you even leave your first solar system. It would also be nice if there were more cases where tech improvements unlocked further ability to explore.

Block placement in construction is still in need of some refinement, but it's quite workable.

Also, it would be nice if there were easier ways to work with and interact with terrain voxels.

Final word:

If you're into survival/creative games, get Empyrion!
